summary: In the years after the Civil War, Jo March lives in New York and makes her living as a writer, while her sister Amy studies painting in Paris. Amy has a chance encounter with Theodore, a childhood crush who proposed to Jo but was ultimately rejected. Their oldest sibling, Meg, is married to a schoolteacher, while shy sister Beth develops a devastating illness that brings the family back together.

reviews.content: Terrible story, based on a badly written and boring book.

Minha opinião: Um filme que é um #remaker E da mesma forma que aqui temos uma constelação de atrizes em 1994 também havia. Winona Ryder, Kirsten Dunst, Trini Alvarado, Claire Danes, Susan Sarandon e Christian Bale. Agora nesta versão de 2019 temos Saoirse Ronan, Florence Pugh Emma Watson, Eliza Scanlen, Meryl Streep, Laura Dern e Timothee Chalamet. Este filme de 94 não assisti. Comecei a ver com grande expectativa o filme, talvez coloquei muito, por isso tenha exigido mais. Confirmo que não fui na totalidade preenchido com a expectativa. Mas não deixa de ser ruim. As atrizes de maior destaque são Ronan e Pugh e Chalamet. Medianos Watson e Scanlen e Streep, Garrel. Abaixo da expectativa Dern. Um filme que passa na época da guerra civil americana, onde os pais das irmãs esta na guerra. Vivem elas e sua mãe desde a junventude até mocidade. Os sonhos a levaram cada um por um caminho. Jo vai a cidade grande tentar ser jornalista e escritora, Amy vai a Europa, Meg se casa e Beth se torna pianista. E neste momento existe amor não correspondido e correspondido que envolve Laurie. Até que o destino tras ela de volta além do pai que regressa da guerra. Ai lavam a roupa e se resolvem. O filme tem vários cortes de tempos em tempos. E isso não da a profunidade necessária para o filme, pois no momento que parece que vai dar sequência ela corta e passa mais anos e volta. Para mim isso não deixou que se apronfundassem. Uma pena, talvez pulassem menos períodos e aprofundasse ficaria melhor a estoria. A participação de uma atriz como Emma e ser colocada como coadvante de 3º escalão e depois de fazer um filme como a "Bela e a Fera" onde teve uma interpretação digna de Oscar.
Roteiro e enredo muito picotado o roteiro. Não utiliza de forma boa as atrizes que tem.
Vale apena assistir? sim
Nota: 7

This beautiful journey weaves together multiple subplots to create an emotional and well-executed film. While the movie initially jumps around, by the second half it settles into a rhythm that is emphasised by the talented casting choices.

Despite the grace and elegance that the film exudes, it occasionally misses the mark. Frequent cuts between angles and scenes detract slightly from the emotional impact of some of the cinematic moments, which would have been better served by longer tracking shots.

Furthermore, a consistent theme throughout the movie is lust and hurt, which the film score could have explored more to enhance the story's impact. The film missed an opportunity to elevate itself in the same way that La La Land and Marriage Story did. 

Overall, this film is a well-crafted, fantastically acted emotional journey that is much worth the watch.
Gostaria de dizer que: Bom, mas a Florence como criança ficou bizarro!

This re-adaptation captured the subtleties of the novel almost flawlessly. Though some parts of the movie felt too polished off, Gerwig was able to highlight all the complexities of emotions of each of the characters. Coupled with the fact that the actors were all superb in their performances, this movie surpassed my expectations and was my favorite depiction of the classic novel.

While it is a little long, this newest adaptation of Louisa May Alcott's classic novel, "Little Women," may be the best version yet. In this version the story of the four March sisters (Amy, Jo, Meg and Beth) in the 1860s is told through flashback from their later lives, which at times seems a little confusing and unnecessary. Still, the Jo and Laurie storyline is as heartbreaking as ever in that Anne of Green Gables and Gilbert sort of way. The cast in superb with the March girls really inhabiting their characters. Saoirse Ronan is wonderful as the feisty and energetic Jo, determined to find her own truth in the world and Florence Pugh makes me dislike Meg that little bit less than usual.
the story is fresh, telling the meaning of life and how people get to interact with others.
Most beautiful thing I have ever seen

Saoirse Ronan is just another example of casting very pretty conventionally attractive women in roles that are not meant to be filled by a traditionally pretty woman. Jo is made to look much prettier than she should be, a fault of both the casting and costuming, and makeup departments. My two biggest issues with the movie are the time jumps which make it hard to understand the movie and how that affects how we see the characters grow and become better people. The movie does not live up to Louisa May Alcott's original vision and message of sisterhood and familial love as the cast has very little chemistry with each other. Even worse is Timothy Chalamets portrayal of Laurie. It's not a bad movie. Its a mostly enjoyable watch. But overall it has many flaws that just don't make it the Little Women we all know and love.

Even better after a second viewing. This movie is just a master class in filmmaking by Greta Gerwig and her whole crew. The color correction is gorgeous, the colors feel alive, you feel like you are in that time, but when we switch back to reality from the past, the colors are darker, they are more cold and I love it. The camerawork in this movie is incredible, the acting of everyone is so good, with Saoirse Ronan of course as the lead performance and probably the best performance. The production design is just gorgeous, heads off. This movie is so emotional and I am pretty young still, but I watched the movie with my mom and I hit her really hard, I love this movie.
Overall liked this take on little women as someone who has seen both older versions. Emma Watson is a terrible actress but saorise and Florence are great

Excuse my lack of words to properly review this movie.  I'll keep it short and sweet.  It's difficult to not view this through the lens of the 1994 Gillian Armstrong version.  This is a very good movie, but by comparison I find it too quickly paced, lacking in character development, and just without the heart of the 1994 version.  In particular it's difficult to swallow the decision cast the parts in such a way that they normalize all age differentiations.  I haven't read the book, so I can't say if this choice makes it less faithful but I'm guessing it does.  Obviously the sensibilities of modern times make some of the relationships in the 1994 film cringe worthy, but it is more faithful to the times.  Making everyone seem almost the same age sort of erases the motivations for the characters to be who they are.  For me there's just no substitute for the 1994 version.  I'll cry every time when Claire Danes gives her big speech, but that's because the character was developed without the need for hurry.  This sounds like a terrible review but I'm still giving it 4 stars on its own merits.  Compared to the 94 version it would be 2 stars, but that's a tough movie to be compared to.

One of the best casts i have ever seen!
Greta Gerwig perfectly captures what womanhood feels like in both the movies she has directed, she is such a breath of fresh air.Saoirse Ronan's and Timothee CHalamet's chemistry is amazing as well.Only thing that bothered me a bit is the few moments were Saoirse's accent slipped and you could tell she is not american
wonderfully adapted and acted. compelling rendition of a classic.
gut wrenching, humorous, well directed and well acted
The score, acting, costumes. Everything works so well together. I laughed and cried while watching this movie.
Coming of age drama and great production design.

One of the few must see period dramas.

The movie Little Women have 3 versions, as in 1949 was the first. What impressed me the most is the latest re-make of it, released in 2019 and directed by Greta Gerwig. There are not much of difference to the plot from the original book - "Little Women" written by Louise May Alcott. This American coming-of-age period drama film really knocked me sideways was despite of the flow of the movie was soothe, the intentions for describing feminisms, women rights, and their role in the society was fully drawn. Personally, I find a scene of Meg, which myself find it was a stroke of exquisite, was when Jo persuaded Meg cancel her marriage to become an actress, though Meg said: "Just because my dreams are different than yours, doesn't mean they're unimportant. I want a home and a family and I'm willing to work and struggle, but I want to do it with John". To my mind, feminism nowadays only focus on how women have to have the abilities and positions like men, therefore, housewives are old-fashioned, a waste for future. The character Meg played by Emma Watsons is a brilliant example to clarify the actual - modern definition of Feminisms. In a nutshell, my experience with the 2019 film was satisfy, and I highly recommended this movie.
Do not watch a film that distorted the history!
Saoirse Ronan was amazing (as usual) and Florence Pugh killed it! The cast was fantastic, and the music was amazing.

I liked some aspects of this film - I liked that it is, in effect, a story within a story and I'm a fan of Saoirse Ronan - I thought she did well as Jo March. The cast is pretty decent overall, with Emma Watson, Florence Pugh, Meryl Streep, James Norton and Timothee Chalamet also present. I like that the story has at least an element of female empowerment about it, particularly at the very end. I did cringe at the really 'girly girl' aspects of it and indeed, of course, if your not keen on 'twee' period dramas with giggling female siblings and the like then this may well not appeal to you but even so, I felt this was a well made film and it has enough going for it for the rating I gave it. It won't be for everyone, so I wouldn't outright recommend it to all but if it sounds of interest, if you liked the book perhaps or your keen on the cast, a fan of period dramas and curious about this, then yes, it probably is worth seeing but otherwise, maybe not so much. I hope this review is helpful.

2 yeas ago- Flawlessly directed and brilliantly acted, I felt briefly confused after not having been familiar with the source material but the film quickly eased me into it's world for a dramatic film experience.
Very enjoyable to watch, full of life and intense emotion. The story also has themes of creativity, passion, friendship and jealousy.
Adorável como o livro, e com atuações impecáveis!🥰
Needless to say, It's Great!

Very emotional and I (personally) found lots of it frustrating, but its non the less one of my favorite movies of all time. The acting and messages hit me to the core!
The acting was brilliant and the costumes exquisite, but it really didn't live up to my expectations. It didn't capture me as I hoped it would, it took me 3-4 days to watch it.
Stellar cast, great performances, but the story was hard to follow/ implausible.
I didn’t want to like it… because I loved the previous one. It took some getting used to a few things, but I thought it was great—-very well done!

What is the secret to taking a beloved classic story that practically everyone knows, a tale that has previously been turned into a motion picture five times and that has been adapted for television at least ten more times, and telling it in a way that is fresh and innovative?  The answer is a simple one… you let Greta Gerwig write an updated screenplay and then let her direct a feature film of her screenplay!

Little Women was written by Louisa May Alcott and first published in 1868.  It tells the story of the March sisters (Jo, Meg, Amy, and Beth) as they transition from childhood to womanhood.  They reside in their childhood home in Massachusetts during the timeframe of the American Civil War.  Their father is away serving as a chaplain in the Union Army.  As the story opens, the four sisters are living in their childhood home with their mother, Marmee.  When word arrives that their father has contracted pneumonia, Marmee heads off to Washington DC to nurse him back to health.   The four little women are now left to their own devices to take care of each other while also determining their fates and futures.  

In Gerwig's 2019 film, the sisters are portrayed by Saoirse Ronan(Jo), Emma Watson (Meg), Florence Pugh (Amy), and Eliza Scanlen (Beth).  Each actress is absolutely wonderful, and the relationships between the sisters are complex and fully fleshed out.  Mother Marmee is portrayed by Laura Dern, and the girl's crusty and wealthy Aunt March is portrayed by Meryl Streep.  The film captures the era perfectly and the period costumes are simply divine (Best Costume Design would be the film's one Oscar win).  

Huge praise is due to Gerwig for her ability to update the story in ways that resonate with a modern audience.  She deftly cut the story into a non-linear one, bouncing back and forth between time periods.  And her clever twist on the film's conclusion was both interesting and satisfying.  No spoilers!  This movie was a wonderful example of great storytelling, superb acting and topnotch directing.  Despite my familiarity with the story and having seen other versions on-screen, this film was a class act and well worth the viewing.
A delightful movie. I’ve seen at least two different adaptations and this was lovely

Little women (2019)

The movie «Little women» is based on the book by Louisa May Alcott. It stars Emma Watson, Saoirse Ronan, Florence Pugh, Eliza Scanlen, Timothee Chalamet. The movie won an Oscar in 2020 and six nominations.

The movie is set in USA. It was filmed on location in Massachusetts, Boston.

It is about four girls, who have different hobbies and goals in life. Jo is a writer, Elizabeth adores playing the piano, Amy is an artist and Meg likes to play performances. Unfortunately, not all of them could find love and achieve a dream. But I don't like the end because Lory and Jo aren't a couple, although they had a close relationship.

I strongly recommend «Little women». It has romantic, drama and unforgettable moments.I am positive that you will like and enjoy it.

I liked this movie a lot and definitely think you should watch it if you like historical dramas.  The time jumps make the plot very interesting.  I enjoyed seeing the characters develop over time.  The plot is very character driven and the characters themselves are very entertaining.  The movie speaks a lot on the issues women faced and it was great to see that represented.  Little Women is one of my favorites because of the relationship between the sisters.  This movie does that justice and displays familial aspects of the plot accurately.  Overall, I loved watching this movie and I recommend it.

Well well well. It was honestly really good. Out of all of the Little Woman adaptations throughout the years, this is one of my favorites. I absolutely love the cast including the iconic Emma Watson, Meryl Streep, and Timothee Chalamet.  The thing with this movie however is that I think you would be a little confusing if you haven't read the book, or weren't familiar with the story. The movie was set up to go back and forth between the years as Jo March, one of the main characters, writes her book. One thing I noticed about this film and actually liked, was how they kept the main actors in to play the young versions of the characters when going back in time. It showed how talented the cast was and the range in which they can act. Overall I think it is worth the watch if you are a fan of this heartfelt story. 4/5 stars.
I cried, I laughed. It made me feel sad and anxious. I feel everything.

There are several layers to this story that the film delves into wonderfully.
Most of them focus on 18th-century women, their attitude towards them, and their choices at the time, raising questions and discussing complex issues, such as female independence, and who thought of that? The world of women came down to having children or is there more to it? Rebellion at that time was it heavenly mourning or liberation? And more ...

 In short, this is a film about the status of women in the mirror of history, and the execution in it is great, whether in the opinion, ambition, and skills that are expressed here in its good script, or in the excellent photography, the amazing acting, and the excellent costume design.
The transition between times through flashbacks adds emotion and longing and to my taste was well done.
Now, in my opinion, this is not an amazing film, but it is on the borderline of very good and amazing, and that is because I think it would not hurt to shorten the script and film by a few minutes.

"My little women."

The ultimate comfort movie when things are getting out of hand in your life.

Little woman 2019, is a drama movie directed by Greta Gerwig, the movie is one of the seven adaptations of the Louisa May Alcott novel of the same name. The main characters are the Four sisters Meg, Jo, Beth, Amy and their friend Laurie. They are played by, keeping the same order: Emma Watson, Saoirse Ronan, Eliza Scanlen, Florence Pugh and Timothée Chalamet. 
The film tells the lovely story of the March sisters, it takes place in Massachusett during the 19th century. The story tells how they grow up and change, but it also tells very interesting and deep lessons of life with the help of little scenes from the sisters' lives. Some people can find the plot boring but I don't, because the way in which the timeline of the film was shot is different from the one in the book. In the book, the first half follows the March sisters when they are young girls, and the second half consists of their adulthood. In the movie, we have two separate timelines that start in 1861(past) and 1868(present). I must admit that it's a good idea because it helps to get into the film immediately. The plot is a little bit predictable but that doesn't change anything because even if we expect it, it doesn't make the film less moving. 
I think the acting was perfect, all the actors fit in their characters. The scenes were well done and very real thanks to the acting. All the actors managed to give life to their role in this movie, they made them sentimental, sad, angry, all that very well. 
The shooting techniques are really wonderful, a result of the fact that the film is relatively new. My favorite shots are the ones where you can see the landscape that seems unreal in the background or the ones where you see the four sisters together. All the soundtrack has been realized by Alexendre Desplat. The soundtrack helps a lot to enter into the wonderful atmosphere of the movie. Somes of the music is happy and some are not, it depends on the scene but all the music is adapted with the movie. In my opinion costumes are really important, they can tell a lot about a character. We can see the ones who are negligent, like Jo or the ones who take care of how they look, like Meg and Amy. We also can see the characters who have a relationship with another, like the fact that Jo and Laurie are sometimes wearing the same clothes, it shows that they are close friends. It's also important to be able to find your way in the history and to realize that the film takes place in the 19th century. 
The film has a lot of messages, each character has something to learn in the movie, for example, the message of Jo's story is that life can be hard especially for a woman and you can't always get what you want but that's not why you should give up. I really like the message of Meg's story, I find it touching, the message is that you don't need to be rich and in high society to be happy, you need to be surrounded by the people you love. 
Generally, I really think this film is fabulous, maybe one of my favorites. I recommend this film to anyone who loves old drama movies. For the ones who read the book, the film is very similar so if you liked the book go watch the movie. If you haven't seen it yet, you now know what you're missing.
I love the character development from each siblings, mostly florence pugh'character. Perfectly balance movie with a balance emotions.

LOVED the vibe of this movie. The overall vibe was superfood and the switches between the past and the future made the movie extra engaging. I really enjoyed the Amy and Laurie story-;line and how it contrasted with their relationship with when they were younger. I also liked the widely different personalities of the four daughters and how this caused for clashes in between them, but also love among them.
Emotive and wonderfully shot. Great cast and I felt like the characters they played were so well brought to life. Florence Pugh as Amy was a delight.

Little Women is a film that I passed on seeing many times, whether it be with friends or with my family, I always chose to not watch it as I figured I wouldn't enjoy it. But boy was I wrong. I watched this film in 2 parts because I was too tired to finish it, but it was the only thing on my mind until I started it again the next morning. That's how you know you're enjoying it.

The first thing to be noticed is the costuming. Wow. Jacqueline Durann is known for her ability to create period piece costumes, and she was the perfect choice for Little Women. The costumes are seriously gorgeous. Alongside costuming, the set design is beautiful. Greta Gerwig did a great job on picking what this film would look like visually, as every room and landscape is gorgeous and seems to actually be in the right time period.

The acting in this is phenomenal. Every single character is acted to perfection. The chemistry between each and every actor/actress adds so much to the film and makes it seem so real. And a lot of these are A-list actors and that's very evident because across the board the line delivery and choreography is astounding. Kudos to this entire cast!

The style of filming is stunning, with scene transitions and offset cameras and long exposure, it's a marvel. With a cinematographer who has not done many big films, he showed off his style in this. I really love how light the scenery and honestly everything is in this entire film, it brings joy and makes for a really fun watch. The camerawork is great too and reminds me of a Wes Anderson movie, very symmetrical and very careful camera movements. 

The last twenty minutes of this film have to be the most magical moments in any film I've seen recently. It's so joyful and so heartfelt and it's hard not to feel so emotional while watching. I could rewatch the ending over and over and over again and never get bored of it. The score and the acting work so perfectly that it's impossible to not want to cry. I'm a sucker for endings that make me cry so here we are. 

There's not much more to be said about Little Women aside from how good this story is and how well it was produced, you just need to see it for yourself. I thoroughly enjoyed watching this and I plan on rewatching it soon!

I'm so in love with this movie. All the character does make me feel like they are human to me. We can understand Laurie's why he is so devasted and falls so hard for Jo. The relationship between Jo, Amy, and Laurie is so touching my heart that I want to feel that again and make me order the little women's book. Emma as meg and Eliza as beth is also a fantastic performance for them. It was a really weird experience for me because all the way watching this movie. I can't tell what is the main conflict of this story. It is just about a family with 4 sisters trying to pursue their dream. But what makes this movie so beautiful for me is the journey and how the movie takes us there to the conclusion of each character. It is charming, funny, happy, angry, and sad. Amy is the character that can become annoying in the movie, but her annoyance is just pure childish and heartfelt. It doesn't make me mad but instead smiles as another sister also smiles because of the stupid and funny thing she did and said. Any other bad decision that Amy makes and causes pain to another character also becomes something that we can understand why she did it. All I can say is that this movie makes me smile the whole damn movie. And the casting for me in this version is better than the old one with Kristen Dunst as Amy. (maybe it is because I watch the 2019 version first too) Anyway, this movie makes me smile the whole damn movie. So yes it become one of the top 10 films that I love personally.

You burn the only copy of my manuscript, you're going in the ground — I don't care if we're family. Josephine "Jo" March (Saoirse Ronan) showed immense restraint throughout the film, not only by refraining from murdering her younger sister, Amy (Florence Pugh) after she commits the cardinal sin mentioned above, but also by pursuing her dream of becoming a self-sufficient writer during a time when she was expected to marry young (and hopefully rich) and have children. Little Women has been remade six(!) times now. Had it not been for the stellar cast and excellent director (Greta Gerwig), I likely would've never thrown it on. The setting doesn't hurt the film at all. In fact, I enjoyed the outfits, whether they were for fancy balls or something to throw on to go ice-skating, and it made me want to get into vests… I also found the dialogue to be enjoyable and shots of rural Massachusetts, New York City, and Paris appealing. I like Chalamet in everything, even if the film itself isn't great. I found Pugh to have the most noteworthy performance, however, as the petulant Amy. In a smaller, but not insignificant role, I really enjoyed Tracey Letts as Mr. Dashwood, the publisher. I'd actually like to take the time to give a shout-out to Letts: the guy always delivers and he doesn't seem to get enough recognition. Watching how Jo's book was made is craft porn. I empathized with her when she held it in her hands for the first time — number one will always have a special place in a writer's heart. My biggest gripe with the film is the timeline, which seems to be a common complaint. It's disjointed and sometimes disorienting, but not even coming close to approaching Tenet levels. Took me a while to get to it, but I highly recommend Little Women whether you think this is your cup o' tea or not.
This movie was a bit slow paced and long, but the story was well told and ultimately inspiring. I saw this with a couple friends in the theater, and it was a fun Ladies' Night movie.
Wholesome, elegant, cozy, free-spirited, empowering. Truly a masterpiece.
Well done, well acted, on the long side, but nice story telling

Such a beautiful and guilty pleasure movie! The dialogues, the performances....everything here is so refreshing! 
Greta is really an amazing director!

Hats off to Greta Gerwig for her rendition of Alcott's classic story of the daughters in Civil War New Hampshire.  Cooper as a character actor shines as usual.  I caught Watson in a Brit accent a few times, I have Brit family and I have the ear for it.

Greta Gerwig directs this version of the Louisa May Alcott classic about the sisters March and their relationships with each other growing up and with others.  Florence Pugh, Saoirse Ronan, Emma Watson, Eliza Scanlon, Laura Dern and Timothee Chalamet make up the main cast. With Meryl Streep and Bob Odenkirk supporting.   Excellent cast and great chemistry between them all make this a pretty delightful viewing experience.

Great on every level—the writing, the directing, the acting; it all comes together to turn a book I would've found boring in high school into one of the finest films of the year, of the decade, of all time.

I was bored by the movie version of this story that came out about 20 years ago and I was even more bored by this one. I also found the soundtrack totally annoying along with some of the acting, which was stilted and unnatural. These characters are just not interesting to me and the story is too bland to be cinematic. Chalamet is creepy in this and his acting is never very good in anything and was no better here. Most of the actor's looked "acty", especially Meryl Streep who was standout terrible. I agree with what others have said about the editing. It was unbelievably botched! I didn't make it through to the end of this one. I highly doubt anything remarkable could happen at the end since nothing the least bit interesting was set up in the first half.

Absolutely fantastic! It is very inspiring and the characters are all intriguing. It is hard not to fall in love with the cast as they portray these old fashioned souls. The pace is slow but certainly not in a dull way, you get so enthralled by the beauty of it that it doesn't need to be full of action and events. A movie about the simpler days depicting: romance, grief, identity and much more. 
I even surprised myself by loving this movie as much as I do - for I am not the biggest fan of romantic films such as this. 
I recommend you give it a watch. 
- Miss M
Normally I am not a fan of fictional historical films, but Little Women completely changed my view of them. The characters were portrayed very well.

This movie is one of many adaptations of the fictional book little women by  Louisa May Alcott. We get to see great performances by the whole cast, but the acting of the main cast, Saoirse Ronan, Emma Watson, Florence Pugh, Eliza Scanlen and Timothée Chalamet elevates this even further. The story feels vibrant, engaging and colourful.  The Set-Desing, the costumes, the Lighting and the soundtrack are so well done they make this story feel truly alive. The story makes use of it's setting in it's entirety. The struggle with ones aspirations and dreams, with societies  expectations and constrictions, familial and romantic relationships interfering  with friendship makes this story into the work of art it is. 
I recomment this story if you like romance or drama movies in general, stories about emancipation or just the setting during the 19. century.

It's a little long and there are a few scenes where the feminism seemed unnecessarily in your face, but for the most part, ‘Little Women' is a triumph and delivers a fantastic, slightly more modern re-telling/re-jigging of a classic story that's still ends up being engaging and moving. That is mostly Greta Gerwig's doing, she is superb behind the camera and makes some fantastic directing and editing decisions that greatly improve on previous efforts. It also has to be said that great performances from the entire cast are a big part of why it works so well -- Timothée Chalamet is particularly memorable -- but it's undoubtedly Saoirse Ronan and Florence Pugh that are the hearts and souls of this adaptation, their very different characters each bursting off the screen in their own, unique ways.
Brilliant film, really loved the last 20 minutes or so which really made the film worth watching for me.

Little Women is cinematic splendor masterfully brought to life by the brilliant Greta Gerwig. If Hayao Miyazaki made a live action film, it would be a similar rainbow of colors and emotions... like watching a living painting. If such a thing exists, it's a perfect film.

Watched on Christmas day in what we thought would be a treat for my mum (she wasn't fussed in the end either), though I found it both dull and confusing timelinewise in some places, and some of the characters/actors irritating, I thought it improved towards the end.

This classic film is just charming enough to get away with the out-of-order scenes. By the end, you get the whole story but it's very confusing at first. The actresses are so enduring and effortlessly brilliant that you get emersed into the 1860s with them. Following their lives feels like a long emotional journey with a satisfying ending. It's worth the two our watch.

I did not read the novel or watched the original movie but I enjoyed it. The chemistry between the girls is so genuine. Saoirse Ronan performance is as good as always. But i’m sorry but I truly HATE the ending. It dosen’t feel right. My least favorite character getting everything. I would give it a 4 start but the ending makes me so mad so a 3 stars is the best I can do.

Incredibly well-planned--well-directed and well-written. Sometimes the scene orchestration is too on-the-nose. It is the most uniquely structured adaptation yet, with the implementation of scenes of the true story that inspired the fictional story, which interestingly makes it less appealing (though more intelligent) than previous adaptations.
1994 movie is better in every way.

Although Little Women's cast is formidable it is not overly boastful about itself. Gerwig is able to maintain a light, childish air and yet stress upon the importance of each of the character's lives. One of the greatest movies of 2019.

Undoubtedly, this is my favorite movie. It has a perfect balance of realism and fiction that there is absolutely nothing to critique. If possible I would give it a 6 out of 5 stars. There are so many themes, which could seem messy, but they are so perfectly pieced together you don't even notice them e.g., Romance, Christmas, Feminism, Family, and Patriarchal Society. When asked to recommend a movie, this will always be the first one I recommend.

بدرستی‌که او جای پای هنرمندانی همچون اینگرید برگمان، لیو اولمان، مریل استریپ و کیت بلانشت خواهد گذاشت.
#سرشه_رونان همین چیزی که هست، بهترین نسخه اوست.
 
وقتی در سال 2007 برای فیلم تاوان Atonement  نامزد بفتا، گلدن گلوب و اسکار شد کمتر می‌شد تصور کرد اینچنین پیشرفت متفاوتی نسبت به دیگر هم‌دوره‌ای‌های خود کند. 
درخشش او فقط با ۱۴ سال سن در استخوان‌های دوست داشتنی The Lovely Bones پیتر جکسون در سال 2009 نوید یک هنرمند زبردست را داد، در سال 2011 در فیلم هانا Hana در کنار کیت بلانشت نقشی مشکل را هنرمندانه اجرا کرد و همچنین سال 2014 در هتل بزرگ بوداپست گرچه در سکانس‎های کمی حضور داشت، در سال 2016 بازی قدرتمند، بی نقص، قابل لمس و فراموش نشدنی او در فیلم #بروکلین Brooklyn که برای بار دوم نامزد اسکار شد، در سال 2017 بازی بی نظیر او با #لیدی_برد Lady Bird‎ گرتا گرویگ برای بار سوم و در سال 2019 برای #زنان_کوچک Little Women گرتا گرویگ که گویا سرشه را به عنوان یک درام باز ناب یافته تا در کنار مریل استریپ بدرخشد و نامزد جایزه اسکار شود.

#گرتا_گرویگ در عصر پر زرق و برق سینمای هالیوود بسیار سخاوتمندانه دو فیلم لیدی برد و زنان کوچک را بسیار عمیق با سکانس‎‌هایی بهم ریخته اما قابل فهم و با هنرنمایی سرشه رونان پیشکش کرده است.

THE FATE OF THE MARCH SISTERS



Over the last century, the novel 'Little Women', written by Alcott, received the attention of a lot of filmmakers. Various films have been made, based on the same storyline of that novel. Sadly, not all films were as successful as the recent film Little women, released in 2019 which was directed by Greta Gerwig. The lead actors delivered an astonishing performance, and the acting skills were incredible. Honestly, I've never been interested in films that are based on novels, because they're usually focusing on the main storyline, instead of bringing the novel into reality. They're almost never as good as the novel itself, which is why this film has been one of the best films I've ever watched. Another reason why I love it is because it's much different from the films of the last decade that mostly involve teenage problems, such as new technology, social media, school, teen romance... On the other side we also have films like 'Little Women' that show us the real side of the old world, mostly about their struggles and economic differences between people. We can see how different poor people and rich people live. That is the main reason why I love this film. 

 

The film is based on an amazing but also surprising life of four young sisters, named the March sisters, who are neither rich nor poor. They lived in a happy household with their mother and their maid. Their dad was traveling a lot because of military purposes, and they repeatedly got letters about his well-being, which made them stay connected to him. These young girls had different ways of looking at the world, and they all had dreams that they wanted to pursue. A few involved marriages, love … but the second oldest sister, Josephine March (also called Jo), had a much different purpose in her life. She wanted to see the world, be adventurous but mostly enjoy life at its fullest without having to give up her freedom. The sisters also wanted to show their artistic talents to the world, such as writing, playing instruments, acting and painting. Once Jo met the young charming boy (named Mr. Laurence), that lived across their house, things began to change and their life got more complicated and mostly exciting. The story of these young girls is an interesting and incredibly beautiful story and is definitely one of the best old like movies ever made. 


My first reaction to the film was that I was genuinely surprised about the acting, mainly because of how they managed to fit their roles perfectly. Another reason why I was amazed is that unlike other stories that are made about the 19th century is that this story shows how differently women are treated in the modern days. The story is mostly based on the girls, they're the main characters of the film, which makes them more powerful. In this film the men are more on the sidelines of the story, but they're also there for love interest and role as spectators. Even though the girls still had to deal with sexism in their path, they were strongly enough to break the stereotype that was involved with women at the time. That is something I really liked about the story. Something that made me very happy but also emotional, is how good you could see that the sisters were so close with each other, they lived like best friends. However, the youngest sister Amy and the second oldest sister Jo, had a rivalry or some sort of competition about who would be better because they were very equal, which made the relationships very interesting. Lastly, the thing that made me love the movie even more is how well the March family treated each other and mostly how they were so welcoming to other people around them. They made every single person feel a kind of warmth because of the love they gave, and that brought me a good perspective of how kindness can change the world. 


During the film, I had a lot of questions that made me think about how the story would end. I thought to myself, ‘What will Jo actually do with her life?', ‘Will Jo sacrifice her dream and marry a rich man to support her family?', ‘Will she pursue her dream and actually be an author, or will she give up her dream very easily?', ‘Who will Laurie get married to?', ‘How will the girls' life's eventually end and what will their future hold?... Luckily all my questions had been answered at the end of the film, and I was left speechless because of how great the film is. Although there were a few sad scenes, which I personally couldn't accept and that got me very emotional. Lastly, another reason why I loved it, is because every actor was so good at showing the characters' emotions and focus on the fact that this isn't a modern film. They were all dressed heavenly and delivered a lovable performance that made everyone fall in love with them. Therefore, I can say that the film is absolutely stunning. 

 


To conclude, I can say that the film is much more different than other films. The story revolves around the four girls and has a very interesting storyline. The actors gave us an impression as if it was their live, and they looked breathtakingly gorgeous. We can also say that the big star involved here, is Greta Gerwig. She directed the most entertaining and unique film, alongside the amazing costumes and feminism involved in the story. What I find really disturbing and sad is that she has not been nominated yet for these great performances and works, because I can honestly say that this is one of the best films ever made. This film is a film that I would highly recommend to anyone who likes equality and lovely stories. If you want to feel a lot of emotions at once, this is the perfect film for you. Ultimately, I can truly say this is a cinematic masterpiece.

Can't speak for it as an adaptation of source material, but as a standalone work the performances are good and the story remains compelling enough. There has been some noise made about how undeserving the film's costume design was of an Oscar considering the many oversights (not limited to one of them actually wearing Uggs at one point).

Greta Gerwig's version of Alcott's classic novel breathes life into an old tale for a new generation. Little Women faithfully explores the lives of the March sisters and their beloved stories but it adds a modern edge that gives them more depth. Saoirse Ronan and Florence Pugh were the brightest stars among a cast of notable talents. Their performances made the most difficult relationship in the film, in my opinion, the most interesting.

The mutilple awards winner Little women, was directed by Greta Gerwing and is a revisited version of the book Little Women, by Louisa May Alcott (1868). There are multiple versions of this film, but by far this is the most exciting and enjoyable one. 

Meg March (Emma Watson), Jo March (Saoirse Ronan), Beth March (Eliza Scanlen) and Amy March (Florence Pugh) are four sisters that live with their mom (Laura Dern) while their dad (Bob Odenkirk) is away for war. The girls and their neighbour Laurie (Timothée Chalamet) are inseparable and they have fun together everyday. Eventually, time passes by, and by the time they're grownups, almost all of them leave the city to see the world. Meg has now a family, Jo is a teacher, Beth is really sick and Amy is a painter, and her and Laurie have now a relationship. Jo even meets her future husband Friedrich (Louis Garrel). Beth passes away, making the sisters see each other after years apart. 

During their lives, they learn to love, to be independent and to manage the struggles of life. Jo publishes her book and while founding her own school. 

The film was really good, and the cast was on point, and the events that were shown were very similar as the ones written in the book.

I recommend this movie for the people that like love, sadness and adventure all at the same time.

A review here has several issues:
- The photography was very well done, the color and feeling of atmosphere was excellent.
- The Period costumes was well planned and excellent
- The acting was superb 
However:
- As a movie the story did not hold together. The editing was faulty, as scenes jumped from one period to another without any warning. The entire flow of the storyline appeared faulty. In Truth, I could not wait for this beautifully photographed movie to finally end. I cannot rate it very high, since the story flow was faulty with what I consider poor editing.

Watching this version of little women was almost painful for me. 
The authenticity of the characters just didn't ring true. We've got Emma Watson as Meg, and Laura Dern as the mom: Wild at heart and Blue Velvet spring to mind.
I can't stop seeing Hermione when I look at Emma Watson..or simply as Emma Watson, but she warmed to the role.  Laura Dern as "Marmy" is trite.
Jo's character was anemic. Amy's shrieking had me wish she wouldn't surface. 
Aunt March wasn't nearly the cantankerous, familiar old~Pill we all came to love or at least understand. Beth seems like a cardboard cut-out, pale in personality as well as countenance. Would anyone miss her, really?  Though I must admit when she got smallpox she seemed to come to life at last.   Timothée Chalamet was an adequate Laurie, as much as he was allowed to be. Mr. Lawrence was reduced to a distant presence as well. 
Everything moves at a frenetic speed in this latest rehashing of Little Women; including the actor's speech:  Even when Their father returns from the war, he and Laurie enter the room at a breakneck clip before the family descends on them replete with the requisite shrieking that seems to erupt every time any issue arises in this film.
There seems to be an awful lot of emoting going on in this film but not much of it felt authentic.
I feel this version of Little Women glosses over many important moments in the book;
All is blatant, with little nuance, while the sound appears to be voiced-over or dubbed in. 
I'll admit, there are poignant moments in this version. Mr. Lawrence with Beth when she plays the piano and the beach scenes between Jo and Beth were quite touching.
For a moment or two, I found myself captivated. 
I must admit; I did love the ending.  Jo got her man, [what a cutie Mr. Bhaer is.]
The ending was a joyous celebration of the family, with nice upbeat classical music and zero histrionics! Yea!
P.S.
For my money; the 1994 version of Little Women with Susan Sarandon and Winona Ryder will always be the stand-out version, It's heartwarming and truest to the storyline., Don't miss it!

Beautiful film but at first near-impossible to follow. When it finally settles down a quarter of the way in, it actually manages to get absorbing, and director Greta Gerwig even caps the whole thing off with a tearful and satisfying romantic finish.

I thought Florence Pugh was quite excellent in the film, as well as Saoirse Ronan. I'm sure enough has been said about Emma Watson's take on an American accent, so I won't go there. The only bit that bugged me was the time jumps between past and present that Greta Gerwig decided to do. There wasn't enough difference in the appearance of the characters to signal to the audience that we're not in the past or present day. The passage of time was difficult to follow - maybe some text on screen would have helped, or other indication on screen. I didn't think it was necessary to take the story out of chronological order. I'm not sure the time jumps added something new to the story, but overall I enjoyed Gerwig's take on the tale.

In my opinion, this film stands as the best remake of Louisa May Alcott's 1868 novel. Being only Gerwig's second film, she is able to bring a sweet, mature, and lively story back to life from its original creation. This film achieves a lot, but one of the most notable things to me personally are the characters. The four sisters- Meg, Amy, Jo, and Beth -all are unique and stand out from one another. This is, of course, due to the original novel, but it is enhanced by the performances of all four actresses. I believe, of the four female leads, Florence Pugh (portraying Amy) brought forth the strongest performance. Though she is in her mid-twenties portraying an often pre-teen character, her acting was believable, charming, and relatable. In fact, I think what makes the characterization so strong is the ability to relate to them. As a teenage girl myself, I found myself comparing my identity to that of the March sisters, which made me feel closer to the story as it progressed.
Another strong aspect of this film was the lighting. I really liked the change in lighting that occured in between the flashbacks and the real scenes. As a viewer, it made it easier to distinguish between the settings and also helped paint the past as good, or at least as a time of nostalgia. This allowed me to further resonate with Jo as she reflected on an earlier time in her life, and helped me put myself into the perspective of the characters.
Overall, I thought Gerwig was able to create a touching tribute to the original works of the author. This movie, which I have now seen three times, remains one of my favorite for these aspects and more.

Greta Gerwig's Little Women is a very entertaining, funny, dramatic, romantic and all around enjoyable film about women trying to take charge in the 1800s. Despite it looking like a standard modern day movie trying to be feminist, it does so not by having its main characters do stuff that men also do, but rather having them pursue their passions and interests by any means necessary.

(Español /English) 

 In this version of the novel Little Women, the director Greta Gerwig makes two interventions: a permanent alternation between the two times in which it passes (which first disconcerts) and the inclusion of metafictional elements; but at the same time she respects the conventions of romantic melodrama and that combination of innovation and classicism ends up working.

 Mujercitas aborda ciertos avatares en la vida de las cuatro hermanas March, sus padres, amigos y pretendientes a partir de la Guerra de Secesión. Una de ellas, Jo,  escribe y se propone ser una escritora independiente (Saoirse Ronan); Amy pinta (Florence Pugh); Meg actúa (Emma Watson) y Beth toca el piano (Eliza Scanlen). Por el momento su madre, Margaret (Laura Dern) se las arregla sola ya que el padre (Bob Odenkirk) se encuentra en el frente, lo que no le impide permanentes tareas solidarias. Hay una tía acomodada por parte de padre (Meryl Streep) y unos vecinos ricos: un abuelo y su nieto Laurie (Timothée Chalamet) que siempre anda orbitando a las hermanas.

Tanto en la novela original de Louisa May Alcott como en la película planea el tema de qué grado de independencia económica podía lograr una mujer en esa época y qué oportunidades tenían de canalizar sus vocaciones, siendo el matrimonio aparentemente el único destino posible (y no necesariamente salvador). Algo así como el universo de Jane Austin pero en EE.UU. y con las nuevas inquietudes de la época.

Con por lo menos dos versiones cinematográficas anteriores, en ésta, la directora Greta Gerwig realiza dos intervenciones fundamentales: una, en la manera de narrar, ya que alterna permanentemente la época de adolescencia de las hermanas con otra posterior a la Guerra, con las chicas más adultas. Este ir y venir crea en principio confusión, ya que toma al espectador por sorpresa. Por otro lado, en la primera parte de la película, las escenas son más bien corales, lo que sumado al permanente quiebre temporal atenta contra el crecimiento de los personajes y la empatía por ellos. En la segunda parte, en cambio, y ya costumbrados al mecanismo y con abordajes más focalizados, esta forma de relatar crea paralelismos interesantes y el relato se afianza. (Con una historia muy diferente, un planteo temporal similar funciona desde el comienzo en El jilguero, por ejemplo)

La otra intervención, enfatiza el carácter autobiográfico de la novela en la figura de la escritora Jo creando interesantes instancias metaficcionales.

Más allá de esas intervenciones, la realizadora respeta las convenciones del melodrama romántico, que es el que termina cobrando fuerza con sus desencuentros amorosos y rivalidades. De este modo este relato clásico pero intervenido termina funcionando.

Las actrices jóvenes se lucen en sus interpretaciones, Laura Dern luce expresiva y contenida, la tía de la infalible Meryl Streep es la voz del establishment y Chalamet aporta un encanto romántico esencial para su personaje.

La construcción de época es primorosa mientras que la música de Alexander Desplat es innecesariamente enfática.

Es interesante comparar esta película con El seductor (The Beguiled), de Sofia Coppola, donde un internado de señoritas dirigido por Nicole Kidman acoge a un soldado durante la misma Guerra de Secesión.

..........................................................................................................................................

Little Women addresses certain vicissitudes in the lives of the four March sisters, their parents, friends and suitors from the Civil War. One of them, Jo, writes and sets out to be a freelance writer (Saoirse Ronan); Amy pint (Florence Pugh); Meg plays (Emma Watson) and Beth plays the piano (Eliza Scanlen). At the moment her mother, Margaret (Laura Dern) manages on her own since her father (Bob Odenkirk) is in front of her, which does not prevent her from permanent solidarity tasks. There is a father's wealthy aunt (Meryl Streep) and wealthy neighbors: a grandfather and his grandson Laurie (Timothée Chalamet) who is always orbiting the sisters.


In both the original novel by Louisa May Alcott and in the film, she plans the issue of what degree of economic independence a woman could achieve at that time and what opportunities they had to channel their vocations, marriage being apparently the only possible destination (and not necessarily savior). Something like the universe of Jane Austin but in the US and with the new concerns of the time.


With at least two previous film versions, in this one, the director Greta Gerwig makes two fundamental interventions: one, in the way of narrating, since it permanently alternates the time of adolescence of the sisters with another after the War, with the girls more adult. This coming and going creates confusion at first, as it takes the viewer by surprise. On the other hand, in the first part of the film, the scenes are rather choral, which, added to the permanent temporary break, threatens the growth of the characters and empathy for them. In the second part, on the other hand, and already accustomed to the mechanism and with more focused approaches, this way of telling creates interesting parallels and the story takes hold. (With a very different story, a similar temporal approach works from the beginning in El jilguero, for example)


The other intervention emphasizes the autobiographical character of the novel in the figure of the writer Jo, creating interesting metafictional instances.


Beyond these interventions, the director respects the conventions of romantic melodrama, which is the one that ends up gaining strength with her love affairs and rivalries. In this way this classic but intervened story ends up working.


Young actresses shine in their performances, Laura Dern looks expressive and restrained, the infallible Meryl Streep's aunt is the voice of the establishment, and Chalamet brings an essential romantic charm to her character.


The period construction is exquisite while Alexander Desplat's music is unnecessarily emphatic.


It is interesting to compare this film with Sofia Coppola's The Beguiled, where a boarding school for young ladies run by Nicole Kidman welcomes a soldier during the Civil War itself.
A beautiful adaptation of the book by Greta Gerwig, who also directed. Great performances by the entire cast and gorgeous to watch.
Very well written film about the cycle of life paired with the phenomenal performances makes for a very entertaining movie. At times can be confusing but not enough to hurt the movie a ton

Let's get the positives out of the way. The acting, costumes, and shots of the scenes are amazing and bring the time period Little Women is set in to life. But that's all I enjoyed.

The time jumps are infuriating and a poor choice by the director. You have to pay attention as the characters look exactly the same 7 years ago vs the present time, so if you doze off for a second you may not realize you're in the past. They should have just kept the story linear to not confuse viewers.

My other issue is that they somehow made all the sisters the most annoying people of all time. In the book, you love each of them and how they make up the family unit even if the characters are not loveable. In this film, I can't feel that they are sisters nor do I feel they love each other. Jo for example does not feel like a tomboy and comes across as a very rude to everyone. Instead of feeling like an older sister, Meg comes off as very fixated on money.  Beth isn't the shy angel as she is in the book, and some of her lines come off as whiny. If they wanted me to hate Amy, well they did a wonderful job because the tone of voice they had the actress use makes me want to plug my ears up. She sounds incredibly rude in every scene. 

I love Little Women, but this film's characterization is an insult to the book and the actors.

My first Little Women film, this movie shows that the title might be sarcastic or ironic, utilizing insanely good actresses to show that its characters are perhaps not little at all, but some of the most mature and compelling female role models ever written.
THIS MOVIE IS AMAZING!!! I did not think that I would like it as it was the sequel, however all of the characters were loveable and i would die for them.

This film is one that I highly recommend. It is an immediate classic that evokes thought as well as feeling. Though this tale has been remade many times over the years, this is a fresh take on a timeless piece. I do advise that one be familiar with the source material, because of its non chronological plotline. Gerwig's use of screenplay format causes there to be a direct focus on time, from past to present. Each scene has its own feel and sense of direction, apart from the others, yet are gracefully intertwined. This is a tale of many narratives, all interlaced at once. While focusing on the aspirations of women and their places in society, it paints a beautiful picture of hope, family, and love.

Ugh, didn't get it. I think Great is a greta director though ... ohh.

I thought I'd give this one a go, having heard the buzz when it came out, but also having noted the collateral buzz that "men aren't watching this excellent movie" (I wonder how many women seek out Saving Private Ryan, on the other hand.  This isn't cultural, folks, it's brain wiring.  If you don't believe me read The Female Brain, or The Male Brain, by Dr. Louann Brizendine. 
We got about 35% through it when my wife decided enough was enough.  Wooden acting, stilted dialogue, generally poor directing (how else to explain the painfully surficial turns of excellent actors like Chalament, Streep, and Dern?
Alan Alda said "you can see how good your acting is in the eyes of the other actors".  I don't think any of these actors bothered to look.
We were confused at first by the time shifts but got used to that (could have perhaps been improved by better editing) but never developed any empathy or sympathy for the characters.  
So, no, I guess we just didn't drink the Gerwig koolaid.
Proof that Ronan and Gerwig are an unstoppable, magical duo. Amazing that the same source material can keep being retold over and over while still being relevant to modern audiences.

This film manages to showcase superb artistic expression in both filmmaking and acting, convey and explore almost every possible human emotion, advertise feminism in an incredibly honest and humble way, teach and illustrate the value of love and friendship, all while telling the rather simple story of the March sisters.

The 2019 Greta Gerwig film Little Women takes the story of the beloved March sisters and twists it into a barely recognizable film that attempts to please fans of Gerwig's other films. 
Despite being set during the Civil War, there are simply a multitude of mistakes in regards to hair and costuming. For one, anyone with basic knowledge of fashion during this era knows that around the age of thirteen, girls start to wear their hair up. At the beginning of the film, Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy are 16, 15, 13, and 12 respectively. Meg, the eldest, is supposedly the "perfect" sister and follows societal rules but has her hair down for multiple scenes throughout the film. This created an inaccurate portrayal of the eldest March sister which causes confusion as moments later, we see her lecturing Jo about the societal do's and don'ts at the party the sisters go to. Does she care about how she is viewed by society or not? The mistakes made by the costuming department again reflect the lack of accuracy to the time period. In the scene where they deliver food to the Hummels, they brave the cold Massachusetts weather without accurate winterwear. They're poor but how are they to be warm?
Although there is a stark contrast in lighting between the flashbacks and present times, many audience members can easily become confused if they are not familiar with the story or do not pick up on this element. If you are not paying attention, it is not particularly noticeable until halfway through the film and by that point, you are most likely confused about what is happening. The stylistic choice is a good attempt at warm versus cool lighting but could have been introduced after the main characters were established, not used as a form of introducing the March sisters. It yet again creates confusion for the audience.
This switching between the past and present is not the only problem with the construction of the film. The timeline of events is inaccurate to the books and makes major disputes between the sisters seem like small childish quarrels. When Amy destroys Jo's novel, the two make up in the next scene as if no time has gone by since the incident. Generally speaking, characters are simply written inaccurately to the original character in the novel. The original message of family and the bond between sisters turns into a modern and inaccurate adaptation. This is perfectly exemplified with Marmee's line "girls have to go into the world and make their own minds about things." This is the Civil War, not modern 2019. 
In sum, Gerwig tries to make a beloved classic into a modern crowd-pleasing film while giving up the integrity of the characters and the original work. The message of family and its importance is lost upon the audience. Instead, the audience roots for the sisters as individuals instead of as a family. Overall, it is a poor attempt at a beloved classic.
Impeccably crafted together, Greta Gerwig's Little Women is not only a beautiful adaptation but one that serves justice to the amazing Louisa May Alcott.
A little hard to follow at times, but full of some great scenes and an interesting commentary on the institution of marriage, though I can't say I loved the ending. Also, Timothee Chalamet 👏

This newest version of Little women wasn't horrible, but it was way too different, in my opinion, than the great versions of this movie that I love so much. The 1994 and 1949 versions are much better movies! One thing that I very much did not care for is that the role of Marmy was not as prominent in this newest version and the actress playing Marmy doesn't hold a candle to Mary Astor and Susan Sarandon. I actually thought that the entire character fell flat this time around. Also, Amy was much too old. The flashback scenes of the girls younger days made the movie seem rushed and it took away from all of the great character development we get to see in the other versions, when it starts out at the beginning instead of flashing back and forth. It may be a trend to remake old classics with their own spin on the story, but this was a classic that didn't need to be spun, at all. Honestly, it didn't need to be remade to begin with, but if you insist on taking on something like this at least find actors and actresses who can do it justice. The actress who played Jo was tolerable and Emma Watson was lovely, but that's it. I would tell anyone to skip this newest version and instead watch the 1994 and/or the 1949 versions. This 2019 version feels like you are reading the Cliff notes of a really great book, you may get the gist of what the story is about, but you're missing out on a lot of wonderful details.

From Greta Gerwig comes a new interpretation of L.M. Alcott's classic novel Little Women for a new generation.  The story follows four sisters as they grow up in the backdrop of the American Civil War as they deal with issues of love and loss, and finding their own way in the world.  Starring Saoirse Ronan, Emma Watson, Laura Dern, and Chris Cooper, the film has an impressive cast that gives good performances.  And Gerwig too does a great job at capturing the romantic tone of the novel and the ambiance of the period.  However, it tries to get a little meta in its shifting time frames and parallel storytelling; which can get kind of confusing.  And Gerwig tries to slip in some liberal messaging that takes one out of the film; which is really kind of a shame given how powerful the original material is on its own.  Still, the authenticity of the costumes and sets is remarkable, and the score is beautifully done.  The ‘94 version is probably a little better, but Gerwig's Little Woman is a compelling coming-of-age drama with its own unique character and charm.

Greta Gerwig's chronology juggling story telling adds an interesting layer to the often adapted story of Little Women.  I appreciated the increased development of Amy in this version as well as the clever ending.  A few plot lines' impacts are lessened by the rearranged order, but ultimately it adds more than it detracts.  Despite his overall strength as an actor, Timothy Chamlet's Laurie doesn't have the charisma as in other adaptations and his chemistry with Jo is luke warm.  Still, as an avid fan of the 90's version, I felt this interpretation brought a fresh perspective and was a satisfying watch.

The story is so chopped up in this film adaptation that anyone who isn't extremely familiar with the book will have a difficult time following the story line. My other gripes are superficial and most people will probably disagree with me.  First, I feel like the girls were made deliberately unattractive for some reason, especially Amy who is supposed to be a great beauty.  Secondly, and I know this scene is in the book, but the scene where Meg is slut shamed by Laurie for wanting to wear lipstick and a low-cut dress feels wildly out of place in an in-your-face feminist production. Lastly, I found it odd that Laurie was portrayed with the appearance of a 13 year old boy. He has zero chemistry with Jo or Amy because he is just a gangly little kid. Why?  Overall, the film was a great disappointment and fell flat in so many ways, which is a shame because I'm a big fan of the book and the 1994 film.

We shouldn't have needed a fresh adaptation of this, one of the most loved and repeatedly adapted books in American culture - it's so embedded in the international psyche that there's even a joke about in an episode of Friends. But we reckoned without the consummate skill of writer-director Greta Gerwig, who finds an unexpected approach to the story that would sound oddly meta in the description but that works superbly in execution. It helps, of course, to have such a stellar cast - one which proves the need for 'Best Ensemble' awards; it's redundant and unfair to pick one performer from the almost universally excellent line-up. Throw in some beautiful cinematography, and this is a beautiful, warm embrace of a film that still emotionally satisfies. There are occasional misfires: the cursory nod to slavery and racism seemed tokenistic to me, but I may have misread that. And Meryl's Streep character and performance seem to me to lapse too much into genre trope territory in an otherwise nimble film. But ultimately this is a film that leaves you smiling, the sort of thing you'll want to watch and rewatch over Christmas holidays, seeing something fresh each time and enjoying everything that feels familiar in all the right ways.

Having never read the book, I only found out afterwards that the girls were supposed to be in their early teens at the start of this movie. How it got the praise it did I will never understand, sloppy and incoherent as it is.

I really enjoyed this movie! I did not know the story as I had not read the book nor watched previous versions so to me it was all knew and it got to me. The story is a little confusing at first with its many characters and some jumping through different time periods but after some time introducing the main characters, the film finds its pace and becomes lovely. The center of it is a young woman, Jo, who has three sisters and the dream of becoming a writer. Her family is poor but seems to be one with large amounts of love, freedom and creativity that makes these girls so different from the apparent average of the 19th century. Jo is a writer, Amy is a painter, Meg is an actress and Hannah plays the piano, talents that not all of them treat as their future, maybe because being a wife seems to be their only possible vocation. These characters are so naturally powerful that you don't really question how rare it must have been to find this level of freedom in women in an age in which dreaming of anything other than marrying a rich man sounded outrageous or nonsense. People did not expect women to succed and it is clear right in the first scene, when Jo tries to sell a novel to a publishing company and the editor likes it but believes no one will want to read about a woman that does not get married or dies in the end (any other option simply does not make sense in his mind). Jo's best friend is a rich a young boy who is a neighbor and shares some of its wealth with her family. The couple has a connection that feels true and natural but she seems so focused on finding her independency that love takes the second plan in her mind. In a way this to me is the main theme of the movie: how the idea that marriage was a financial decision for women had large impacts on their lives and dreams. Some of them might understand that marriage should be lead by love and not wealth, others might fight so hard against it that love becomes an almost neglected feeling, many might succumb to the pressure. However, any path that is taken has a strong presence of this overwhelming feeling that women just won't get there alone. The movie flows very well after a slightly slow start when its base is being built, then it is wonderful. The photography is amazing and at several moments it just seems like you are watching a paiting or even reading poetry, the acting is fantastic with an incredible cast, the dialogues are powerful and beautifully written even when it seems that too much is being said to us. I loved Lady Bird as well and I cannot wait to see what Greta Gerwig will do next.
4.5/5.  An interesting and emotional tale with an excellent cast.

I have to give it 5 stars. Why? I do have some slight criticisms but enjoyed watching the film so much anyway that I cannot justify taking any points away. The pace of the movie is wonderful. The script wraps scenes together with past and present intermingling  in a way that is both artistic and productive. This style brings a rich meaning to aspects of all of the characters and their relationships. I love the way this was done. Of course this period piece is full of beautifully videographed scenery and it is obvious that a lot of attention was given to detail. Delicious. 
What I thought I might find here in the way of complaint was that in order to follow the events and the flip flopping between past and present, it seems necessary to have read the book and if you have read the book, You may have already formulated an image of Amy. And Amy might not seem like you imagined her - or at least she wasn't as I imagined. This version of her was a much stronger character with sharper edges. I personally didn't fall in love with her  or sense the passion between her and Lori but was amazed at the believability of the youthful as well as the grown up Amy. The acting in this film was real talent. Often, I am annoyed by the casting of recognizable actors and actresses in films like this but Meryl Streep and Emma Watson while recognizable and solid in their parts did not overact or steal attention from the others. No single role stole the show. It was a well balanced story of all characters. I was drawn in. I had to love it.

This new adaptation only holds an extra 17 minutes over its beloved 1994 predecessor and yet finds the time to add new layers to an old story.
While spirited writer Jo is still the central player, each of the March sisters enjoy a good share of the spotlight. None benefit more from this than artist Amy, whose previous depictions as the shallow and opportunistic youngest have here been replaced with an ambitious but realistic young woman who is very aware of her limited options in life.
It takes a brave and talented director to breathe new life into a story that has already been adapted for the screen six times, but Greta Gerwig makes it seem effortless. Saoirse Ronan and Florence Pugh are well deserving of their Oscar nominations. That their director was overlooked in her category is shameful.
Awesome film, great characters, interpretations. Saoirse, Eliza, Timotheé and Florence.

Other than that, the movie was awful.

Beautiful and touching, though I'm not sure about the end.

I enjoyed this more than I thought I would, but it was as good as I'd hoped from Gretta Gerwig since I like her other films. LITTLE WOMEN seems a bit strange that it has 30 year olds playing teenagers, but you know, living was harder back then. Gerwig's choices with what to draw from the book work out pretty well. The set pieces are really great and the performances are just as good. Despite its length, it still felt like it needed more, which I'm guessing is why it works as a novel. Enjoy.
Absolutely beautiful

I haven't read the book or any adaptations because quite frankly this genre isn't quite my cup of tea. However, I must admit to really enjoying this enthralling tale, even though the flashbacks and odd dream sequence threw me a little.

Saoirse Ronan as Jo, is an absolute delight to watch. I believed in her character almost from the first frame, and even though the ending was just a little on the predictable side, I was really pleased she got what she always dreamed about, rather than just cow-towing to what society expects of young women of that era.

Good support all round, other than for the rather wooden performance of Emma Watson.  Laura Dern and Meryl Streep, were particularly excellent. Add to that a rousing score, superb cinematography, wonderful period costumes, and I have to say it was an absorbing 2 hours.

But because of the flashbacks etc. and because I haven't read the book, it does demand a second viewing just to make sense of those jump scenes and thus complete the engaging jigsaw.
A different way to tell the story!

I'm not a fan of romantic or a drama movie.But this one made my day.

"Lady Bird" director Greta Gerwig perfectly connects with the timeless tale of sisterhood and refreshes the frequently-retold story to great effect by her own spin while still faithful, then leaving the heart she has written in a structural sense to be filled by such wonderful ensemble's sharply delivered brilliant efforts to liven the characters. While the previous adaptations, mainly the two predecessors that I have seen and the 1994 prerequisite classic of the story's both modernization and realization, are exceptional in their own way defined by emotional sensitivity, the arguable best, and theoretically the final version till the next generation(s), continues that as it easily fulfill the standardized expectation but emphasizes on connection and perfection. I was never really a fan of "Little Women", but this version was less enjoyable than the Winona Ryder version. Time kept jumping back and forth in this version, and I had to look for clues to see where we were in the timeline. It also seemed like they kept interjecting political talking points at random spots in the movie. I'm not against political messages; it just seemed particularly forced here. The emotions didn't seem real here, either. Sometimes they came across as Hallmark characters on Prozac. The Christmas breakfast scene seemed logistically impossible, and that really bothered me. I had the same problem here as I did with the previous versions: the plot for this story just isn't all that compelling. The photography, clothing and set design were great, though, so there's that.

It made me feel a lot of emotions, I really enjoyed it ! The actors are really talented, the light and colors are amazing and soft giving a poetic tone to the scenes ! It's a great adaptation ! It wasn't a revolution in cinema but quite good !

A beautiful adaption of the classic novel by Louisa May Alcott, Grewig's 'Little Women' consists of a remarkably talented cast and is visually stunning. A must watch, heart-warming film that is guaranteed to make you smile, cry and laugh all at once.

The characters are all so fleshed out and everyone's playing their polar opposite to their characters in Lady Bird; the carefree spirit becomes the lonely downbeat storyteller, the rebellious punk rockstar wannabe becomes the kind, sweet and sensitive gentleman and so on and so forth. We are blessed with a surprising allstar cast, beautiful cinematography, typically sharp writing and directing and a well-paced story where everything feels essential, all as always. I disagree with those who say it's overlong but agree that it's main flaw it it's confounding nonlinear structure set in the blue end of the timeline and the yellowish-orange 7 years prior. All the jumping around is confusing, as well as how vaguely we are told of events and how it intertwines with the author's stories. It doesn't add much to jump around so much, other than to challenge it's audience to figure out it's complex timeline. The ending also felt abrupt, but as I am new to the Little Women property, I cannot say if this was in the original novel or millions of screen adaptations before. I absolutely reccomend it nonetheless. 8.75/10.

I knew this would be one of my favorite movies before I'd finished my first viewing. Louisa May Alcott's book is a classic and a personal favorite, and Greta's version gave it incredible justice in a modern way. It is the first adaptation I've seen that doesn't make Amy out to be a villain but instead dives into the complexity of each girl and represents their own personal struggles- something the book had clearly done. The rearranging of the timeline was done in the most tasteful way, marking time jumps with an obvious yellow filter and differences in the characters' wardrobe and hair styles. Arranging it in this way allowed for audiences to see the parallels between the childhood and adult girls and how they were shaped to become who they are. It caused me to think completely differently about a story I thought I knew by heart. Her writing was also completely immersive. Paired with the outstanding performances, the film was completely natural, allowing a full immersion into their world for the full 2 hours and 15 minutes. If Greta Gerwig wasn't already a legend, this movie tipped her over the fence.
