I expected to be blown away by this film adaptation of the beloved book classic, LITTLE WOMEN, but I just wasn't. I can usually hang tight with films that go back and forth in time, but I found this to be an annoying approach in this film. I know what the writer and director, Greta Gerwig, was trying to do, but I don't feel she pulled it off all that particularly effective. Flashbacks and movement of different time periods in a film need to be perfectly fluid and timed (pun intended), and I just found that was not present here (if interested, a perfect example of successfully accomplishing this film technique can be found in the sublime film, THE HOURS). But LITTLE WOMEN is hardly a bust.  Ronan as Jo is terrific, although she really can't hold a candle to Florence Pugh's unadulteratedly and ambitiously robust performance as Amy.  Pugh takes a truly annoying character like Amy and gives her heart, gives her all kinds of crazed character colors, and this is because Pugh is an actress of great range and depth. Pugh just blew me away in last year's MIDSOMMAR, and she just keeps getting better and better one brilliant performance after another and is undoubtedly Oscar-bound. And I supe- loved the ending of the film, watching Jo's book getting published in that old way that books were once published with bindings and glue and fabric, basically before self-publishing and blogs and online readings found their place.  It gave me chills, and the character of Jo inspired me to always stay true to my artistic vision, NEVER compromise, and to ALWAYS and ONLY write from my heart and my truth and my soul.  These are things I have already come to know, but it certainly hurt nothing to be reminded.

Florence Pugh was a delightful surprise with an honest performance that left me speechless. I just want to encourage Greta Gerwig to keep on writing and directing these fantastic stories that will stay in my heart forever.

From director Greta Gerwig, coming off her 2017 critical darling "Lady Bird", comes the sixth cinematic adaptation of Louisa May Alcott's beloved book "Little Women". Following the goings on of four sisters in 1868 Massachusetts seeing their journey from childhood to adulthood, experiencing love and sorrow as they must come to terms with what lies ahead in their future. Thanks to the masterful oversight of Gerwig we get to observe said journey in such an authentically beautiful way. 

The film already feels like a classic that one might look upon with nostalgia, perhaps this can be accredited to the film's heavy thematic attention to nostalgia. Jumping between present day and the past, it gives the feeling that these flashbacks are childhood memories reappearing as the characters think back on a simpler time. Thankfully Gerwig shows constraint to not force feed us through text appearing on the screen reading "a few years earlier" or use blatant expository dialogue, and despite this the non-linear plot never feels confused. The choice to construct the story in such a way makes for great engagement and pace, helping to maintain the audience's attention.

This distinction of time is successfully achieved thanks to cinematographer Yorick Le Saux's expert attention to colour. The warm hue of the past reflecting the joys and splendours of their childhood creates for a stark contrast to the blue coldness of the present. But while these periods differ so significantly, they are both composed of equally beautiful components. One can give much praise for this to the choice to shoot using film as opposed to digital. Giving the illustrious costume and production design of the film its true medium in which to shine. The grain of the filmstock works well in tandem with the 19th Century period of the film, giving further depth and life to the warmth of the candlelight and the snow-covered exteriors. The way the camera is able to capture the materials and colours of the period reminiscent of a great painting of the time. You can give partial thanks to Steven Spielberg for this who not only suggested, but practically begged Gerwig to utilise film once he caught word that she would be adapting the story to the screen.

But what the film is dependant upon to tie all of this together is the characters, and the respective actors who have been tasked to portray them, and they are nothing short of stellar. Each member of the cast brings such charisma to the screen, and the comradery and feeling of true sisterhood from the central four characters is palpable. While many film casts will say how well they got along on set, for "Little Women" you can feel a genuine sense of chemistry. They feel like a real family, bickering back and forth, laughing together, and caring for each other. It is the great care that the characters show for one another which is so infectious as the viewer finds themselves becoming deeply invested in the lives of these four sisters. 

The two standouts however would have to be Saoirse Ronan as Jo and Florence Pugh as Amy. With Ronan displaying expertly the range of Jo's journey from joy, whimsy, and passion, to devastation, cynicism, and rejection. Whilst Pugh gives genuine humanity to Amy as she grows from a mischievous child to a mature woman. 

It is refreshing to see such a sweet, warm, and ultimately uplifting film. While one may say that at times it is bordering on saccharine, that would be doing a disservice to Gerwig and the casts ability to engage the audience with captivating drama and emotion. One moment the film fills you with a sense of childhood joy, the next emphatic sorrow for its characters, but never does it feel tonally inconsistent, conveying the masterful work of Gerwig's adapted script. 

Whilst watching the film it appears as a mere slice of life, simply observing the days in the life of these sisters, the film in the end reveals how throughout its runtime it has been building up to a satisfying and almost profound feeling of a clearly defined journey from beginning to bitter sweet end. Displaying how it was ultimately about growing up, developing some semblance of autonomy, and figuring out one's place in the world. With all this Gerwig has truly shown the world how to successfully adapt a classic novel to the contemporary cinema scene.

Little Women (4 out of 5 stars). Little Women is a good coming of age drama about four young girls who are raised by there mother. While they meet a young boy across there street which he befriends with them. As years go by, their love for each other changes as they grow apart and trying to overcome with life changes. It is a beautiful plot. I liked it more than i thought. These four girls growing up and changing. One wants to be a writer and live free from marriage. Another wants to be a painter. The other wants to be an actress but falls in love early. And the youngest wants to play music. The plot can be emotional with characters facing tough times in life. It does have a feel good ending. The cast ensemble is great. I love the actors that played there roles. They all did great. The direction and script is great with the storytelling. It was a little confusing at first with the story bouncing around from the past and present. Which the tone and characters clothing needs to be paid attention too to find out were the story is. Overall, Little Women is a good film that is worth seeing.

Omigod – where to begin. I just watched this version of Little Women because it won all these awards. I've seen this version, the BBC version and the one with Winona Ryder (she made a pretty good Joe). So, this latest version seemed so staid; like it was trying to hard to fit in a mold that suited the tastes of today. The "Little Women" didn't seem like a product of *their* time; the one in which the book was written. The struggles didn't seem genuine at all. And when I saw Laura Dern and Bob Odenkirk? No, just, NO! Zero chemistry there. I didn't know Bob Odenkirk was going to be in this and I about busted out laughing when I saw him on the screen.  All of Joe's outfits looked like something from an Anthropologie catalog, and this won an award for costume design? Laurie looked and acted like he was 15 years old the whole way through; showed no signs of maturity and by the end he was supposed to be married? It was just not believable. This version of "Little Women" as a movie, to me, added nothing to what has already been done. Did this movie just get awards based on some big stars being in it? It seems so.

i was so excited to watch this movie and was left so disappointed. the acting was great but the structure of the movie was horrible. rather than following a linear timeline, greta gerwig chose to bounce between present and past randomly throughout the film. the "past" portrayals used the same actors and it made it very difficult to differentiate between timelines. this choice made it difficult to portray character developments and relationships. for example, the relationship between jo and laurie is never fully portrayed; we never see how they got so close or why jo was closer to laurie than any of the other sisters. throughout the film there is also constant chatter; even when unnecessary, and it made it quite distracting during certain scenes. another note to add: florance pugh is an amazing actress but the portrayal of her character's  younger self is whiny, childish, and overall just plain corny (which i don't blame her for, i feel that it was more due to greta's direction). if there had been different actors to portray the characters' younger selves, perhaps this review would be written very differently.

OK, OK, I can hear you screaming. How dare you disparage such a classic story with your dull wit? The work of Greta Gurwig is not meant to be trifled with! Truth is, while this movie has a lot going for it, I do have some problems.

Let's talk about the good stuff first, though. There is some truly stellar acting here. Everyone pulls their weight, and ensemble scenes are just everyone raising each other to new heights. My personal favourite was Florence Pugh, she played the ‘bratty but excitable younger sister' role exceptionally well. Another standout was Laura Dern, who has really been killing it lately with her roles.

The story is nice, too. There are high points, and low points, and even a nice framing device. You end up loving these characters and you understand their motivations very clearly.

My issue lies with the editing. You are constantly jumping around in time, and the cues you are given to understand these jumps are inconsistent. I still don't know at what point Jo cut her hair. Also, it seems to me that [CENSORED]'s death should have been the emotional climax, but because of the editing, we see them again after the death scene? It just doesn't work that well for me.

If you don't mind non-linear storytelling, you will likely appreciate this more than I. Provided, of course, you can get over the fact that they are all full-size women.

Thank you, Ms. Gerwig! This is a lovely story lovingly told. Three moments remain with me: Lawrie quietly and affectionately taking in the riotously loving sisters - Jo comforting her dying sister Beth in bed - the sisters erupting with joy at the return of their father; and yes, a fourth - Marmy. All these highlights in this story of family and neighborly lovingkindness. An oh-so-much-needed reminder that such grace can be known and told in these venomous times. Yet, I agree with viewers that the  flashbacks and fantasies (Jo's dream of Beth's recovery, for example) gave the story a bit of a jagged edge. Nevertheless, I left the theater in joy and delight, all thanks to Ms. Gerwig's masterful work.

Reviewed 1.12.20  Greta Gerwig wrote and directed this latest version of Louisa May Alcott's classic.  Saoirse Ronan is solid as always, serving up an empowered version of Jo March, as Alcott's fictional alter ego.  While Florence Pugh adds strong supporting work, playing Amy with welcome dignity.  Meryl Streep and Chris Cooper headline the senior roles, providing the gravitas lacking from the 1994 version of their characters.  Only Timothee Chamelet seems miscast as a too boyish Laurie. 

Gerwig deserves all the credit she's receiving for somehow reviving a staid story in it's 7th (12th including TV versions?) go around.  Her version possesses superior character development, and most originally, her masterful use of time jumping vignettes.  She basically cut the book up and pastiched it back together in a more cinematic manner. Bravo! 

Unfortunately she eschews more deliberate identifiers, like date/location stamps, for more subtle hints, like alternating colour hues between scenes and stylistic changes for the characters. While the increased activity adds welcome excitement to her telling, it also results in a periodic sense of displacement too.

Those viewers familiar with the source material will follow, and newcomers will find their way. But the challenges persist in pivotal scenes involving the relapse of beloved sister Beth, and when Jo negotiates a deal while the character in her book lives out the editor's requested fantasy ending.

This is a bold return to Alcot's seminal work, loaded with vibrant energy and cinematic beauty.  Gerwig's occasionally unwieldy screenplay distracts, but recreating such classic source material is no simple task.  And the result feels both vital and timely.  Who knew these little women had it in them.

I watched Little Women twice and enjoyed it more the second time. I saw it the first time with my mom, whose movie interests run very narrow (she's basically only into period dramas/romances and romantic comedies). Neither of us was familiar with the Little Women story before watching this movie. The things I liked: the acting was fantastic. Ronan is consistently one of the best actors around. Dern is indomitable in everything she does, Chalemet is an annoyingly charming and capable performer. Florence Pugh is going to be a SUPERSTAR - I couldn't take my eyes off of her (in this or any of her other performances this year). The script was great - it felt modern in a lot of ways, which I appreciated. I appreciated the transitions between warm and cool tones to differentiate between scenes in the present and those in the past. The direction of the ball scene was super cool. And I super enjoyed the open/vague ending. If this is a Gerwig innovation (haven't read the book), it's really brilliant. The things I didn't love: I understand that she's done 8 trillion films and is consistently excellent, but I'm tired of Meryl Streep. Emma Watson was the acting weak link. And as modern as the story felt at times, as much as they tried to at least (lightly) reference the cultural/political context of the period, as compelling as the acting was... very little of this felt fresh. It's been done. It's been seen. I am ready to see more stories about non-White, straight cis women navigating patriarchy and love and independence and friendships and family dynamics in this time period (and others) in ways that aren't deficit-based, clichd, or solely about their suffering. It's why Portrait of a Lady on Fire felt like such a breath of fresh air. These Little Women got to be so human, and it was beautiful to see I felt moved by it throughout the film. And I want to see it happen across more identities and about people that are generally approached with less nuance and humanity. And I want to celebrate, make visible the people doing that work already.

"Little Women" is a resonant reinvention of the oft-adapted, 150-year-old Louisa May Alcott novel of the same name. Gerwig accomplishes this primarily by rearranging the timeline, jumping back and forth between the March sisters in the original novel and a period seven years later. Though it can be a tad confusing at times, this is primarily how Gerwig infuses the narrative with additional relevance and enjoyment, and breathes new life into a classic story.

I thought I'd be annoyed by their attempt to make the movie more feminist, but it was pretty well done.  I won't spoil it by explaining too much.  Don't get me wrong, I consider myself a feminist in general, but sometimes Hollywood can be pretty un-subtle, and this book is a classic, I liked it the way it was.  The changes here weren't too ham-handed, I thought anyway.  My biggest beef with it was that it was kind of confusing.  I know the story well enough that I wouldn't have thought that possible, but they were jumping back and forth between timelines and they used the same actors throughout--we were supposed to buy into adult women playing the child versions of the little women--and it was pretty hard to follow at times.  And if you DIDN'T already know the story it would kind of....ruin it for you.  I didn't quite understand the logic of presenting the story in this strange order other than to be...interesting.  I'm a traditionalist, I know, but I feel like telling the story in chronological order allows you to build up the right kind of relationship with the characters.  Otherwise, the acting was amazing, the casting was great, the costumes and the cinematography were beautiful.  My 11-year-old daughter and I both really enjoyed it.  We laughed and cried like you're supposed to.

The 2019 version of Little Women is the ultimate adaptation of this source material. Greta Gerwig infused newfound energy and life to this famous story while still retaining its core values and an immense charm. The editing and the time jumping can get a bit excessive, but it mostly led to increased emotional intensity. The film is old-fashioned while also being quite lively and fun, and it is technically gorgeous to behold – the costumes are absolutely amazing, the production design is splendid, the score is very good and the attention to detail in recreating its time period is remarkable. Its heart is always in the right place, its portrayal of women is complex and profound, and the character development is truly phenomenal. The standout aspect is the perfect casting with everyone delivering a terrific performance – Saiorse Ronan is incredible as complex Jo, Emma Watson is lovely as very likable Meg, Timothee Chalamet is quite charismatic in the role of Laurie, Meryl Streep is hilarious as wealth-obsessed Aunt March and Florence Pugh herself is a revelation, playing fascinatingly complicated Amy with a tremendous confidence.

Greta Gerwig does something different with her adaptation of Louisa May Alcott's "Little Women". With so many adaptations in existence, she needed to do something to stand out. The adaptation works completely.

Amy (Florence Pugh), Beth (Eliza Scanlen), Jo (Saoirse Ronan) and Meg (Emma Watson) are sisters growing up during the Civil War. Amy is the feisty, youngest sister who dreams of being the best artist; Beth is the musically talented sister with the most health issues; Jo is the writer who defies all traditional female roles and Meg wants to live a domestic life. The story begins in the future and is told via flashbacks starting seven years prior.

Apparently some found the use of the flashbacks confusing, but once the film truly gets going it's easy to differentiate between the time periods. I've read the book so I knew what was the past and what was the future. Still, I thought it was easy to differentiate between the time periods regardless. Most of the scenes that take place in the past involve the sisters' neighbor Laurie (Timothee Chalamet). The cinematography is also bleaker in the future as it matches Beth's declining health.

Gerwig does a great job of making all the characters sympathetic. She also does a great job of showing that all the sisters' life decisions are worthy in their own way because they're living their truths. All the actresses do a great job as well. Ronan has the difficult job of portraying the strong willed sister that has few moments of vulnerability, and those moments she really lets her emotions through. Watson and Scanlen also do great in their roles. The standout for me was Pugh. She portrays Amy as a young girl all the way to being a young woman and she is able to portray that childlike wonder while also showing us her maturity once she's of age.

The main focus of the film is womanhood. It shows that every woman might desire something different from someone else, and regardless of the decisions made, they're valid. Some of the sisters also end up doing something vastly different with their lives than they initially imagined. The problems they faced as women growing up in the 1800s are in many ways still relevant today. Gerwig portrays all of these ideas masterfully.

The film has beautiful moments as well as heartbreaking ones. The sisters never feel like caricatures regardless of their life experiences.

Là một bộ phim nữ quyền kinh điển. Đúng. Nhưng mình không nghĩ nên xem bộ phim này dưới góc nhìn rằng phụ nữ cần phải đấu tranh. Cá nhân mình cảm thấy, dùng view đó nhìn về phụ nữ, đã là không công bằng cho họ rồi.
Một cách công bằng nhất mà nói, mỗi con người, mỗi giới tính đều phải chịu những bất công riêng mà xã hội dành cho họ, không ở lĩnh vực này thì cũng trong lĩnh vực kia, không vì lý do này thì cũng vì lý do kia.
Vì vậy, cứ xem như đây là một bộ phim kể về quá trình trưởng thành của rất nhiều con người, trong đó mỗi nhân vật đều cho mình một bài học để có thêm nghị lực vượt qua nghịch cảnh. Và rằng hạnh phúc là do tất cả mọi người cùng nhau tạo dựng chứ không là trách nhiệm của riêng số phận nào.
Xem phim với góc nhìn như thế, mình cho rằng, mới gọi là công bằng.
P/s 1: À mà đôi lúc để đạt được hạnh phúc, chiến thắng bóng đêm, con người ta cũng cần sự dẫn lối của thiên thần. Phải, với mình, Beth là thiên thần, thật sự là một thiên thần có phép màu.
P/s 2: Gặp lại Saoirse Ronan (Jo) mà cứ ngỡ như người nào xa lại. Chẳng nhớ ra được đây chính là cô bé Susie Salmon ngày nào, lưu lạc cõi tạm bợ để tìm cho ra kẻ đã sát hại mình và tìm thấy lý do để mỗi linh hồn tồn tại. The Lovely Bones (2009), highly recommend các bạn ạ.

I loved Little Women! I went into this movie knowing nothing about the source material and in most cases I probably wouldn't have been interested in seeing it at all, yet alone in theaters. However, when I saw Greta Gerwig was directing and Saoirse Ronan was playing the lead, I made sure I saw it as soon as I could. 

Like I said, I knew nothing about the story going in, so watching all the character work and plot developments unfold was deeply captivating. The March sisters and their entourage are all likable and the story doesn't feel antiquated at all, despite being 150 years old. Its one of those escapist period pieces where you just feel immersed in the time period and want to spend more time there. You wanna spend more time with this family. It's over two hours long, but it doesn't feel like it. The film breezes by on whimsy and charm. The cast is surprisingly star-studded and the acting is all top-notch. Saoirse Ronan has quickly become one of my favorite actresses. The life and personality she brings to the role is just incredible to watch. Everyone embodies their character so well that I didn't even mind Emma Roberts' accent slipping from time to time.

My favorite character was Jo, played by Ronan, which makes sense because the Little Women Personality Test said I'm a Jo. She's definitely the focus and I would be lying if I said her relationship with the young aristocrat Laurie didn't have me swooning and rooting for romance. 

Gerwig 100% got robbed for a Best Director nomination. To take this Civil War-era story and make it feel fresh is no small feat and she achieves it seemingly without effort. I doubt all the adaptations are this good! The setting and costumes are so simple, yet there's so much life in them. When it's warm, it feels warm. When it's cold, it feels cold; not just in the visuals, but in tone. 

In conclusion, Little Women is excellent. It doesn't feel old and it's not too harsh, so anyone at any age can enjoy it. It's about women, but don't think that makes it inaccessible to men, who I genuinely think will like it as well. Its funny when it needs to be. It's emotional when it needs to be. It's relatable, surprisingly timely and overall, it's just a good time. Go see It because I want to see more movies like this. Call me selfish, I don't care! I want Gerwig-Ronan movies every Oscar season for the next 20 years! More Little Women's & Lady Birds can only be a good thing

This movie was cliche beyond belief. I had heard a lot of positive talk about Greta Gerwig, and so I was sadly disappointed in Little Women. I didn't feel aligned with any of the characters nor did aI feel like their performances were more than superficial renderings, largely due to a crappy script and cheap dialogue. The moments where the women "made a stand" to say something about the society's restrictions also felt cheap and manufactured. Gerwig could have done so much more with this story, even without "changing" it to some sort of activist message.. just develop the characters into real people rather than spoiled, privileged people who say nothing of importance - nothing we haven't already heard before. The film was a cliche snooze in nearly all aspects. I should note that I am a queer feminist too.. this film worked to uphold gender stereotypes, cliche notions of love, cliche notions of people who step outside of leading a "normal" existence. It pointed to the sexism inherent in any patriarchal society, but it didn't do enough to critique it in my eyes. The woman changes the book at the end to fit into the stereotyped stories for and about women (and therefore men).. separating the sexes even further. Gerwig does nothing that makes any sort of new cultural insertion into this conversation. I would suggest not giving this film your time.

This was the worst adaptation of " Little Women" that I have ever seen. There was absolutely no charisma or camaraderie between the cast members, although to be fair, individual cast members played their parts adequately. Emma Watson could just not pull off the part of the  proper, reserved oldest sister, Meg. Laura Dern, as  Mrs March ( the mother)  came across as shallow and plastic. And of course the brief conversation her character has in a scene with a black woman, near the beginning of the film, about how she was ashamed, and is still ashamed of America, came from no part of this classic novel, and was just another vehicle to spew Hollywood hate. 
The young actor playing "Theodore Lawrence" looked far too young and effeminate for the part. He did the best he could in a part for which he had been miscast. 
The way the movie unfolded, starting practically with the end of the novel as we have known it, then jumping back and forth to flesh out the characters and lend explanation to events, was irritating. And unless you are already familiar with this classic story of the March family, I think you might find it confusing..
I have never seen a movie that so compelled me to voice such negative review. Until now.

I had heard a lot about Little Women before I saw it, from friends that had read the book to people that had already seen the movie 4 times in one week. I went in expecting a cinematic masterpiece and was not disappointed. The variety of charming characters provided every viewer with someone they could relate to. Each with their own well developed personalities, you may think it would be tricky to truly explore everyone in 2 hours but the director did a fantastic job. Little Women chronicles the lives of four sisters over about a 10 year period, and instead of playing the story chronologically, the movie is arranged connecting moments from the girls childhood to their adult years. You may think this constant switching back and forth would be confusing and hard to follow, but the production team made it clear by aging the characters and displaying events from the girls childhood with a warmer filter and events from later on with cool tones.

With Little Women, first published in 1868, Louisa May Alcott crafted a story so nearing perfection that not only has it become a classic, but it is difficult to mess up when retelling it. The fourth big screen adaptation Alcott's novel, written and directed by Greta Gerwig, finds a fresh approach to the lives of the March sisters without making any major changes to the well-loved story. Gerwig uses a flashback structure, a steady and lively pace, equally lively performances, and a lovely score by Alexandre Desplat to make this period drama easily engaging to a modern audience. 

Gerwig begins her film near the end of Alcott's story with Jo (Saoirse Ronan) living in New York trying to carve out a career as a fiction writer. Her sisters are scattered and wrapped up in their adult lives. Meg (Emma Watson) is raising a family and keeping a house while struggling with money. Amy (Florence Pugh) is learning painting in Europe. Only selfless and caring Beth (Eliza Scanlen) remains with their parents at the March family home in Massachusetts. Then the film flashes back to where to the novel and other film versions begin, with the sisters as adolescents living together under one roof with their mother, Marmie (Laura Dern, with infinite patience and warmness and wisdom). Their father is away serving with the Union army in the Civil War. It is seven years before we began with Jo living in New York.

There is real joy and emotion in the scenes of the March sisters together (that's the appeal of watching any version of Little Women) but we get time with each of the sisters on their own. We get to know them as individuals and are privy to what is in their minds and hearts. Gerwig put together a fine ensemble but Saoirse Ronan and Florence Pugh have been singled out by the Academy with Oscar nominations in the Lead and Supporting categories, respectively. This is no surprise since Jo and Amy are the two showy roles.

Ronan brings just the right kind of energy to the rebellious, strong willed, sometimes abrasive, but always charming, Jo. She is full of life and personality without becoming a caricature. On the other hand, I found Florence Pugh's performance as the youngest sister Amy (a child when the novel begins) so broad as to be distracting. Pugh plays Amy throughout the film, but the younger Amy's behavior and actions have not been altered in any significant way. So, in the flashbacks we see an adult Florence Pugh speaking and acting like a child even though she looks like a teenager at the youngest (even with her Cindy Brady haircut). This unfortunately makes the younger Amy come off as odd and extra bratty.

Timothèe Chalamet is a perfect fit for the role of Laurie, the dreamy and charming boy next door destined to be intertwined with the March sisters. Chalamet brings a lively physicality to his performance, moving his long, slender body with a lilt that matches the energy of the movie. In smaller but no less entertaining roles are Meryl Streep and Tracy Letts. Streep plays the intimidating and acerbic Aunt March, who is rich enough to be able to speak her mind. She is full of 19th century quips and zingers that are delivered wonderfully. Letts plays a grumpy New York publisher that is willing buy Jo's stories if they are spicy and if Jo's female main characters get married at the end, or die. Jo's conversations with him are entertaining but also come right up against being too meta for the movie's own good (if you weren't sure about Jo being a stand-in for Alcott, these scenes leave no doubt).

I have to admit that as much the jumps back and forth in time work for the overall structure of the film some of the cuts are not immediately apparent and it takes a moment to figure out where you are in the timeline. Once you get into the rhythm of the pacing, however, you'll find yourself caught up in the film's enthusiasm and love for its characters. Right from the start this version of Little Women lets you know that it is not a pageant, not just another recreation of a familiar story, but a new perspective on a classic story that gets to the core of what makes this story timeless. The climax of Gerwig's adaptation, is not whether or not Jo gets married and to whom, but how she is able to stay true to herself and her dreams and her family.

Even though these stigmas are well torn down, the movie raises a decently valid question about marriage and women in work business. Saiorse Ronan and Florence Pugh are the high points here, while some direction is definitely out of touch with its cast (the "You're on fire" scene and "I don't know anyone" scene), the story lacks climax or even an anti-climax (like The Irishman did with Frank Sheeran last moments) and the confusing time lapses are enough to confuse the spectator, but that's Greta Gerwig unwise choice to not pick an adolescent cast to play the younger sisters.

I have a tendency to enjoy these period romantic dramas that a number of foolish men would write off as “chick flicks.” There’s something so charming about watching the complicated courting rituals from these more traditional times. Little Women worked for me on the same level that most Jane Austen adaptations work. It has several moments that get boring, but I get so involved in the characters’ lives that I want to see how their story ends anyways. Ordinarily, I’d say there was a risk of me falling asleep with a movie like this, but I cared about the titular women (which makes all the difference.) The cast in this adaptation is quite good, and there are a number of powerful moments that they deliver with all the emotion required. I liked the inventive way that they bounced back and forth between the present and the past. At first it would take a moment to ground myself and figure out we had changed time period, but eventually there were key indicators you could count on to place yourself in the timeline. Unfortunately, I found myself crying much less in Little Women than I would expect for this kind of story. There are several moments that were clearly meant to bring out the emotions, and I worried that I should have brought more tissues, but I barely got misty-eyed. That is unlike me, but I think there was something lacking in the way they were presented, because I could see every one of the moments coming. My other big complaint with the way this film was presented is some of the clunky ADR lines they shove in for no good reason. Over the past few years, I’ve become painfully aware of when the director dubs in a line when we can’t see a characters’ mouth move, and pretends it was there from the start. The two most blatant occurrences of this technique were throw-away lines that added noting to the film. In fact, one of them was answered mere minutes later on screen. So, it wasn’t a perfect film-going experience for me, but the quality of the story-telling and acting were such that I enjoyed myself anyways.

Beautifully written, directed, acted, filmed. The characters are completely believable. We feel all of their joys and sorrows, and we feel we know them so intently that we regret the movie has to come to an end -  but most importantly, this movie adroitly shows the tremendous gender gap in patriarchal society in 19th century American (and European) society, and the ways in which women could deal with power - and money. In this movie all this is done with a wonderful light touch, frequently with gentle humor and always with a sense of realistic optimism. The brilliant dialogue and superb acting, and imaginative cinematography result in 7th-Art storytelling of the highest order. The women and the men in this film are authentic; their emotions, hopes, despair, losses, and accomplishments are ours, too. A chef-d'œuvre from Gerwig, brava!

I watched this film back in December and it's images and thought provoking script enter my mind frequently. Gerwig insisted the Actors who play siblings live together during the 2 months of filming as well as lots of improvisations during rehearsals to create a strong "sisterly" bond. This showed in every scene; Gerwig and her Actors created the joyful chaos of a house full of siblings. The bickering, the talking over one another and the laughter. Shot in film instead of digital was a brilliant choice for a period piece and the cinematography was breathtaking. Costume design was a highlight for me. The sumptuous materials of the dresses looked like were flowing out of the screen and could so easily be touched.  Stand out performances from Timothée Chalamet and Florence Pugh. Both seem so effortless in their genius acting choices. Disappointingly Gerwig has not been nominated an Academy award for directing and neither has it's Cinematographer however it's costume designer has so we may have a winner here.

The most overrated film of 2019 by far. I wand to preface this review by saying that this instalment was the first version I saw of "Little Women" and I have not read the book. I am just baffled by the good reviews this director and consequently this film has received and it makes me wonder who is really writing these reviews and what credentials and knowledge about film they actually possess. Gerwig misses everything when it comes to character development, plot, theme and even following a coherent storyline. The flashbacks are so awkwardly integrated into the story that it becomes very difficult to follow. The fact that the actors/actresses don't seem to age (Florence Pugh playing also the younger version of Amy March in a rather childish and awkward performance) does not help, nor does the lack of any kind of maturing process. All roles seem to be caricatures and ideas without any substance. We are unaware of inner or outer conflicts until they are presented to us in the end. Lori was in Love with Jo...I didn't know. Jo was in love with the professor...I didn't know. Jo was dying to go to Europe...I didn't know. Jo was facing prejudice as a female writer...I didn't know. Meg wanted to be an actress...I had no idea! It goes on and on. I didn't care about Beth dying, I didn't care about any of the characters because they were not developed at all. One has to go back to the 1994 version to really understand and get an idea why this beloved novel had been turned into a film so many times. And it's so simple. One look between Christian Bale (Lori) and Wynona Ryder (Jo) and his love for her is clear. The most basic forms of storytelling are simply missed. When Beth dies, I had no emotional connection to her because I didn't get her struggle. She was completely irrelevant and I also didn't get her connection to her sisters and what she represented. What did I miss? How did I not care about someone dying? If anyone watches Clair Danes in the 94 version, one cannot keep their eyes dry not only because of a wonderful performance, but because we feel for her, we know her, we understand who she was within this family. Gerwigs film doesn't even scratch the service not only of these characters, but the theme altogether. I was shocked by the mere absence of what the novel supposedly set out to do: to tell a story about women empowerment in a time when women were meant to do nothing else but taking care of the home and the children. Gerwigs decide to change history and present us with a newspaper editor who presents to conflict to the theme whatsoever. We are presented with a family dynamic that seems everything but surpressed. We are presented with women who are already free to choose, without the pressure of finding a rich husband to secure their future. What is the point of this film? What is it trying to portray or tell the audience if no conflict is present in regards to female empowerment and yet this director and the film are plastered with MeToo praises in a world that turns mediocrity  into a weapon...but an ineffective one. So many of these actor's performance are rendered bizarre and useless as the writing turns them into mere result driven puppets. If anyone truly wants to understand and feel these characters to the fullest, please go back and watch Gillian Armstrong's rendition of it. Sadly, this female director didn't have the fortunate circumstance to make her film in a "MeToo" era and yet should be much more praised for making a feminist film with wonderful female characters in a time when it wasn't fashionable. It's should be about the quality of what we make, not about who is behind it.

I was expecting to love this film, and was very disappointed. I think Gerwig had a bold idea, which was to combine a classic story with modern feminist ideas. But to me the way she tried to fuse the two just didn't work: the scenes that were most faithful to Alcott were sentimental and diminished: and then in scenes she wrote herself, the dialogue sounded akin to what women would say a hundred years after the films time. I also did not think the scrambled chronology worked: I know the story well and yet was unsure from scene to scene where we were: childhood, teen years, or adult years. Back and forth, in and out: the jumping around kept me from connecting with any of the characters: It would be like a person changing their clothes every 15 minutes over a long lunch: so distracting! What a shame. I loved a few things: the sets and historical details were very interesting to me; I found the male characters, especially Laurie, compelling and less confusing than the women. And some of Jo's bravery was moving; but while critics and viewers seem to love this version, I just felt it was a flop. I still think Greta is a wonderful artist-look forward to seeing whatever she does next.

This version of Little Women has stuck in my head since watching it back in December. It delves deeper than any other version focusing on siblings Amy and Beth's character arcs more than we've seen before. It was refreshing especially as Amy is notoriously disliked. Gerwig shot in film which was perfect for this period drama; It would have felt odd watching it any other way. During rehearsals Gerwig insisted the Actors bond through improvisations and sharing a home during filming. This preparation shows; Gerwig and the Actors capture a chaotic household of sisters perfectly; the squabbling, the talking over one another and the laughter. It's joyful to watch. Unlike other versions, Gerwig chose to skip back and forth through time. A brave choice to make but it works excellently by the use of clever editing, melding past and present together with different intent.  The costume design is breathtaking. The clothes are sumptuous making you want to reach into the screen and touch them. Standout performances from Timothée chalamet who plays Laurie and Florence Pugh playing Amy. Both effortless in their acting choices. Laura Dern (Marmee) is brilliant as always. I hope this picks up at least a couple of Academy awards this year.

"In the end, Little Women doesn't do enough to warrant a spot in my 2019's Top10, but Greta Gerwig's adaptation of the classic graphic novel deserves all of the screenplay awards it has been receiving so far. As expected, the whole cast is phenomenal, but Saoirse Ronan, Florence Pugh, and Timothée Chalamet not only deliver the best performances of the film, but their characters carry the most compelling arcs. With so many people, it's remarkable the level of detail, complexity, and depth that each character has. However, some storylines are not as captivating as others, and the pacing suffers from these less exciting stories, which bring the movie down for some moments. The past-present transitions are mostly well-handled but a few are too confusing and abrupt. The contrasting tones of each timeline are consistent throughout the runtime, and the costume design steals the "technical spotlight". Overall, it's a pretty good romance, so if you enjoy the genre, I can't see why you shouldn't enjoy this one."

I feel so lucky that this is my first memorable exposure to the story of Little Women. This is a stunning film with effective pacing and an extraordinary cast.

The decision to tell the story of the March sisters in a nonlinear way creates emotional ebbs and flows that drive the plot flawlessly. The talent and chemistry of the entire cast blew me away. Florence Pugh and Timothée Chalamet gave stand out performances as Amy and Laurie. Pugh's portrayal of Amy as a daydreaming, impetuous pre-teen who grows into an intelligent, passionate young woman is utterly charming. It's impossible not to get butterflies while Chalamet is on-screen. Even while portraying a stumbling drunk Laurie, he moves and speaks with elegance.

Although I have not read Little Women since before I can remember, it is my understanding that Greta Gerwig did a great justice to the book, which is now on my re-read list. I am so grateful to be introduced to such strong and incredible women who are encouraged to be themselves and follow their hearts and minds on their own terms.

This movie is a gorgeous retelling of a beloved story, without being inauthentic or cheap. Gerwig crafts her female characters in a way few writers can, and directs a film with cinematography reminiscent of Victorian-era paintings. The story has something new to say about being a woman in a man's world, the pains of growing up, and where we find true love. Not only this, but it does justice to Louisa May Alcott's story in a very (fascinatingly) meta style. This movie is engaging, insightful, well rounded, full of astounding performances/dialogue, and it is a film I will hold dear to my heart for a long time.

While it is a little long, this newest adaptation of Louisa May Alcott's classic novel, "Little Women," may be the best version yet. In this version the story of the four March sisters (Amy, Jo, Meg and Beth) in the 1860s is told through flashback from their later lives, which at times seems a little confusing and unnecessary. Still, the Jo and Laurie storyline is as heartbreaking as ever in that Anne of Green Gables and Gilbert sort of way. The cast in superb with the March girls really inhabiting their characters. Saoirse Ronan is wonderful as the feisty and energetic Jo, determined to find her own truth in the world and Florence Pugh makes me dislike Meg that little bit less than usual.
Exceptional cast and acting. Very heartfelt and emotional movie. Last minute decision to see this movie and I am glad I did.

I had low expectations to begin with but the rotten tomatoes reviews came in so positive that I gave it a try.  The visuals were lovely, landscapes and interiors, however the costuming was frumpy and the hair and makeup awful. The characters were terribly miscast and the feminist message annoying. The exceptions were Amy, Laurie and the Professor, who gave the movie a chance to succeed, unfortunately they did not blend authenticity with rest of the cast, the actress who played Jo would have been a fine Anne of Green Gables , the director was clearly confused. And the "Meg" was the saddest, most depressing version that I could ever imagine. It is too bad, I could not suspend belief to enjoy this rendition, it was stiff and out of sync. 
On the other hand the recent BBC version with Maya Hawke was fantastic!

Little Women is a movie with some great moments. I think Saoirse Ronan's performance was outsanding and certain parts of the movie worked really well. However, sudden tonal shifts and time jumps made the movie somewhat confusing at times.

Little Women is great with its characters. All of the characters are distinct and are played by great actresses. As I mentioned above, Saoirse Ronan is a stand-out among the others and is one of my favorite performances of the year. Furthermore, the story handled emotion really well and made the movie interesting to watch. I enjoyed the use of period-accurate clothing and set pieces. Some of the shots in this movie were shot really nicely. Near the end of the movie, I started becoming more invested in the story and the characters. The final act is a wonderful piece of movie, I'd recommend it for this alone.

While I enjoyed this movie, I did have quite a few issues. First off, the sudden tonal shifts felt abrupt at times. I mentioned above that this film handles emotion well. Still, it never seems like the movie can stick with a mood for more than a few minutes. There were also odd uses of time progression, often leaving me confused about when this was compared to other events. I haven't read the book, so, it's possible that some of this might have made more sense to others. While this isn't something that ruined the movie, I was also bothered by how much they complained about how poor they were while they were putting on fancy clothing. Most of my complaints are focused on the end of the first act and the start of the second. After that, I enjoyed it the whole way through.

That being said, I really enjoyed this movie overall. It tells a great story and is presented well for the most part. I would definitely recommend this to anyone that has or has not read the book. It's an emotion-filled movie with great acting and a wonderful final act. I'm giving this movie a 3.5/5 because some of my complaints bugged me more than they should have. Still, it is a great movie, I would recommend it.

If Florence Pugh wasn't already on my short list for best actress from her exhausting and sublime performance in MIDSOMMAR earlier this year, her turn as Amy in LITTLE WOMEN just shot her to the top of whatever list of good actors I don't actually keep. Sure Saoirse Ronan is great as always, and Laura Dern just won the Golden Globe for her supporting role...oh yeah, and...Hermyoney...was in the movie...too. But Pugh manages to turn the most objectively annoying character in the movie into a wonderfully complex study of sisterhood. If she were the only leg the movie had to stand on it would be entirely adequate. However director Greta Gerwig assembled an amazing cast including everyone's favorite twinkie emo boy Timothy Chalamet, and I couldn't believe I was looking at Bob Odenkirk from "Mr. Show" in a heartfelt Hollywood adaptation of a classic piece of semi-proto-feminist literature. It truly is the BerenstAin universe at this point.

After turning out one of the finest movies of 2017, LADY BIRD, Gerwig had some great expectations to top it, and I can't say I'm terribly surprised to see she exceeded those expectations and decimated them. This is easily one of the most moving and universal stories put to screen this year. It kind of ticks me off that I have to wait months at a time to see something as good as this, and when it comes out there's about four or five other films released the same week that absolutely kick me in the gut. Movie distributors need to take a leaf from Gerwig and learn a better sense of pacing. I get pretty ticked off by time jumping narratives, but for some reason the way LITTLE WOMEN unfolds is so optimally timed and perfectly accents the juxtaposition of the girls' adolesence and their burgeoning adulthood. Now let's see if Gerwig can handle a STAR WARS spinoff or maybe a 7th phase Marvel movie. That'll be a true testament to her skills as a filmmaker.

Conquering Ourselves

Little Women (99/100 )     (Spoilers: but only if you havent read the book(shame on you!))

Dress/Coat Score(0.5/1) This was handled better  in the 1978 miniseries.

Story Score(29/29) This viewing has convinced me. This ranks with Pride and Prejudice as the most endearing, and enduring, stories in literature. Jo Marsh and Elizabeth Bennet are definitely my two favorite characters.

Flashback Score(0.5/1) An interesting, and new, way to tell the story. It was effective in Beths death scene was confusing at some other points.

Conquering Ourselves Score(20/20) The movie never shoves it in our face but its always there – the desire to become a better person. From the first Christmas, through Megs determination not to be poor(and to have a dress), and Jos desire to curb her temper, and Jos selling of her hair(and her Moms pride in her, and her later anguish) and the constant pointing out of flaws in Lauries character, the upward are is always on becoming our best self, on conquering our weaknesses.

Gods Will Score(20/20) Well, God hasnt met my will yet  Jo thinks her passion will carry the day, that she can heal her sister with her fervor. And, yes, sometimes youll rush downstairs and find Beth and the kitchen table, but sometimes all youll find is your weeping mother. So what happens when our will meets Gods will. We bow. We can do nothing else.

Relationship/Mise en Scene Score (30/30) The heart of the movie. Gerwig makes an interesting choice to reveal Jos rejection of Laurie early on. So there is no suspense about that relationship. This leaves us free to consider the question of fulfillment how do the characters conquer themselves?  Meg finds that even a marriage relationship doesnt always satisfy, she still wants the pretty dress even at the expense of Johns coat. But she learns to take satisfaction in the relationship and to relinquish possession of the fabric.

REPORT THIS AD

But Jo is at the center of the outworking of this question.  In the central scene of the movie she rejects Lauries proposal. He goes and leaves her alone on a hillside. Alone except for the church in the distance and as she sits on the grass she places herself under the church.  Because even in the absence of the human relationships we want there is a deeper yearning. Not just a will to which we can bow but a love in which we can immerse ourselves.  It is this relationship which makes the quest to conquer ourselves not just a question of ethics but one of a perfecting love. We dont just strive to comply with an abstract set of norms, we strive to know and love the one who made us.
Jo beautifully expresses a tension in the film, Women have souls, and ideas, and they should be able to express them!  But Im so lonely!
There is a relationship that encompasses both of these yearnings, that invites us to be all that we were created to be.  But which still acknowledges that its not good to be alone. In their enjoyment of family and their yearning to conquer themselves and their(sometimes stiff-necked) bowing to Gods will Jo and Meg and Amy and Beth and Marmee and Laurie testify to the joy and sadness we all encounter on the journey to find our better selves.

With a wealth of talent both in front of and behind the camera, Little Women is the 5th adaptation of the Louisa May Alcott story. Despite all the plaudits, it felt to me like a pretty typical period melodrama. People argue over money, over love, over career choices or whatever else comes up. The dialogue is often frantic and spoken by many characters in close proximity, so I had trouble keeping up with a lot of what was happening, and the films insistence on constantly jumping back and forth between 2 times periods quickly became tiresome. Sometimes its hard to know which point in time we're supposed to be observing. It's completely unnecessary, and having the film take place in chronological order would have made the character development much more convincing, rather than having them abruptly shift from one emotional extreme to another. The acting is great, as you'd expect from this cast, though I was less impressed with Timotheé Chalamet, who always seems to act like the spoiled, smug rich brat who nobody really wants to have around. His romances don't feel very convincing, partly because of the films spontaneous time jumps, and also because there doesn't seem to be much genuine emotion in their interactions. When he does get married it feels more like an obvious rebound than anything else. I suspect many will enjoy it more than I did, and while there was plenty to admire, I just wasn't taken with it.

From books to plays, to films, the Little Women story is one of those stories that just keeps getting updated, which isn't a bad thing, as long as they are doing it for a specific reason and not because they are out of ideas. Thankfully, it's very clear that this adaptation was updated for the modern age, which felt like a strong enough reason when watching it. Now, I'll be very upfront with this before diving into my review and state that I don't have any knowledge of this classic material, prior to viewing this movie, so it felt pretty fresh to me. For that reason, you may want to take this review with a grain of salt, but here's why I believe the 2019 version of Little Women is worth your time. 

Flashing back and forth between time periods, the focal point of this film is Jo March (Saoirse Ronan) and her writing ambitions. The film begins and concludes with her story, but the rest of the movie places her sisters Meg (Emma Watson), Amy (Florence Pugh), and Beth (Eliza Scanlen) at the forefront as well. All trying to find a man to love and discovering what love truly is, these young women strive to become something greater than how they grew up. Diving into very emotional struggles as the film goes on, there is quite a bit of depth to this story. Loss and relationships are what kept this film emotionally resonant with me and I believe the care that was put into the characters is what made it work so well. 

It doesn't hurt that the cast was so well constructed, but I believe the shining star here is director Greta Gerwig. Although I feel that this is a very solid film like all of her previous works (as she has yet to blow me away), she definitely seems to be improving, every single time she steps behind the camera. This is her best film to date in my opinion. The way she was able to bring such raw and realistic performances out of these actresses was amazing. Timothee Chalamet is also an actor on the rise to super-stardom and his presence here was nothing short of fantastic either. 

Little Women is filled with some very well-done cinematography by Yorick Le Saux and I also found Nick Houy's editing style to be pretty special as well. With that said, the main thing that deterred me from loving this film was the pacing. There are times, especially throughout the majority of the second act where the movie seemed to really slow down. Yes, these moments were buoyed by effective drama, but I found myself waiting for the next scene to come on a few occasions. This is a wonderful film that I just found to be a little too slow. 

In the end, although the pacing of this movie did hurt my experience a little, which doesn't usually happen with slow-paced films, I still was able to really admire it. Little Women is a fantastic effort by director Greta Gerwig and many of the technical aspects stood out to me as well. Quick shout out to the set design and costume work as well, as those will probably be worth of awards very soon. This is a wonderful movie from start to finish and it deserves all the praise it's receiving, but I just didn't quite love it myself. Still, it's a very good movie nonetheless.

Laura Dern continues to prove David Lynch correct in saying she can do anything.  Probably most interesting about this adaption is how the sense of individuality all four girls have; nobody is sidelined or treated as an afterthought, and for the occasional frustration you feel, you never detach from the characters. Surprisingly snappy rendition of a classic for young girls to grow up with, and for boys to learn from.

Based on the 1868 drama novel written by Louisa May Alcott, this lovely and romantic movie directed by Greta Gerwig follows Jo March, a writer reflecting back and forth on her life, telling the beloved story of the 4 very independently-minded March sisters. I have sadly never had the pleasure to read the novel but I definitely will after familiarising with this adorable story. The main characters are superbly portrayed by Saoirse, Timothée, Emma and Florence, and Alexandre Desplat's score gives the story the magic only he is able to convey. Gerwig's innovative adaptation seems more progressive and makes the sisters have a more modern and fresh feeling of freedom. It may well have a good chance of winning for Adapted Screenplay. Good luck at the awards' season!

Après Lady Bird, on pouvait s'attendre à quelque chose de très grand de la part de Greta Gerwig. Il se trouve que Little Women est une petite déception. Son sens du dialogue a disparu au profit d'une adaptation sage du roman de Louisa May Alcott, sa mise en scène est devenue extrêmement commune et sa direction d'acteur est entravée par la catastrophe Emma Watson qui continue à montrer qu'elle est une piètre actrice. Little Women n'est pas sans ses charmes, Saoirse Ronan est toujours fabuleuse mais au bout de 50 minutes, l'ennui poli montre son nez et ne quitte plus, possiblement dû à une structure catastrophique qui mélange les temporalités et qui dessert totalement le propos. Petit accident de parcours pour Greta Gerwig.

Most reviews I've seen of this film have reviewed it either as a take on a classic story, which it is. However, I've never read the source material, nor have I seen another version of this story. Therefore, I can only review this as I would any other film. Having said that, this is a well made film in all regards except the story. The characters are rushed in, to the point that almost 20 minutes into the film there's voice over that has to be accompanied with a quick shot of the actor just so you know who it is talking. You are asked to care about characters before you've really even memorized their names. There's way to much exposition. Motivations are obvious and carried through dialogue.   Character traits have to be visually portrayed with such means as having messy hair. I guess I could blame the source material but as an adaptation screenplay could things not have been done in the process of adapting it to make it better? Besides the storytelling problems the film is fine. I'm not sure why it was made if there are other versions of this same story. It's like Les Miserables, every time a studio wants a prestige film they just do another version of something most people could care less about and which by today's standards isn't very well written to begin with. My rating was the "Meh, it passed the time" rating...it fits. This wouldn't be so bad if it didn't get a Best Picture nomination. There were more films by far more deserving. See it if you haven't seen any other version of "Little Women..." or don't. It's not really a good story to begin with.

Ao assumir o roteiro, e direção, de Litte Women Greta Gerwig teve a preocupação de não alterar a essência de uma história já conhecida e querida pelo público. Nesa nova versão Greta conseguiu deixar uma história que talvez seja considerada meio enfadonha por alguns, muito mais interessante, ao contar a narrativa de forma não linear ela consegue capturar muito mais não só a atenção do público, como também sua devoção as irmãs March.
A Jo March de Saoirse Ronan traz ainda mais empatia, é incrível ver o que ela e Greta fizeram com uma personagem que já tinha a afeição do público, Ronan conseguiu trazer perfeitamente toda a molecagem de Jo durante sua adolescência e também sua maturidade quando a vemos como uma Jovem Adulta. Ela brilha ainda mais em uma cena específica onde contracena com Laura Dern, onde ela afirma que está cansada de todos dizendo que tudo que importa para as mulheres é o amor, é ali que vemos toda vunerabilidade de Jo, que acaba justificando sua quarta indicação ao Oscar.
Florence Pugh, que já havia mostrado que é uma das grandes atrizes dessa nova geração depois de sua atuação impecável em Midsommar, também mostra o quanto sua indicação a atriz coadjuvante também foi merecida. Pugh consegue mostrar totalmente duas versões de Amy: a irmãzinha egoista e "pentelha" de Jo e a artista madura que buscava a perfeição.
É certo dizer que cada um do elenco escolhido a dedo do filme traz algo único para seu personagem, por mais simples que seja.
Nessa nova versão Greta nos faz entender a importância de precisarmos tanto de filmes com histórias de mulheres roteirizados, dirigidos e produzidos por mulheres, coisa que a tempo atrás talvez não tenha surtido diferença, mas que hoje em dia é importântissa.
Ao terminar de assistir esse filme automaticamente entramos para o clube de pessoas que ficaram completamente indignados com a ausência do nome de Gerwig na indicações do Oscar de Melhor Direção, pois com ele Greta nos prova que a narrativa certa escrita pelas mãos certas faz absoluta diferença.

Adapting a book like "Little Women" which has been adapted to the screen so many times previously with the George Cukor version being possibly the best is a seemingly insurmountable task. Greta Gerwig seemed like the dream choice to serve as both writer and director of the film as she could inject her fresh, modern perspective and write dialogue that sounded quotidian. When the film's trailer was released I had immediate doubts as the spewing of feminist ideals with little consideration of the period the film is set in and Saoirse Ronan's odd accent put me on edge. In 2019 the film opened to rave reviews so I assumed that I would love it but I felt deflated and sad after watching the film as all the expectations I had for the film were not met.

During the American Civil War in Concord, Massachusetts, the spirited and strong willed young writer Josephine March, Saoirse Ronan, struggles to express herself within a patriarchal society. She has an antagonistic relationship with her younger sister Amy, Florence Pugh, as March has more opportunities than Amy and the two both have a close bond with Theodore Laurence, Timothee Chalamet. March's older sister Meg, Emma Watson, is the most sensible member of the family and marries the poor but noble John Brooke, James Norton, but finds it difficult to let go of the pleasures that come with having money. Finally, the youngest sister Beth, Eliza Scanlen, dies of an illness that her sisters had tried to prevent by earning enough money to pay for expensive medical treatments. Years later Amy falls in love with Laurence while in Europe but still suffers from an inferiority complex in relation to her sister and feels that she is seen as second best. Meanwhile March writes her first book and develops feelings for the older teacher Friedrich Bhaer, Louis Garrel.

One of my issues with the story of Little Women is that I am inclined to dislike the main character with all of her haughtiness and supposed literary talent. It is hard for me to like her and I was overwhelmed with joy when the great Katharine Hepburn molded her into an immature, flawed young woman who still has a great zest for life and love for her sisters. In this film I found March intolerable as Ronan's portrayal wavered between second rate Hepburn impression and overly mannered but emotionally cold line delivery. There were points in the film where it seemed that she was just reciting her lines in a monotonous tone and at moments that should have been greatly impactful the audience has a muted response. Her scenes with Pugh in particular should have an undercurrent of hatred between two sisters who are rivals but Ronan will toss off lines that should be cutting in a casual tone and has that amused little half grin on her face. All of the elements of the character that I dislike are played up in this performance with March's arrogance and superiority being present throughout while her better qualities such as her passion for the arts not being projected as well by Ronan. 

Another issue with the film is that while I did not want to be in the presence of March the rest of the characters in the film did not hold my interest. Amy is set up as the major supporting character and her conflict with her sister and romance with Laurence should be captivating and present us with a different perspective on womanhood. Unfortunately Amy is saddled with most of the feminist rhetoric and while I am a proud feminist myself I would like the theme of feminism to be presented in films without feeling that I am hit over the head with it. The scenes in which Amy expresses her opinions on the position of women in society felt preachy and lacked form as Pugh is left to angrily shout about her lack of financial means and dislike of the controlling men around her. I half expected her to start talking about "intersectional feminism" with how modern all of her speech was and I felt like I was watching a TED talk or listening to an article from Ms. Magazine read aloud. Gerwig did not fold the rhetoric about this important topic into the film successfully and that is a shame because it is rare that a film that centers female characters like this gets so much recognition. I would have preferred to see the sisters represent their feminism in more subtle ways and to have scenes devoted to the issue that feature dialogue that sounds natural and not overly written.

I went with my mom and sister, and at the end all of us were equally confused. My mom's first comment was "well, that was a disappointment" and that about sums it up. 

I love the book Little Women (although have always been partial to Little Men). And I'm always cautious about movies based on books, since they invariably do something that veers wildly from the expected plot. 

This time, at least I went in knowing that that had been part of the point of this production (although I didn't know *how* until I saw it). 

I have four main problems with the movie. 

1. The time jumping was really hard to follow (minus the short period of time where Jo had short hair). I spent what felt like half the movie (or half of every scene) trying to figure out when it took place. 

2. Everyone looked the same the whole movie. No one aged. Even though it takes place over a course of 7 years. Seven years where Amy is now 20, which means the earliest scenes show her as 13. Show me one 20 year old who looked the exact same at 20. 

3. The end didn't make sense. Jo is stating one thing for her book, but possibly choosing a different tack in her life? Or is the movie we've been seeing actually supposed to be the book that she was writing? It's not clear. If she's writing their story, does she feel her character needs a different outcome than what she wants? And she and Frederik spent no time together. Their relationship was just odd. 

4. For some reason Gerwig decided to have Beth live much longer and in the end it made her death have a lot less impact on the story and characters. Which felt overly emphasized by the fact that once Amy finds out and is (supposedly) upset and grieving and in a rush to get home, what does she do instead? She gets married. 

For bonus, randomly three characters speak directly to the camera at various points, for no reason. Breaking that fourth wall can be effective, IF THERE'S A REASON to. What the reason was here, I couldn't tell. 

All of that said, sure, there was some good dialogue moments. And there was some good acting. But those don't fix what was a fundamentally a difficult movie to follow where the choices just felt like someone was reaching to try to make their version standout and be "artsy" and less about telling the coherent solid story the book tells.

"Adorable women" Greta's new film is an epic epic, beautiful and playful that despite many setbacks and casualties always tries to keep up with hope and passion.

The script, which is based on a book that has already had other adaptations for the cinema tells the story of a quartet of sisters, their loves, difficulties and disagreements, never hiding the tragedy but always looking for the happy part, Greta introduces us the film with a sentence saying that it tells happy stories because it has lived many sad times, and that is a perfect allegory to the film and the metalanguage produced by him in the figure of the book of Job.

Each sister has her own personality that is intertwined between them, Jô is the sister who seeks independence and the different, the sister who does not accept the status of the situation and wants to change constantly, extroverted and charismatic the actress who lives Jô incorporates her character and gives a show apart, the young actress is the beating heart of the film, contrary to what Jô represents we have Amy, the most spoiled of sisters, who dreams and preaches the pattern, getting married and living a beautiful and artistic life, lived by florence who makes a wonderful performance, incorporating all the perks that her Amy lives for, plus a great performance for the young actress, we also have Meg who dreams of love and starting a family, lived by Emma Watson who is very well in the feature , and finally we have Beth, the youngest and most innocent of the sisters, and in turn the most perfect for not containing the evil and malice of the others.

Greta directs her film very smoothly, counting on an incredible artistic direction, with great hair, makeup, great costumes, her great direction is even a little lost among all this production, another highlight is also the great soundtrack and magnificent photography, which mixes different shades of colors between the narrative lines and the mood of the feature, these changes are small, but they are able to situate the viewer very well.

"Adorable women" It's a great film, a shame that came out in a year of so many great films, which ends up somewhat obscuring its prominence, but we have great performances and a beautiful story, we left the cinema happy and satisfied, knowing that we saw something pleasant, touching, an allegory to life very well acted and directed, with a beautiful artistic production. NOTE 9/10

Greta Gerwig's direction of Little Women, was in my opinion, was a little too grandiose for the narrative style conveyed in Alcott's novel. The linear narrative of the original story benefited little from the many flashbacks used to contrast the happy adolescences of the March sisters, to the more bleak early adulthood. Gerwig missed the opportunity to develop a more convincing relationship between Jo and Laurie as she quickly established that they were friends, and nothing else. It is obvious that the chemistry between both the actors exists, as evident in their wonderful partnership in Ladybird, but this previous success was too heavily leaned upon and fell flat. Yet, Gerwig had done a wonderful job in developing Amy, giving a more humanised depiction of her to which I enjoyed. Overall, this film has heart, the acting from the cast was fantastic and is an enjoyable watch, but can come off as confusing and rushed at times.

I found Little Women to be a wonderful revisitation of a beloved classic, with so much more depth of character than previous adaptations. The cinematography was entrancing and I loved how I felt like I could emphasize with the female leads. I think it truly brought to light many factors that I missed in the earlier movies, such as Amy's struggles and a further study of Jo's character. It did, at times, feel slightly rushed- but overall it was cohesive, largely owing to its familiarity. I want to see more movies like this, that lift me up and inspire me to do my best. Movies that give me, a seventeen-year-old girl, some semblance of hope in a world where fire drills can mean a school shooting and the statue of liberty no longer stands for equal opportunity. I appreciate the work and dedication that went into this production, from the ensnaring costuming to the delicate dialogue that simultaneously tore my heart in two and put it back together again. I come from a large family, so the ideals of hope, happiness, and support resonated with me and inspired me to try my best, even when I feel lost, to find joy and make the best of the world. To be strong and brave and to follow my passions. To adhere to my principles, to learn from my mistakes. It may sound flowery and verbose, and I doubt anyone will read this- or even care- but I felt an unrelenting need to share my thoughts. I want to thank the actors, in particular, the March sisters, for giving me this. 
I'm the oldest child in my family and I always aspired to be like Meg. But to see her struggle and her flaws and watch her and her sisters' journey through all that was so much more impactful. To witness lines such as the opening scene of the novel, directed in such a way that it did not feel like 'the perfect model family', sitting beside the fire and bettering themselves of their flaws in a way I could never hope to match- it felt like watching me and my sisters, while we tried to come to terms with not having as many presents as we would like on Christmas, though we all knew we were lucky to have anything at all. It felt like my family when I watched the March sisters tumbling on the floor and laughing and talking over one another. It felt like home. The story of this family has given me so much hope throughout my childhood, but this rendition surpassed anything I've gained before. I just wanted to say that, to anyone looking for light in the dark, I would suggest this. It is by no means a perfect film. But I think it is made better by its flaws. 
I've been away from my family for a long time, and when I miss them, I try to reflect on the time spent together. I try to enjoy the times when we are all together. And this movie encompasses that. It's a bildungsroman so similar to my own situation that I cannot help but feel like it's my lifeline. And perhaps this is just me. But I hope that this review will tell those who worked so hard to create this that it was not for naught. You've helped me.

I walked into the Classic Gateway Movie Theatre almost with a defiant attitude of "Show me!" as I have seen 3 versions, and read the book, of "Little Women". No way could anyone be prettier than Elizabeth Taylor in the 1949 version or Katherine Hepburn's strong, steadfast as Jo in the 1933 version or the realistic Jo of Winona Ryder in the 1994 film. After twenty minutes I was confused because the women we are seeing aren't 'little women', they are grown women.

This is the only way that the director/screenwriter Greta Gerwig missteps in both categories because at times it becomes confusing at moments--important moments, otherwise she has kept everything under control from the perfect cast to keeping all important parts of the book.

Most people reading this are familiar with "Little Women" either from previous movie versions or actually reading the classic book and if you aren't I don't want to spoil any of the film so on to the cast.

Saoirse Ronan, as Jo, projects a strong women of yesteryear and today and has scored her 4th Oscar nomination. Emma Watson as Meg, Eliza Scanlen as Beth and Florence Pugh, who won a best Oscar supporting actress nomination interact as sisters do while Laura Dern as their mother is warm, stern and her own woman. Meryl Streep is playing Maggie Smith's role from "Downton Abbey"!

Most of the men, except Timothee Chalamet who plays Laurie, and is prettier than Elizabeth Taylor or anyone in this film, captures the audience in a heartbreaking scene with Jo. Louis Garrel as a language professor in a few short scenes shows he can stand up to whatever is thrown at him. Chris Cooper, as Laurie's, grandfather, opens himself gradually until we get to know this intensely private human scene and Tracy Letts as Jo's first publisher  and James Norton as Meg's husband support the women. 

"Little Women" will take hold of you about 30 minutes into the film and hold on to you for the next 105 minutes.

Greta Gerwig takes a scalpel to an amazing piece of literature, inserts a bunch of bad fanfic, and throws the linear plot into a blender. Multiple contradictory statements included, along with one of the worst ensemble casts ever conceived.
