This film version of Little Women tells the classic story of four young sisters after the American Civil War of the 1860's. It is heartwarming and has great storytelling in the screenplay, adapted from the Louisa May Alcott book by director Greta Gerwig. I liked this take on the classic book made into a movie. All the scenes were so true to the time period and shot beautifully. The bond between the sisters seems genuine and deep.

During the Civil War, many husbands and young men go off to war, leaving their loved ones to struggle to survive. Scarlet fever is killing people rapidly. It seems people are either really wealthy or really poor. This family in the film comprises the mother and four sisters who are the "Little Women." They love, play, laugh and grow together. They deal with starvation, illness and love.  They pull together to help their neighbors in time of need.  You see the challenges they face of this time period, and they question the way things have been, facing issues such as marrying to help their family or marrying for love. Or whether to pursue a career or not. 

This film really takes us back to this time period, and we are able to get an understanding of the struggles of young women of those days. At first I didn't catch that the film was moving from past to present. The time switches made it a little hard for me to follow, but that did keep my attention as did the sets and costumes.

The actors did phenomenal work in their roles. I really felt the civil rivalry, love and bond between the siblings.  The main character in this film is the oldest sister, Jo March (Saoirse Ronan). She aspires to help her family and to be a writer, so she writes stories and submits them to a paper. She was great to watch in this role. The other sisters are Meg March (Emma Watson), Amy March (Florence Pugh), who loves to paint and draw and who looks up to her sister Jo, and Beth March (Eliza Scanlen). Aunt March (Meryl Streep) is a well-to-do, snooty widow. She is really funny, annoying and uses her money to her advantage.  

My favorite part of Little Women is when the man that works at the paper company wants Jo's book. He thinks he is smarter than she. 

Little Women is about young sisters growing up, facing life challenges, making mistakes and forgiving.  It really is good for all young ladies and women to see this film.

Last night I watched the newest alteration to Louisa May Alcott’s Little Women with the two (not so) little women in my life, my sisters. I haven’t read the book, nor watched the other film adaptations, aside from the 1994 Winona Ryder version. So this is my vague attempt to compare the two films since I haven’t seen Winona’s since my teens and didn’t pay attention. The biggest difference between the two films, and honestly it made Greta Gerwig’s special, was making the decision to tell the story in a non linear style. Jumping from the present to the past, successfully pairing the two.  Something as simple as Jo burning her dress in one scene in present time and then jumping to the past having her dress burned right before she meets Laurie. A touching pairing (spoiler) was when Jo nurses Beth back to health after getting Scarlet fever, juxtaposed with Jo’s attempt to nurse Beth one last time and failing. There isn’t a major attempt to show physical changes since both time lines are only 7 years apart so the director uses a summer hue for the past and a gray/blue winter tone for the present. This makes it real easy to follow. Another important factor is that they introduce a character like Friedrich earlier, so we aren’t left wondering why Jo ends up with a character that shows up in the second half of the story. There’s more to talk about but this is running a little long. This film is playing at Maya, and Edwards, take your daughters. It’s worth watching.

Not a remake, this fresh adaptation brings some of Allcott's own words from her letters into the text, bringing the sense that she was a woman ahead of her time, at least in her private thoughts, into the film text. Gerwig's adaptation is faithful, and brings with it a strong knowledge of film grammar, a logic different from chronological literary narrative, to create a film experience that is a cognitive as well as a visual treat. While details of production design, costuming and music are all close to perfection, it is the work of the central performers that impresses the most. If we can say it is a film where Streep's performance is the closest to caricature of all, we merely point out how stunning the women, most notably Saoirse Ronan, in fact are. The work of Dern and the actors portraying her daughters, is subtle and nuanced where the great work of Zellweger ('Judy') is conscious and hammy. There's no sense of 'look at me, I'm acting'. Their world becomes our world. The narrative is true to emotion and the human condition, and has a validity that makes it more universal than the more male-centred cinema dominating awards conversations. This adaptation, this film, will, I think, outlive those ephemeral award winners.

Overall, I throughly enjoyed this film. Gerwig is two for two with her films, and I cannot wait to see what she does next.

This movie made me think of a sort of picturesque portrait; you know, the ones of persons and places, where the colors and lines can leap off the surface, the interweaving strokes and details responding to each other with such intimacy that you can almost hear the polyphony of feelings and thoughts that ushered it into being......Okay, maybe that sounds a bit pretentious, but my point is this: the film reminds me of a moment when a piece of art utterly, inexplicably captures a person, quietly igniting an unexpected connection, perhaps acting to comfort or calm, or provide an answer to an unspoken question, or unveil a deeper sense of perception that even this person didn't know he/she possessed. This movie feels like that special piece of art. It's a story, a poem, a painting, a sculpture, a play, a song, an expression, a perception,...a beautifully written and poetically communicated orchestration of feelings and thoughts, lovingly taking hold without you even realizing it. Superb...simply superb.

Greta Gerwig's "Little Women" is a smart, heartwarming and moving adaptation of the beloved literary classic. With her latest feature, writer/director Greta Gerwig has crafted an astonishing adaptation of a beloved book. Using a finely tuned script and excellent ensemble cast, Gerwig captures the essence of Louisa Mary Alcott's timeless story. It is the director's first stab at creating a period piece set in the 1800's, but she pulls it off effortlessly. Through gorgeous production design, Gerwig draws viewers into the lives of the March sisters. The sets, costumes and musical score are pitch-perfect, capturing the time period accurately. In terms of acting, the entire ensemble is at the top of its game. Saoirse Ronan delivers her finest performance to date as Jo March. Strong, charming and resilient, she captures the free spirit of the iconic character. The supporting cast, which includes the fantastic Florence Pugh, is also worthy of recognition. Although "Little Women" is incredibly well-made, ultimately it is not a film without flaws. At nearly two and a half hours, it is slightly long and suffers from a lengthy running-time. Moreover, it's non-linear narrative has sudden time jumps that may be confusing for viewers that haven't read the book. Nevertheless, fans of the beloved book will definitely enjoy "Little Women" and so will movie-goers seeking heartwarming entertainment. At a time when female-led films are a rarity in Hollywood, it's reassuring to be reminded that movies like "Little Women" are still getting made.

Little Women is a totally delightful film, but this is probably doing it a disservice. It is so much more than that. But from the start it is certainly a delight, it's very charming and crafted with extreme care. You could wonder if we really do need another remake of Little Women as the much loved novel has been adapted many times. And quite possibly we honestly don't need another one. But this film is so well directed and written and acted that I am very happy that it exists. Plus I have never read the book or seen previous film versions so for me it was a fresh slate. For those that don't know the film is set in late 19th century Massachusetts. Told in two parts, the first part deals with the March family. Primarily a mother and her four daughters as the father is away fighting in the Civil War. They are not well to do and we meet four women of totally different personalities who have dreams of a larger life. The most prominent daughter being Jo, who wants to be a writer. The second part takes place 7 years later as we see how life has treated the family. Some good, some bad. The unique part of this film is that the two sections are not handled chronologically. We jump back and forth in the timeline. It's a fresh approach and I think adds extra weight to the drama. In just her second film Greta Gerwig shows she is a film maker of remarkable talent. She frames the film beautifully and the writing is spot on. Production design is exemplary too and the film truly glows with a wonderful spirit and charm. Plus the topic of women trying to make a mark in the world is more relevant than ever. The struggles they face is still certainly timely. This is especially the case in the free spirit of Jo, the true centre of the film. She is played by the superb Saoirse Ronan, surely one of the greatest acting talents of this era. Also wonderful are Florence Pugh and Timothee Chalamet who also shine in their roles. This is a film to enjoy on many levels. It's a joy to watch but it also has sad moments and moments of good humour. A film that is good for the head and the heart.

When I think of Katharine Hepburn's Jo, in George Cukor's delectable "Little Women" of 1933, what I remember is not her chatter, as raucous as a raven, but her impromptu fencing match in a drawing room, or the galumphing (moving in a clumsy, ponderous, or noisy manner; inelegant) rumpus she makes when, at her mother's call, she clatters down the stairs.

Ronan is less loud than Hepburn, but she has inherited some of her hustle and bustle, and anyone who admired Ronan in the title role of Gerwig's "Lady Bird" (2017) will note a similar fixity of purpose in her portrayal of Jo. Katharine Hepburn is a very hard act to follow but Ronan exudes the role brilliantly.

In the latest film, Amy is played by Florence Pugh, whose star, from "Lady Macbeth" (2016) to "Midsommar" (2019), has continued to rocket. (Next spring, she will battle through "Black Widow," as Scarlett Johansson's sister. A slight change of tone from the Marches.) Pugh is twenty-three but seems older, with her frightening poise and the pass-me-a-smoke throatiness of her voice, and while the innocence of Amy, equipped with long blond braids, is a stretch for her, the willful tenacity presents no problem. Florence Pugh's Oscar-nominated portrayal of Amy March was a stand-out. Her performance is tremendous.

The other actors who complete the March quartet--Emma Watson as Meg, and Eliza Scanlen as the vulnerable Beth are perfectly cast. Both were women are superb in their roles.

Laura Dern, who plays Marmee and Meryl Streep as Aunt March, Laurie (Timothée Chalamet),and his sad grandfather (Chris Cooper), Professor Bhaer (Louis Garrel) round out the notable ensemble.

Gerwig's adaptation is not chronological: to and fro she darts across the years, chopping the plot into flashbacks and flash-forwards, and keeping us on our toes. Gerwig isn't afraid to let her audience work a little. She trusts our intelligence and our curiosity, and also her own command of the medium. It kept the story fresh and I applaud her storytelling. Brava Greta !

Little Women is made with so much heart, love and enthusiasm both behind and in front of the camera that even the deeply sad scenes still fill you with joy and longing. It's an explosion of emotions, from loss to love to everything in between. Gerwig's smart, delightful film seems on its way to becoming a classic.

Director: Greta Gerwig Writers: Greta Gerwig, Louisa May Alcott (based on the novel by) Starring: Abby Quinn, Bob Odenkirk, Chris Cooper, Eliza Scanlen, Emma Watson, Florence Pugh, James Norton, Jayne Houdyshell, Laura Dern, Louis Garrel, Meryl Streep, Saoirse Ronan, Timoth, Tracy Letts 10/10
 Nominated for six Academy Awards including best picture.

Sophomore slumps are a dime o' dozen these days for writer/directors (i.e. "Us" & "Midsommar," in my opinion) but with her adaptation of "Little Women," Greta Gerwig looks to power through the mediocrity and -- most importantly -- keep the audience on their proverbial toes with something quite different from what was offered an entry ago. This is a sumptuously designed, beautiful-looking saga of love, possibility and the yearning for what could have been, featuring some standout performances from nearly every cast member (though high praise goes to Saoirse Ronan, Florence Pugh and Timothee Chalamet, in particular) and a truly winsome screenplay and vision from Gerwig herself. Tender, yet pleasant, sad, but still joyous, and challenging and crowd-pleasing all at once, this is most definitely one of the best of the calendar year that was 2019, and yet another reason why Greta Gerwig is one to look out for in terms of burgeoning filmic talents.

I'm automatically attached to the 1994 version of Little Women because of Winona Ryder but in general...fantastic version of the movie. The new 2019 one that's in theaters...well let me tell you. We have the character Amy being played by a TWENTY FOUR YEAR OLD ACTRESS....where in the book and 1994 version she is supposed to be TWELVE YEARS OLD. HOW DOES SOMEONE LOOK PAST THAT. I literally was sitting there laughing at this 24 year old women on the big screen, talk and act like a 12 year old little girl, it was absolutely ridiculous and ruined her character completely! Made me so angry.   Also, how in the world did this actor who played Laurie get the role? He literally looks like a 16 year old little boy. Horrible casting choice. Beth also doesn't have enough screen time in the movie to be the deeply spiritual and loving person she is in the house that she is in the 1994 movie and book. I didn't even cry when certain scenes with her happened. THAT SAYS A LOT. I brought Kleenex to the movies...for nothing. All four girls HAVE DIFFERENT HAIR COLOR. Did "Marmee" sleep with four different men? Like, at least make them all look alike. Beth had flaming red hair, Meg had dark brown almost black hair, Jo had dirty blonde and Amy was blonde...like really? Also, Orchard House (where they live) is also missing some meaning that was really profound in the book and 1994 version of the movie. All the girls look the exact same age which they're obviously not supposed to be, everything seemed to be so rushed. Some iconic lines that we're supposed to hear, are meshed with everyone else trying to talk at the same time. "Marmee" didn't seem like the caring, compassionate and devoted mother she is in the 1994 version aswell. So disappointing. The ONLY thing I like, was that they added a few more scenes in this movie that were actually in the book. Anyway, rant over

I liked this film quite a lot, but I didn't love it as much as many. I really respect and admire Greta Gerwig's auteurship, and think this was a nice re-telling of the story. I loved what she did with time, jumping back and forth, and knitting the various pieces together into a coherent and fresh take. It was a more interesting presentation of this well-trod tale, rather than just telling it in a linear fashion. Lots of other good things about it, too. But, I spent the first half of the film sulking a bit, realizing that I'm probably prejudiced against the source material. American literature from the 19th century, be it Alcott, Twain, Hawthorne, or any of their lot, has always been my least favorite genre, even though the single best teacher I've ever had was for junior year high school English which was American literature and while she set me on the path of thinking critically and expressing myself with words, even she couldn't get me to love most classic American novels. Don't let my lukewarm review or dyspeptic demeanor dissuade you; I definitely recommend seeing it if you're a fan of the story or any of the cast. It's an empowering tale told well.

Although we have long LOVED the book, play and 1994 movie revival (and others), my teenage daughter and I were both sorely disappointed in the 2019 movie revival, for several (unanimous) reasons: 1) The 2019 screenplay changed the story's timeline of how events unfolded, in ways that compromised cherished dramatic tensions...I'm not referring to the flashback storytelling method, which had merit; but to the actual sequence of events in the story being told. 2) While each actor was superb in their craft, the sister characters were written with less clear distinction between them, and with the characters of Meg and Beth appearing less firmly committed to their distinctive life choices. 3) The decision to cast one actress to play BOTH the younger AND older Amy resulted in an unbelievable rendition of the younger Amy character.

I'll try to keep this vague so as to not spoil it too badly for those unfamiliar with the story. I love the book Little Women and have mostly enjoyed film adaptations of it. This adaptation was both unneccessary and disappointing. It seems like a vanity project. The acting was good, as was the look of the film, but the so much of the story's charm was lost by the flashback nature of the narrative. Even for someone familiar with the story, it was hard to follow and frustrating. I left the theatre very upset by what had been done to a beloved story. The only thing I really liked was that Amy's romance, which always seems like an afterthought, got a great deal of focus. Beyond that, it was painful. Meg's romance seemed one-dimensional and Jo's romance was rendered practically ridiculous. The flashbacks made it hard to tell, but she seemed to barely speak to her love interest before reaching an absolutely horrendous scene (it made me cringe) where everyone told her she loved him and then she chased him down at the train station. The character of Jo was further diminished by the way she dealt with her loneliness at one point. I also felt that Laurie's grandfather was misrepresented as if he had been sitting at home waiting to be invited to join in the jolly antics next door. His character, although more of a background character, has a more complex journey than that. To me the absolute travesty of this film was the casting of the actor to play Laurie (aka Teddy). This was a huge mistep. I didn't like him from the start, but could accept him when Laurie was a teen, but when Laurie was a grown man in his mid-twenties, both when living wildly and when taking responsibility, it was abasolutely impossible to take his character seriously when he still looked 13. I'm not sure that there are enough words to decribe how much I disliked this adaptation of Little Women.

All of the actors and actresses in this movie have all played much better roles in the past, even if they do still do a good job (preferably Sersha Roman). I haven't read the book myself, but everything they did regarding the book's plot I think was done well, from what I've heard. The pacing is also exceptable, but it doesn't make the movie more interesting. What this movie really needs is something to make it stand on it's own, but I just couldn't find that in this movie, and I'm sure I'll forget about it fairly soon.

I did not like this screen play. It went back and forth between the present and past to the extent that it caused not a little confusion.  Do we really have to try and figure out in what tense things are happening?  And,  I'm really getting sick of being preached to about women's rights and portraying women in power roles.  I want to be entertained and not have someone's message thrown at me.  Really, Hollywood, I resent you trying to be everyone's moral compass, especially when most of you are lacking any.  This was the poorest version of this beloved work and I've seen them all.  I think it's time to put it back on the shelf.
Good cast.  Enjoyed the mixing of the time line.
Cinematic excellence.

It was a good interpretation, but the casting for Amy was very difficult to tolerate. The scenes where she is 13 were not believable since it was a grown woman playing her. Those scenes were like watching a high school play. But the rest was very enjoyable.
Took  a while to gel, but ultimately a strong film with great, impactful performances. The collage storytelling was effective.
Amazing story line. Created a great backdrop to woman and how they were viewed as nothing without a man in their lives. Strong woman figures that were able to grow despite the times.
Beautiful to see, and the family relationships were appealing and plausible.  Portrait of a period.
At first, I felt like walking out but I stayed thru the end and I am glad I did! The message was loud and clear! We must believe in ourselves and follow our dreams!
I did not like Hollywood putting its spin on Jane Austens story. The sets were beautiful and so were the costumes. The story left me insettled.
Fantastic movie. Surpassed my expectations. Acting was phenomenal. Can’t wait to see it again.
Fantastic film. I loved the non linear storytelling.

Great acting and a gripping story of the challenges and joys of growing up with your sisters.  I read this book to my daughter when she was little and we both went to see the movie together 45 years later.  Great experience!

it was heart warning, growing up with three sisters it brought back memories

I loved Little Women. The performances were outstanding and the wardrobe was exceptional. Ronan's, the actress who played Joanna, performance, in particular, was very real and moving. The way the focus moved around was a little confusing at first but then I came to understand the time changes and appreciated how they improved the story being told. The plot did stay true to the book and the emotions of the characters' felt real and relatable, despite the large time difference. It was overall an amazing movie and I would definitely see it again.
The movie left me feeling good and smiling. The actors, Male & female, were outstanding. l loved it.
I'm a traditionalist so interpreting the novel doesn't fly with me. There were a few digressions from Alcott's work. I did love the casting, however!

Little Women was my favorite book as a child/teen. I read it many times. I saw all the other movies... this one was beautiful - costumes, cinematography, etc... I didn’t love it though.  This movie made such small story changes that they were barely detectable but they actually really changed the feel... I think it was trying to be relevant and empowering in today’s modern world but it ended up making the movie less authentic and in my opinion changing the movie entirely.  Not my favorite adaptaron... wish they would have stuck with the original script/book.
Interesting adaptation. Full of life. Excellent acting. Hard to follow if one did not read the book.
I liked the idea of putting Jo as the "author"  I got a little confused with the flashbacks sometimes: And I was a little confused at the beginning, until things got rolling.

was pleasantly surprised how good of a movie it was. excellent performance all around.

This movie was sooo good....I really enjoyed it....I found it a little confusing going backwards(when the girls were smaller) and forward to NOW time, but figured it out....would like to see it again...now that I know what to expect....Have FUN!!!!!

This was one of the best movie adaptations of books I have ever seen. Between the great and beautiful set and costume design, great cast, and the not too boring or repetitive score, there is absolutely no way anyone could call this movie bad in any way. Out f all 3 of the little women movie adaptations, this is by far the best. I strongly recommend this movie to everyone whether they have read the book, or not.

Thanks to the rewrite on this classic I ended up hating Jo and Amy. This new version bounces back and forth in time and it appears confusing and poorly done. It's also a very long drawn out movie and the best part was that it finally ended. The actor who played Amy would be better suited for a role as prisoner in a bad gang movie. Don't waste your money. rewatch the original or the other remakes. This one will actually make you hate this once loved classic

Though I was skeptical at first, to see a piece from my childhood portrayed on the big screen, I cannot express enough how much I enjoyed this movie. This is an inspiring and elegant interpretation of a timeless story; it is truly a delight to see such an exquisite work portrayed in modern cinema. 
Every detail is kept in mind in this beautiful depiction of a classic piece of American literature. The richness and depth of this charming adaptation Louisa May Alcott's famous novel will capture the audience from the first frame to the last. This film showcases the raw struggles of family, loss, and love in the most human way. 
The actors do an excellent performance at bringing their characters to life while keeping them as authentic as possible. The characters become so human and so powerful, and the audience truly feels they are part of the March family.
 "Little Women"  is a must-watch for movie enthusiasts of all ages.
Wonderful!! Very well done!! Enjoyed it tremendously!!
Choppy plot line. Too many back and forthwith between current and the past. Too bad. Beautiful Performances and realistic recreation of the time period. The editor should be shot! Incoherent movie.
Just give Florence Pugh an Oscar right now. Thank you.
Very hard to follow the time line. Movie was beautifully filed and acting was terrific.
It was great... such a wonderful story & the cast did a wonderful job.

I'm sure we would have enjoyed the film if we had been able to stay but that was impossible.

Very disappointing. The fact that this movie scored so high with both critics and audiences just goes to show the terrible state of modern-day cinema. The time-travel storytelling style was completely disorienting and guts the narrative of its emotional weight. More than anything, Greta Gerwig's re-imagining of the story to reflect her modern feminist attitude fails to deliver the core themes from the book. I gave it two stars because there are a lot of films out today that are worse than this one.

Greta Gerwig has fashioned a fresh adaptation of the Alcott novel. It's been-there, done-that for the overall story, but new viewers unfamiliar with the characters and story will be riveted. And the ensemble is brilliant together.

Possibly the best version of the Alcott novel I've ever seen, and I've seen most, if not all of them. The casting was brilliant, the cinematography gorgeous. Greta Garwig did a brilliant job with the script and as director. Touching, beautiful, exciting, moving. Excellent movie.

Excellent rhythm from beginning to the end. No scene felt boring and there was both humour and drama. The four actresses are all brilliant but Ronan and Pugh really kill it. The time-jumping was well managed and subtle, relying more on colour grading and on-screen details rather than text cards. Gerwig is really gaining steam as a major filmmaker with this movie. There are no big grievances to speak of. Excited for more from her ! (As a frenchman, I must also mention my talented compatriots in this movie, Garrel, Chalamet and Desplat)

Being one of four sisters, Little Women has always been one of my favorite books/movies. This new movie based on the cherished novel was a work of art. The way the director wove the tapestry of their lives in and out of past and present was absolutely beautiful. My daughter and I took my mom to see it last night and we all loved it. It is in my top 10 favorite movies of all time:)

'Little Women' is a great film filled with wonderful performances (especially Pugh and Ronan), a well-written, heartfelt script and an extremely solid direction from Greta Gerwig. With a smart retelling that takes some of the novel's themes and spin it to aim at more modern preoccupations, 'Little Women' accomplishes its main goal : a remake that justifies its existence, and even more.
Great cast, imaginative retelling of this classic. Appreciated the open discussion of the status of women and the unconventional timeline. Laura Dern is amazing as always!
Fantastic in every sense. Its one of the best movies that I have seen in a very long time.
I didn't love the cast (although Emma and Saoirse are good) or how the timeline jumped around. I LOVE the 1994 version and found it impossible not to compare the two.
I really liked the storyline and the actors and actresses conveyed their emotions very well.

Theres so much care taken in every aspect of the set, costumes, props, characters, etc. Greta Gerwig truly made a masterpiece that relies on memory and emotion to bring fundamental truths about humanity to the audience. A must-watch for anyone.

Beautifully shot with strong acting but ... the time shifting / dream sequence is way more trouble than it's worth.  It's a stretch to offer the four Little Women convincingly as their younger selves, and the lack of physical demarcation between 'then' and 'now' makes scenes difficult to place in context.  I thought the movie was exquisite visually, but so-so as a story.  As a result, I'm not quite so apoplectic if Ms. Gerwig gets a pass in Best Director nominations this year.

A beautiful tale of family, love and career in times of war and illness. The characters are unique and refreshing. The quality of differentiation of the ages was great. And the plot is heartwarming. The star cast are well-suited for their roles. Must see!

The only awkward parts IMO were the scenes where Amy is younger and her voice is SO deep. She was terribly miscast.. just didn’t like her at all. But, I guess I never cared for her character as well. I didn’t think I would like Emma Watson in her role, but I think she did a good job. Not anything to write home about. I wish they had also given us more time w/ Beth because her death almost felt like an after note and was not as impactful.

With the exception of Laurie's character, all of the actors gave great performances. My chief complaint lays with the direction/cut of the film. Sometimes moving back and forth in time can be employed effectively to make a point. When it is overused, it becomes confusing. Essentially, the story become muddled and the plot fizzled. Watch the previous version. One further point—all of these rave reviews are completely unfounded. The 1994 version is vastly better in many ways. Rent and watch. Make your own comparison.

I'm shocked to learn I'm one of the who people who found this movie impossible to sit through. The beauty of the story is that the feminist narrative is natural, and is evident through plot and character but Gerwig is more concerned with over the top speeches and declarations. Anyone who has read and loved Alcott's novel should be severely disappointed with the very shallow character development, and confusing stop-start storyline. Despite the star studded cast, a number of whom I think are brilliantly talented in other movies, not a single actor impressed me in this. Saoirse Ronan was tolerable, but chalamet was a disaster, as was Pugh and *gulp* even meryl Streep. After the Winona Ryder/Christian bale version this was an unwatchable let down.

Enjoyed it but did not love it. Felt some of characters were miscast. Actor  playing Lorie looked too young for the part. He did not look like a romantic suitor for Jo. There was no real chemistry with him and Amy either. Relationship with Any was not developed enough to suddenly blossom into a romantic one.   Actress playing Amy looked too old to play Amy when a child. . Especially with that deep mature voice. Even actress playing Beth did not encompass the shy introverted Beth in the book. As much as I very much like the actress playing Meg, she did not come off as the older, more mature sister. In fact they all seemed to be the same age. Also did not love the new twist that Meg as a Mother is not happy with her less than easy life with her husband due to finances.  It seemed mismatched with who Meg was and the expectation of women in the day. 

Also felt the movie was disjointed and more difficult to follow since the director kept moving between the women as adults and then flashing back as younger girls. They always looked the same age. At times hair style or length of hair was the only way to be sure what year the scene took place. There was not enough to delineate time periods. For younger audiences especially it could be hard to follow. 

Felt Jos relationship with the professor is not clear at the end due to her discussion with the publisher regarding the ending of the book she wrote. At one point she says Jos heroine does not marry Lorie or the Professor at the end of her somewhat autobiographical book because her heroine  kept saying she would never marry. In fact, Jo said the same through out the movie. Yet, we are lead to believe she ends up with the professor. This was a scene the director added, but I felt it did not imply what the director hoped it would that Jo did not allow her heroine to cave to the mores of the day where women were meant to marry. In reality, Louise May Alcott never did marry. It might have made sense if her Little Women ended with Jo single as the author was, but in the movie it did not make sense to try to support this singles lifestyle when in fact Jo ends up with the professor or so we are lead to believe.  It was confusing.

In general, when dealing with a classic it is difficult to make changes that do not fit with the basis of the original or the time period it was written. To modernize it changes the story. Jo does not think she will ever marry not because she is pushing a feminism viewpoint  but rather more because she feels introducing others to the family, namely spouses, threatens the closeness she has with her sisters and family. She fears losing these people she feels so much for.  She wants to hold on to what she knows and does not want change. As she matures into an adult and expands her world and experiences true love, she realizes she will never lose the love or relationships she has with her family and in fact adding others to the family only enriches it and life.  
This is the basis of the book to me. It is about family, relationships and growing up. It really was not about womens rights. I understand why the director chose in this day and age to update the story line to address the suppression of women, and normally I might agree it was a clever addition. But in this case, I feel it clouds the point of the book and changes a classic read.

While the story is not preachy, this is a scathing indictment of American maltreatment of women around the Civil War. But the story is much richer than that, posing a tapestry of American life, of families, siblings (both love and rivalry), of love and war, of rich and poor, of sense and sensibility, of darn near everything. Alcott and Gerwig have a real American masterpiece here, and the superb acting includes Saoirse, Dern, Pugh, Chalamet, Cooper, Watson, Letts and Streep. It's even set in Concord, Mass., to emphasize it is a bigger American story than four girls growing up -- yes, that Corncord, which with Lexington are in the history books as the flashpoint that started our 18th-century revolution. Even the title is  based on an affectionate name a father at war has for his four daughters, Little Women. But it also means an American era in which all Women were of Little value -- no vote, no property, no rights over their own children, few jobs, etc. It was actually breathtaking how much the central character, Jo, was taken by the throat by Saoirse and dominated the whole movie, not by force, but by her personality, spunkiness, humanity and determination -- and willingness to suffer for the path she chose, while vulnerable to struggle with romance and loneliness, too. Bravo. If not the  best movie of the year, it's darn close. And the love for offspring and people embodied by Laura was palpable, even visceral. I happened upon the 1995 version on TV, and while the cast was impressive as Winona Ryder was Jo, Susan Sarandon was Marmie, Christian Bale was Laurie, Eric Stoltz was the penniless teacher who married Meg, Trini Alvarado, Claire Danes was the pitiful Beth whose music could not keep her alive, and Amy was played young and old by Kirsten Dunst and  Samantha Mathis, and Gabriel Byrne played Jo's final love interest as a German prof, not French, I'm afraid it can't hold a candle to this one. Saoirse as Jo represents a kind of every American girl who longs and works to become an everywoman who charts her own course based on her aptitude, ability and skill and is not hampered by an oppressive society and culture that trivializes, even infantalizes, women. It's a hundred years since women got the vote, but I think that they'd tell you today that while they've come a long way, baby, they haven't come all the way, even in 2020, making this story not just relevant but also timely, though set 160 years ago.

Greta Gerwig's take on Louisa May Alcott's classic book is a beautiful heart-warming tale about Jo March's ambition to become a published author, but also about the domestic lives of herself and those close to her. 

The screenplay for this film is incredibly well written by Greta Gerwig, with the concept of having a non-chronological storyline really blooming for the promise of the themes and storylines in this film. An example of this was Amy's chat with Laurie about why she's giving up art was directly followed up with her talk with Aunt March years earlier about how she is the only hope left to be the economic back bone of her family, a true stroke of genius from Gerwig. However, during the film it did at times become unclear as to whether the scene is taking place before or after the last scene and roughly how long before or after which makes you think about how the story is working rather than letting yourself delve into the blissful world of the story.

As with great direction, comes great editing. Nick Houy does an excellent job assisting Gerwig in letting the different complex emotions and atmospheres of the scenes seemingly flow into another. However there were moments of sloppiness. In the first Christmas breakfast scene there is an abrupt change in atmosphere and the audience can tell two shots were acquired from different takes, rather than making it seem like it was one take, which often isn't the case in cinema, but is the goal to edit it to make it look like it is. Though that could be claimed as nit picking, as it is really, however the scene between Amy and Laurie where Laurie is wearing a green scarf is anything but. His scarf seems to magically change knots when the camera goes back to him. This lack of care to detail in continuity by both Houy and Chalamet takes you out of otherwise a beautiful scene.

Alexandre Desplat does an incredible job of creating a beautiful score that perfectly weaves into the scene it's used in and it accentuates atmospheres/emotions in a scene, or in the case of the two Beth Christmas breakfast scenes, harsh contrast to really get the most out of the performances given by the cast. Yorick Le Saux does a sublime of capturing the action between the frame lines, with each image of the countryside looking blissful, the use of vibrant colours contrasting with dull colour palates also beautifully creates the atmosphere, credit here also goes to Nick Houy and the set designer, Jess Gonchor, who created incredible locations for the shoot making it seem like we were actually in the 19th century.

The acting in this film was overall really solid, with Meryl Streep (Aunt March) putting in a good performance as you expect of her to do. Saoirse Ronan (Jo March) puts in a flawless performance creating a person of flesh and blood that the audience can invest into. An actress that may get looked over in this film is Laura Hern (Marmee March) who also puts in an incredible performance as a caring mother who has to paint herself as braver and better than she is for her children. Emma Watson (Meg March) also puts in a really good performance in this film, creating some beautifully heart-warming, and sometimes heart-breaking scenes with her incredible nuanced work with James Norton (John Brooke).

Overall, Gerwig's take on 'Little Women' is a tale of female identity and how companionship is a help to us rather than a hinderance as it may seem. This film will make you laugh with the characters and cry for them, this is easily the best film released at Christmas time within the last decade.

For me, the 1994 version of Little Women is peak perfection. Thus, I had super high expectations for this latest take, but tempered my excitement. In the end, while I really enjoy a lot of the cast and aspects of Gerwigs version, I didn't feel like I wanted to re-watch it again and again. 

Amy's scenes stole the show, as did Aunt March (I mean, c'mon. It's Meryl). As great as Saoirse Ronan was as Jo, Amy's character was just a lot more dynamic and surprising in this version. Chalamet measured up very well to Christian Bale's performance. Laura Dern as Marmee was a big misfire. She was too bubbly compared to the serious-natured and wise Marmee from the book. Beth's drawn out death/memory scenes were a little watered down. There was no tear-jerking speech goodbye from her.  And Poor Emma Watson really got the shaft. Meg was so bland and forgettable.  

Finally, Bob Odenkirk as papa.... it was a distraction. When he came on the screen, is when I finally told myself this version just isn't as good.  That said, worth watching, but I doubt I'll see it again.

Greta Gerwig's ‘Little Women' runs for 2 hours and 15 minutes, but when you're sitting there taking in all the beautiful costumes, music, styling, acting by the incredible cast, you'll feel sad when the credits arrive.  Ronan and Chalamet are SO charming, as expected, but all of the interwoven storylines just hit so hard emotionally, the theater was filled with (mostly women) of all ages, including my 9 year old daughter and I, all of whom had piles of soggy tissues. The script felt quick and lively and held attention throughout, its been 30 years since I've read the novel and yet I still felt like it was a story I'd never heard because the acting and characters were so compelling they drew me into the world onscreen. Can't recommend enough, and bonus points for bringing some male company with you! This is a universal love story about family and independence, it deserves to be seen by all.

In fact, it is a colourful film, shot in two different time zones which gradually come together.  The light changes with the mood and brings the audience in so you feel as though you are one of them.
The film is portrayed so wonderfully by all the actors - I was going to start listing their names but really, they are all incredible.  This must also have a lot to do with the direction which was clearly excellent.

While I love the story of Little Women, this adaptation left me quite disappointed. The casting of Meg, Jo, Beth, and Amy by actresses that all looked like they could be the exact same age (I know much earlier adaptations of Little Women have historically done this too, but this is one area where the 1994 version really excelled), with no real age progression in their appearance from when they were young to their adult selves, was in my mind a poor decision. Amy especially is supposed to be such a young child! Also, the constant flashing back and forth damaged the potency and power of Alcott's narrative and was at times confusing. Not to mention the ending, which was cheesier than I felt it should be. Additionally I found the random direct talking to the camera towards the end to be distracting and inconsistent - it felt like an amateur, unnecessary move. I wanted to love this version, as I greatly admire many of the actresses, but it just felt wrong from start to finish.

This movie missed the mark for me. By chopping up the events of Little Women and displaying them out of chronological order, the movie lost what makes the story fantastic- the character development and relationships between characters. It really emphasized the "what" versus the "why".

*Spoilers*



 I'll break this down by character:
Jo: Saoirse Ronan did a fine job. Her best scenes and acting were in the trailer. I did love that she hits Laurie frequently, it was fitting of the character.
Meg: Every scene she is in is about her clothing choices. It made no sense because John Brooke is in the film a ton and they discuss him a ton, but never show their romance in any way.
Beth: I didn't even get choked up when she died because they don't portray her as a painfully shy and compassionate, so she's got no character traits and is utterly forgettable.
Amy: Horrible casting. She's a full grown woman with a super deep voice playing a 12 year old. She also conveys zero emotion in her scenes, despite getting a huge chunk of the movie dedicated to her. She also seems to lack any traits other than "artist".
Laurie: Timothee Chalamet is probably the best Laurie I've seen despite the terrible screenplay. He definitely shows what a philanderer Laurie is. Unfortunately, it starts in the second scene before we even have a chance to fall in love with the character. Also, it's hard to believe he is madly in love with Jo when all of his scenes are pretty much with Amy. Jo and Laurie seem like barely more than acquaintances.
Frederich Behr: Dude doesn't say anything the whole movie except that he doesn't like Jo's writing and then somehow Jo is magically in love with him.
Marmie: Has almost no scenes and doesn't come off as having any notable characteristics. She sobs after Beth dies but they mute it and cue the music, thus effectively destroying the one chance Laura Dern has to convey emotion.
Aunt March: Meryl Streep stole the show in her 4 scenes. Well done. She manages to show the character's personality and motives with just a few minutes of screentime.
Grandpa Lawrence: This guy should have had way more screen time, he did a great job.
Mr. March: I don't even know why they bothered putting him in the movie.

And there you have it... The character driven movie's terrible character development and character relationships. How is this getting rave reviews? Watch the 1994 version. It's amazing.

The deconstruction of this story is an interesting perspective to take. It truly does break down something that is so familiar and injects a different POV to it. Instead of the main focus being the 4 sisters, we have the journey of Jo March to ultimately writing this story and truly being herself. I appreciate how each sister gets a moment of focus, almost like their own chapter of the story. 

The way this is played, you really do see the growth of everyone's characters. I appreciate how the relationships all make sense and characters like Meg March are much clearer and well-formed in the story. Florence Pugh does an exceptional job of taking one of the most controversial characters in literature, Amy March, and making her much more three-dimensional and understood. There are some things that are inescapable, but at least I don't leave despising Amy (like I usually do). Timothee Chalomet is phenomenal as Laurie. He really does an exceptional job of making us understand WHY he loves Jo and how he could potentially move on to Amy. The Jo-Laurie-Amy problem still exists to some extent, but it is actually addressed and I think in a lesser actor & filmmaker's hands, it would be troubling. Saoirse and Timothee have such amazing chemistry, it is a perfect casting. 
Saoirse does an amazing job as Jo and even layers in some things I never even considered for the character. Overall, I think if you are a FAN of this work, you will love this. Those new to the story might get a little confused, but it is well worth watching no matter what.

Listen to the girls.  So this is the story of four sisters growing up together in a household.  One is a writer (Saoirse Ronan), and they say write what you know, so she's going to tell her story.  Now I've managed to go 33 years of my life without experiencing this story.  It wasn't by design, mind you, it simply wasn't on any of my reading lists in high school.  I've never seen any of the other six film adaptations, so even though this is a tale that is over 150 years old, it is still new to me.  I can't say that I generally connect with period pieces, but every so often there is an exception to the rule, and Little Women is most certainly that.  Now the two biggest reasons I adore this film as much as I do are the acting and the direction.  This is helmed from Greta Gerwig who previously directed Lady Bird, and she has only honed her craft since then.  She knows when to go into deep focus and knows when to pull back, and she should be a serious contender for Best Director this year, despite being snubbed at the Golden Globes.  She works well with her actors to get some fantastic performances, and there isn't a weak performance in the bunch.  These are subtle yet powerhouse performances delivered from an all-star cast, and I was very much enthralled from start to finish.  Every single one of these girls has a lot of personality, and even though you're jumping from sibling to sibling, you feel like you know each and every one of them.  I typically get on period pieces for being stuffy, but that is absolutely not the case here, and I think that has a lot to do with how the script was adapted.  Now that I'm critically thinking about this in retrospect, I don't really have any major complaints about this.  The story is told out of order, which I suppose may be confusing for some people, but I had no trouble following.  In fact, I think it actually works as a positive to make you feel the correct emotion in the flow of the narrative; you see exactly what you're supposed to see when you're supposed to see it, and because of that, Little Women ends up being emotionally successful.  I give this a big-time recommendation, and you should absolutely watch this.

I was only one of a half dozen men watching this film tonight. The reviews have been exceptional, and I was drawn to see what all the fuss was.Â

I finally decided to sit back and just enjoy the ride. The dialogue was a bit tiring, and having a group of girls all talking at once was distracting. What I did enjoy was the absolutely fantastic cinematography. Many scenes were akin to looking at Impressionist or Americana era paintings. Mind blowing.
The relationships with the sisters brought back memories of my girls growing up. Like the characters in the movie, my girls all had very distinct and strong personalities. I got a bit emotional at the right moments...insert small tear here.
I did enjoy the film like reading a good novel. Just ask my wife about how I wanted to read the ending before it was over.

In the 19th century, cocaine was very often added to drinks and "tonics" to provide extra vim-and-vigor to ladies and gentlemen. Coca-Cola? Cocaine! Well, in the 2019 production of "Little Women," Marmy March clearly bought 30 cases of Coca Tonic for those rascally girls! The fighting, punching, throwing, wrestling, kicking, screaming, running..... Lordy! World Wrestling Federation? Step aside.... for March Madness, 1864 style! The scenes cut and slice and jump and smother like the Rock sending the Undertaker over the ropes, then smashing him with a metal folding chair! Ladies and gentlemen.... you have not seen "Little Women" until you've seen "Little Women 2019.... live from the Olympic Auditorium in Los Angeles"! (Cage matches on Saturday nights.) OK, OK, OK.... about a third of the way through the film things settle down.... Freddie Blassie is replaced as Jo March by Saoirse Ronan.... the cocaine has worked its way through their systems.... the girls go to the beach. In all seriousness, though a shock to the system of one weaned on Martin Scorsese's gentle, elegant, poignant, thoughtful "Age of Innocence" (and I can assure you, 1870's Manhattan had NOTHING over 1870's Concord, Mass.), "Little Women 2019" is loads of fun and sentiment. The costumes and interiors are superb. The acting... a bit hyper....but yes, eventually made me misty eyed.... as it should. Go see it. And buy a 32 oz. cup of Coke before you enter the theater!
So well done. Every character is marvelously developed. Cinematography is on point. Lots of laughs and tears. Greta crushed it.

Very subversive for the late 1860s and the 1870s in more ways than it might appear at first glance.  Little Women (2019) is a well done piece of filmmaking. The casting is spot on, with our 4 March girls, being lead by Saoirse Ronan as Jo. I think Laura Dern as the mother, Marmee, is particularly affecting. The cinematography, art direction, and score all do a fine job transporting the viewer to a Concord Mass, New York, and Paris of the 19th century.  I have a few quibbles. The chief one is that the aging of the characters is sometimes weakly communicated. The films in an intercut set of sequences 7 years apart, and it feels to me as though the characters who are going from roughly 16 to 23 would transform more physically more than some hair styling.  The result is some moments of confusion when trying to figure out what time period a scene occurs in. There is an exception in the styling of Florence Pugh's Amy, who maturation from pig tails to married woman is very striking. I cannot quite put my finger on why the language and body moments seem anachronistic. Given that LW and Downton Abbey no doubt share a similar fan base and are separated by 55 years or so, they feel worlds apart with the Little Women seeming the more modern. Speaking of Downton, it struck me very early how each of these films executes a lovely romance dance on the veranda away from the hustle and bustle more conventional party goers, portraying the same "we are the outsiders" message.  Saying that Little Women is very good, but didn't blow me away seems like faint praise.

I absolutely loved the movie as a whole, but I thought that the character of Meg was not well written.  In our haste to admire Jo, love Beth, and (alternately) hate/admire Amy, we forget Meg, who although not as saintly as Beth, longs to have a family of her own.  In chastising her for succumbing to materialistic pleasures (the ball, the new fabric for a dress, etc), we forget that of the four sisters, Meg vividly remembers what it was to be rich.  We also forget that she went to school with girls like Belle Gardner--yet, she remains true to herself, and still marries for love.  In this iteration, Meg is best when she is with her sisters.   The writing and the performance are both natural and nuanced in these situations.

Any message that the movie was trying to convey ended up being confused and forgotten. The final scenes were rushed which cheapened the character development of all the characters (but most especially Amy, Laurie and Jo). What is the point of giving such focus to Jo's rousing speech about how she's so sick of women being told that love is all they're good for and then to have, a few scenes later, the audience clearly being shown that her own true happiness was only achieved through finding 'true love'? What point was the film trying to make about how fiction will only sell if any female heroine is either married or dead by the end?? The film simply ends up affirming both propositions. How did Amy go from 'marriage is an economic transaction' and 'I will not be the person you settle for' to declining Fred's proposal three seconds after Laurie gave her 'that look'?? And since when was Laurie ever interested in Amy at all??? (And don't try to tell me that I should read the book – a movie must be able to stand on its own.) 
If the film had spent more time giving its pivotal final scenes, including Jo and Friedrich's relationship, greater nuance, it would have come out much the better for it.
The acting, production and costume design are otherwise splendid. It's the kind of movie one enjoys tremendously if you don't think about it too much after you've watched it.

Greta Gerwig must have been channeling Louisa May Alcott when she wrote and directed this movie. It is like she reached back in time to gift Louisa with the story she wanted to tell all along. There is a movie within a movie in this version of Little Women and they merge in a seamless way. There is the book based on the Alcott family about the Marches as Loiuisa in it as Joe but then there is Louisa herself apart from the story in her book and she is now allowed freedom to tell the story as she would have liked. So disappointed that Gerwig did not get the nod for best director.

One of the most amazing movies i've ever seen. Saoirse Ronan is an incredible lead, steals every scene while making her relationships to other characters seem intricate and authentic. My heart and soul are still reeling after the heart breaking roller coaster of this movie. For me, I judge a movie based on how emotional it makes me and this one left me in tears multiple times. Not ugly crying tears, but the kind that make your eyes well up because you feel so much for what the characters are going through, or want so much to tell them to choose a different option even though the story is already set in stone. I found myself luck to be in an empty theatre late at night and i was fervently yelling at certain characters throughout the movie. If a movie can provoke that much passion, it is definitely worth seeing. I want this movie, and the cast to win all the awards! They deserve it more than most nominated films.

I love the story of Little Women. Watching this movie was like anticipating a beautiful 10 course meal at the best restaurant in the world with a partner you love, but arriving to be served each course randomly, dessert first, only one bite at a time, and it turns out it's not from scratch chocolate mousse, it's some grocery shelf chocolate pudding. Continuing with this metaphor, you know early on it's going to be poorly executed and you're sitting through it hoping it turns around. This movie puts all other storylines/courses in rapid fire, social-media-feed, random chaotic order, with the lack of complexity passion and coherent storyline and message, and as a result, an incredibly frustrating experience for the watcher wherein your head is spinning and you cannot emotionally attach to the material over the two hours you are required to sit for this. The March family character profile was so singular and vanilla it was difficult to differentiate between sisters, a disappointing result with this quality cast. Amongst an outstanding cast, there were no moving portrayals save Mama March losing her daughter (again a very brief moment). When it comes to M.L. Alcott's literary classic, I'm practically a virgin as I've avoided reading the books or watching any of the numerous screen adaptations, and if it wasn't for the Oscar buzz, I probably wouldn't have bothered with this one either. That's because the story of the four March sisters, each with their individual personalities and ambitions, struggling to cope with societal pressures as well an uncertain future after the US Civil War is, as expected, an old-fashioned and conventional melodrama that I feel I've seen before. What is refreshing and impressive, however, is how Greta Gerwig's adaptation extrapolates, condenses and re-jiggles the various storylines, originally presented in a linear and chronological structure, into a non-linear one that jumps around and between two time periods seven years apart, and blows off the cobwebs to reveal a far more reflective and contemporary film. Quickening the pace and cutting down the hefty source material to its leanest form, it manages to retain its essence, though written 150 years ago, that still resonates with viewers nowadays. It also helps that it looks amazing and sumptuous, with stylish framing, beautiful costume designs and Alexandre Desplat's classy score. Saoirse Ronan's Jo anchors the film well while Florence Pugh's Amy is re-conceived as a more sympathetic character who's practical and worldly; but I find Timothee Chalamet's Laurie a bit too contemporary and out of place. Ultimately, this is Gerwig's film and by amping up its feminist qualities and infusing it with a sense of modernity, this latest incarnation justifies its existence by being thoughtful and pertinent, and I am almost ready to forgive its corny and generic plotting by the time we reach the slightly reworked ending that straddles the line between being faithful to the original and an ending that this book truly deserves.

A picture that prides itself on its fine performances and excellent period piece production design alone is not enough to elevate said release to cinematic greatness. So it is with director Greta Gerwig's new film adaptation of the classic novel "Little Women," a self-congratulatory offering that might look nice but rings inauthentic and tedious in many regards. This is particularly true for its almost-laughable screenplay, whose contemporary dialogue doesn't even begin to adequately suit the film's 19th Century setting. The nonlinear storytelling approach often doesn't work, either, given that there are few recognizable distinctions to separate different time frames from one another. And, while many of the portrayals are solid -- Florence Pugh, Laura Dern, Timothee Chalamet and Meryl Streep -- one can't help but cringe at the overwrought, award-baiting performance of Saoirse Ronan, whose mugging for the camera becomes tiresome quickly. For all its hype, "Little Women," unfortunately, leaves viewers with little to like.

*possible 150 year old spoilers ahead*    I enjoyed the way the director structured this retelling of Little Women. It gave a fresh take to the story and made this feel like a modern movie and gave new tension to the characters and their individual story arcs. Although this is my favorite part, my mom said it made it harder for her to follow.                          The way this was laid out also gave much more attention to each of the sisters making it so the audience really got to know them. Casting was perfect and each of the sisters felt believable in their roles.                                                     I very much enjoyed the did she/did she not idea behind if Jo got married or not this time around. It made the story, again, feel more updated for a new audience and her not getting married was the original book authors intention before the publisher made her change it.                                  Over all I would highly suggest this movie to all ages, to both Little Women lovers and to people new to the story. A cinematic delight that even those not typically interested in period pieces can enjoy.

Where to begin? This movie was a mess! The casting was horrible, the acting was awful, the screenplay was terrible, the music was lifeless, and the editing full of errors. I know this story inside and out and I can’t tell what the director was trying to do here. What a waste! The only saving graces were the few original story elements that were accurate, the acting by Emma and Saoirse, and a few randomly added comments about economic equity, plus the scene showing the Hummels’ poverty. That said, Laura Dern was a horrible Marmee and Chris Cooper was a terrible Mr. Laurence. Oh it pains me to see these beautiful characters so misrepresented! Besides the incredibly choppy and confusing timelines that deflated every opportunity for intimacy or connection, the actors were so clearly not their correct ages. Timothee looks like he’s 13 years old throughout the movie, even at the end when’s he’s supposed to be holding his baby! And Emma Watson as Meg was ridiculous when all her sisters looked older than her, not to mention that they all looked like they were adopted from different families! How are we supposed to believe they’re related?! Also annoying was the inconsistent language style, sometimes going for modern and quippy and other times trying to sound old and proper. Holy cow, it was so bad! I really don’t know what the director thought she was doing with this slap in the face attempt at one of the best novels and stories in American history.

I have to give this version of "Little Women" only 3 stars (the website is not responding to the star selection for some reason) for three main reasons.  First, if I did not know the story I would be very lost because of the continuous jumping back and forth from past to present literally throughout the whole picture, that is the format the writer/director chose, unfortunately.  Second, the actor who played "Teddy/Laurie" was much too young and very slender.  He had this sweet baby face and never grew up, but remained looking like a 17 year old young man even when he should have been in his mid-twenties and bulked up a bit with maturity.  Third, Jo's relationship with the older professor she meets at a boarding house in New York barely scratches the surface.  The only scene really she has with him is when he is reading her writing samples, gives them a harsh critique, she gets mad and leaves the city to go back home to attend to her sick sister Beth.  You don't see him or hear of him again until the very end of the movie when Jo is supposedly "in love" with him and her sisters tell her to chase him down before he leaves for California.  Complete lack of character development on that one!  My favorite film of this great story is the 1994 version with Winona Ryder, Susan Sarandon, and Christian Bale as "Teddy/Laurie."  It is worth checking out!

Just saw this movie and I'm just completely blown away. Greta Gerwig of Ladybird is a genius. I can't believe how modern this felt even though it was a period piece. I've never read the book and I don't think I've ever seen any adaptations of this but I may actually read it. I just found the story of the March sisters absolutely compelling. A story of love, loss feminism in a time of great inequality, coming of age and so much more. The movie speaks volumes to any who would see it but especially women. The movie is not preachy by any means and I was surprised at how entertaining it was funny, sad, emotionally resonant and completely engaging. The performances are just stellar across the board. Laura Dern is solid in a subtle turn as the mother. Florence Pugh of last year's Midsommar adds another great performance to her roster and Emma Watson has truly never been better. Meryl Streep is also great in a smaller role and Timothy Chalamet of Call me by your name adds another mesmerizing turn. But it's Saorise Ronan as usual who steals the show. Her Jo is modern, inspired, layered and passionate. Everyone has amazing chemistry together and the film is just one of the best I've ever seen. From the inspired cinematography like the scene on the beach with Jo and Beth to the effective score and confident, inspired direction it's truly a masterpiece I didn't see coming. Definitely the best film I've seen so far out of 2019.

When this came out, I had mostly every intention of seeing it. Having some other recent movies, I found myself with nothing better to do with my life than go see this. With my fleeting trepidation out of the way, I was treated to great acting, great directing and a great story. With tears that fell asunder, I felt myself falling in love, capricious as it may be. We all know the story but never has this material flourished in the medium that is cinema. Saoirse Ronan was a literal force of nature in the lead role. Florence Pugh offered forth a radiant elegance when her character had the maturity to showcase it. Emma Watson is always so adorable and this part suited her magnificently. I really have to applaud all the charms that Laura Dern brings to the world. Timothée Chalamet is ever so dashing as Laurie. As for the brilliance that is Meryl Streep, I think anyone who is endeared to movies will forever be at a lost for words regarding her imperishable legend. Newcomer Eliza Scanlen grows up right before our very eyes, to become the true heart of this film. And Bob Odenkirk with mutton chops? Yes please. Lastly, Greta Gerwig's direction is superb in its impeccability. I shouldn't of waited as long as I did to see it.

One of my favourite movies this year. A film adaptation that revives the novel in a refreshing way. The cinematography and costumes were stunning and the acting was amazing. Saoirse Ronan and Florence Pugh played the roles of Jo and Amy superbly. I especially liked how the film focused more on Amy and Laurie's relationship, and revealed Amy as a much more complex character than the bratty child she was portrayed as in the novel. The flash-back structure of the film allows us to reflect with Jo on her life and instills the film with nostalgia. This is an important theme in the novel, and especially for many viewers, who having read the novel as children are now adults and can relate to this sense of nostalgia for their own childhood when they first encountered this story.

little women

2019
U
director: Greta Gerwig
starring: Saorise ronan,Florence Pugh,Emma Watson,Eliza Scorn,Timothee Chalamet,Laura Dern, Meryl streep etc

overall rating 96/100

Little women is based around 4 sisters who are successful artists in different forms such as authors,actors,musicians and painters. But they must try and either succumb to expectations of settling down with a man and getting married. Or to fight against the power of men and make it on there own. Wow what a beautifully crafted movie with so much warmth,charm and fantastic acting lets talk about this more in depth.

First of all the films cinematography and aesthetics were stunning. This film was simply stunning to look at. It was so simplistic and yet so effective, i felt like i was in a massive story book. With also breathtaking dance routines and costumes that really caught your eye and left you in awe of what you were watching.

Next the film was actually fairly funny and it also had a fantastic amount of emotional weight to it as well. The family dynamic between the four sisters and the mother bought a lot of relatable humour for me. As i have two sisters which made me connect slightly more with the humour that was being used. Florence Pugh who we will be talking about again soon bought me the most humour as her brutal honesty bought a few much needed chuckles. And the film also had a perfect blend of emotional weight to it as well. The film spent so much time developing all of the sisters stories that you couldn't help feeling emotionally connected to each of them. And to see the collapse of the youngest sister ( Eliza Scorn) health was incredibly heartbreaking, and seeing her death and the impact on Jo ( Saorise Ronan) was heartbreaking but also inspiring as this is what motivated Jo to right her most impactful and successful book.

Next the film had a charming tone throughout,and the script was phenomenally clever and impactful. As previously mentioned seeing the family dynamic and the bond that the whole family had was truly charming and heartwarming. As it reminded me of the bond i have with my family which made me feel comfortable and at home whilst watching. And the script wow was phenomenal. Despite it being set a long time ago the script felt so modern and reflected on society today. With some brutal truths of the roles of women in society in the past and today. With some impactful lines from Saoirse Ronan and Florence pugh.

Now before i get into my final positives. I do just have to say my one negative that stopped the film from being perfect for me. The film slightly overused its usage of flashbacks. So it firstly made it fairly confusing at first to know what time period you were in. And then it made the narrative slightly clunky. But this was only occasionally so didn't really effect my overall opinion of the movie. 

Now time for my final positives. The casting was perfect. All the performances were great and i had 3 standouts in particular. I thought the films casting was perfect for every character. And it was filled with both experienced talent and up and coming talent perfectly. And everyone did a fantastic performance. So i haven't mentioned Eliza Scorn,Emma Watson,Laura Dern or Meryl streep in my key standouts but they all did great jobs. But my key standouts were Saoirse Ronan,Florence Pugh and Timothee Chalamet. Saoirse's performance was incredible and oscar worthy in my opinion. She put so much effort and passion into her performance that you believed everything she said and did throughout the whole film making her character truly inspiring. Florence pugh was phenomenal really showing her acting versatility. With both the serious and funny moments making me excited for her future roles she takes on. And finally Timothee Chalamet who held his own in a rightfully so female dominated movie. He was charming throughout. And he also showed a great contrast with his character of the mischievous and troublesome side to him, but also his sensitive and charming side and Timothee portrayed  this perfectly. Also making me excited for his future work.

Overall despite a slight over usage of flashbacks. Little women is a visually stunning,excellent crafted and acted cinematic masterpiece that deserves to be an awards contender.
A wonderful historic fiction rendering of the book, uplifting and friendly

I'm a Chalamet stan, so admittedly I'm a bit biased. But he manages to immerse himself in his roles so effortlessly that by the end of the movie I actually find myself rooting for Theodore Lawrence instead of Timothee Chalamet. It goes without saying that the acting in this movie is spectacular. Meryl Streep got to play the comedic side character, and it was refreshing and enjoyable to see her be able to shine in a different way on the big screen. Saoirse Ronan was simply delightful to watch, as expected; I'd seen her in Lady Bird, and I was pretty much blown away in laughter and tears. It was no different with Little Women; her portrayal of Jo March filled me with sadness, loneliness, mischievousness, and empowerment all at once.  

To me, the standout character in this remake of the classic tale was none other than Amy March, acted masterfully by Midsommar breakout-star Florence Pugh. Contrary to how many felt about the character in the 1994 film, this version of the character didn't annoy me one bit. In fact, at times, I sympathized with her. I know what it's like always being the second-best, and the one who never gets invited along with the bigger siblings. Pugh, although in her mid 20's, was able to perfectly encapsulate the image of a young, innocent yet mischievous pre-teen that only ever desired the hearts and attention of her sisters. It was even better to see her all grown up, sophisticated and in near-total control of her feelings. [kinda SPOILER] Although I was a little sad to see how Jo and Laurie's story turned out, it was relieving to see Amy finally get one of the things she truly wanted. 

Overall, the movie gave me so many feels. I felt like I was sitting in a living room with all of them, warmed by a nearby fire and the stories they told each other and laughed about. It was a movie not only about empowerment and self-reliance, but about learning when to let go of your childhood prides and fears and realize what makes you happy. Don't be afraid to chase after something even if it doesn't align with what you've been working toward; go with your gut. I left the theater feeling glorious but somehow empty at the same time. I will definitely be watching this film again.

Louisa May Alcott wrote a cohesive story that is heartwarming and, at times, heartbreaking, with beautiful prose and  a compelling plot featuring realistic and charmingly relatable characters.  While Greta Gerwigs depiction achieves the heartwarming/heartbreaking qualities of the original, it bounces distractedly through the plot, features modernized, flat dialogue and turns a story that is a rich portrayal of American family life during the Civil War into a made-for-TV Hallmark production. Meryl Streeps portrayal of Aunt March is cartoonish and distracting. The ending, in particular, is just plain sappy.

Beautifully filmed, and the sets and props were spectacular. Otherwise AWFUL. The flying back and forth in time was inscrutable. Meg and Jo were well-cast but everyone else, most markedly Beth and Laurie (and Marmee for the small role she had) were awful. Laurie had zero romantic presence or energy. Friedrich looked like a cognitively-impaired rat, with no air of intellectualism about him, whatsoever. SO, SO LONG. Look, the 1994 version was definitive. It was perfect. Even Winona Ryder’s irritating personality worked - Jo is irritating, really. Clare Danes was the PERFECT Beth. Susan Sarandon *was* Marmee. Gabriel Byrne was exactly Friedrich Behr. Samantha Mathis’ Amy was perfectly serviceable, and Christian Bale had adult charisma and chemistry with both Ryder and Mathis. The story made sense, it gave EXACTLY enough play to the theme of feminism (because that theme is inherent to the book) and it was a reasonable runtime.

The movie's really well put together on a technical level. There's also a compelling emotional heart to the movie that you don't always get, even with these Oscar season releases. Gerwig's directing is top notch and the actors all bring their A-game. Standouts include Saoirse Ronan as Jo March and Timothee Chalamet as Laurie, though the whole cast is terrific. Over the course of the film, you become immersed in each sister's story to the point that even relatively low stakes situations feel cataclysmic. It's an intimate and deeply human tale that Gerwig brings to life notably. Still, the many plots of the movie feel disconnected and it never coalesces into something truly satisfying. The story on display felt like something more akin to a Netflix miniseries and I think the movie could've done with more time to explore its ideas and characters.

This and Steel Magnolias both deserve to be pinned on a joist like piatas and whacked at with a sharp stick. Someone please pluck out my eyes, and muffle my ears from even one more rousing bonding session with these March sisters. See the black and white version instead. Less treacle, better acting.
