4.5 Star Review: (No Spoilers here)
In what is sure to be an Oscar contender, Greta Gerwig masterfully directed and wrote this coming of age story of Jo March and her sisters as they deal with family hardships, love and coming to terms with how easily life can change in an instant. Set in the post Civil War years, Greta Gerwig's film is told through 2 distinct timelines set 7 years apart. Initially I was thrown off by this as there are no clues on screen for this back and forth in time save for the single caption that appears once saying "7 years earlier." From that point forward, the March sisters' story is masterfully juxtaposed with what is happening in the present with the adult sisters with the scenes in the past using color hues of orange, yellow and red contrasted to the present color hues of blue, white and black. The film's cinematography and editing help in successfully telling the story in this back and forth fashion. I was very impressed how this technique in storytelling paid its dividends in a major scene involving the youngest of the sisters, Beth. The back and forth time jumping as these events unfolded with Beth made for a powerful moment in the film that may not have been otherwise possible in a linear form of storytelling.
Little Women is based on the 1868 novel by Louisa May Alcott of the same name. I have never read it so I can not say how much it closely follows the book or not. However, as a film it is a wonderfully crafted movie. Casting a stellar ensemble cast to portray the March sisters, Saoirse Ronan, Emma Watson, Florence Pugh and Eliza Scanlon all have their moments to shine in their roles but it is Ronan's role as Jo that stands out the most. Jo March is adamant about living her life the way she wants to without being bound to the societal constructs of what they deem she should be. Jo is passionate about following her dreams and becoming the author she knows she was meant to be.
My one quibble with the film is that of the character Laurie and how certain characters appear to be infatuated with him. I found him to be obnoxious most of the film and the way his story arc concluded did not appear to be earned, in my opinion. The ending, while cliched, was well done and will likely have many of the female fans loving how it ended. I would have preferred the ending Jo had originally intended for her book to be the same for the film. Nonetheless, Little Women is still a very good film with a stellar cast. Expect Oscar nominations for this film.

Heartfelt performances despite ridiculous editing choices.

Greta Gerwig's period drama Little Women (2019) is a beautiful film with tender direction and powerful acting performances from a phenomenal cast. However, the editing within Gerwig's version is so rapid fire and oddly cut that I felt she rushed the story as scenes cut right when lines end with no room to breathe. Sometimes characters talk over one another as scenes are not allowed to affect you in the muddled first half until the strong second half. Gerwig is a fantastic director, whom I love and respect after seeing Lady Bird, but she fumbles Louisa May Alcott's classic tale told better in the 1994 version of Little Women starring Winona Ryder, Kirsten Dunst, and Claire Danes. Gerwig's Little Women will move you with devastating acting that made me cry, but it takes a while until those scenes get there.

Aside from Gerwig's striking direction and visuals and the awful editing, Alexandre Desplat's score is sweeping and inspired. He carefully fits every song to the emotions on screen with subtle musical cues that make effective scenes even more affecting. Gerwig's writing modernizes Little Women with strong speeches on the opportunities for women as well as professing the virtues of owning your own art's copyright. Some of her choices to make Amy more feminist instead of Jo feel out of place for the character, but overall Gerwig keeps things iconic and classy for her sweet Little Women. Greta Gerwig should continue to direct original concepts instead of adapting novels as Lady Bird is a stronger piece than Little Women.

Saoirse Ronan is likable and gripping as Jo March. She feels like a young woman striving for a career as Ronan is as touching as Winona Ryder's portrayal of Jo. Saoirse is the greatest actress of her generation and outdoes herself as always. Laura Dern is subtle and tender just as good as gentle as Susan Sarandon's Marmie. Timothee Chalamet matches Christian Bale's iconic Laurie with a moving performance that made me cry at least three times. He may be my favorite aspect to Gerwig's Little Women. Chalamet is certainly the greatest actor of his generation after roles like Call Me by Your Name and Little Women alone. Chris Cooper is really sad and tear-jerking as Laurie's grandfather. I found him surprisingly moving.

Florence Pugh may be miscast as Gerwig makes the baffling decision to dress Pugh like a little girl to play both young Amy and older Amy in Paris. Pugh is commanding and pretty as older Amy, but ridiculous and unbelievable as young Amy. Pugh puts on a childish voice that does not convince you she is much younger despite a little girl's dress being on and her fake childish voice. Kirsten Dunst was a revelation as young Amy March, so Pugh does not compare. Florence Pugh is much stronger as the older Amy scolding Laurie for not understanding her position on marriage. I also loved Pugh during the scenes where Laurie proposes to her both times.

I really enjoyed Eliza Scanlan's Beth March. She is realistic and soft spoken letting you believe she is sickly and frail. Scanlan is nearly as good as Claire Danes in the same role. Emma Watson is fine as Meg March, but she's nowhere near as good as Trini from the 1994 Little women. Meryl Streep is okay as Aunt March, but she's given nearly no lines.

I did not care for Louis Garrel as the professor since he gets few lines and no development, especially compared to Gabriel Byrne's professor depiction. The man Meg marries in this is completely forgettable and not likable at all compared to the wonderful actor in the 1994 version. Bob Odenkirk is cute as the March father, but he gets little to say. I think Gerwig wasted some of her cast, but the main leads are all so resplendent, it doesn't matter.

In all, Little Women is a story near and dear to my heart as I genuinely relate to Jo and Laurie a lot, but the 1994 film is a timeless classic. I did enjoy Gerwig's movie, but it has too many odd choices to be flawless.

Disconcertingly "busy" in the first 15 minutes (do these people ever stop dancing?), then a series of gorgeous but vapid tableaux, beautifully photographed. I agree with Louisa May Alcott, who disliked her own story.

Greta Gerwig established herself as a talented director with Lady Bird (2017), but while that film had boundless charm and excellent performances, it never enraptured me the way her expertly realised sophomore film does. Little Women is brilliant. It is brilliant on a structural level, brilliant on performance level, brilliant on a design level. Greta Gerwig's adaptation is a charming, all-consuming joy. There isn't a moment that doesn't sweep you away. I left the cinema feeling lighter. It will be the film I'll watch every year on the sofa.

Little Women is a film that is alive. It is alive in the ink-stained fingers and always messy-haired Jo (Saorise Ronan) or in the scrunched-up nose, and often petulant, Amy (Florence Pugh). It is alive in the quiet spark of Beth (Eliza Scanlen) and in the girly shrill of horror when Meg (Emma Watson) has a curling iron accident. It is also alive in the way Marmee (Laura Dern) peels away her warm scarf and stuffs it into a blanket for somebody that needs it or the way Mr Laurence (Chris Cooper) sits on the staircase, stifling a cry, as the girl that reminds him of his departed daughter plays on her piano. Based on the classic novel from Louisa May Alcott, the characters are brought to life in every frame, helped by a collection of great performances and cosy attention to the details that make 1860s Massachusetts burst off the screen. The film has the colour and care that a painting has, and it often looks like one. Every corner feels lived in and the March house is the epicentre of this, crammed with the passions and laughter of the women that live there.

Saorise Ronan re-joins Gerwig from Lady Bird and imbues Jo, and lynchpin of the story, with the perfect blend of messiness and fiery ambition that has made the character so endearing across generations. You feel the artistic desire that fuels and burns inside of Jo, and Ronan is naturally suited to puffing it out in moments that see her nervously waiting in the doorway as a love interest reads her work, bristling with jittery excitement only to fly into a tantrum of rage when the pompous man tells her he thinks her writing is no good – Little Women is sewn together by these small bites of character and all of them feel real.

Fighting Jo in the film as the jealous sister but also fighting Ronan for best performance is Florence Pugh as the young, sometimes brattish, always determined Amy. Pugh cements her excellent year with another scene-stealing performance, instilling a new-found charm and vulnerability into a character that would otherwise be spiteful and jealous. It is both a testament to Pugh's gifts as an actor and Gerwig's as a talented, observant writer. The same attention is mostly given to the other women, with Eliza Scanlan dealt a difficult hand playing the doomed and shy Beth, and yet in the brief scenes she has, she finds a way to steal a little of the spotlight… and your heart strings, building a brief and sweet relationship with Laurie's Uncle, Mr Lawrence, a fatherly figure mourning the death of his daughter. Emma Watson is reliably good but out of the four women Meg feels the most underdeveloped, although Gerwig still finds time to make you care about the direction her life has taken and what she wants, but more importantly, what she's had to sacrifice to make her cute but tested and relatable marriage with John (James Norton) work.

Gerwig sets down her creative marker early by opening the film with eldest sister Jo already making her way into a male dominated publishing world, hiding behind the pretence that the work she presents, her work, is courtesy of a friend. There is a small but sharp and impactful turn from Tracy Letts as the stubborn editor, slashing through half of Jo's story with a frozen glare that's certain to send a chill down any aspiring writer's spine. The film then breezes along, flowing between past and future, showing the women as squabbling sisters with clashing dreams and the different paths each of them took. The timelines are framed intelligently using colour and clothing; warm oranges and yellows flood the past, whereas the future is cloudier, the house darker and the skirts purple and blue. Structuring the script like this is the first of many decisions from Gerwig that freshens the source material and gives the timeless classic a sense of renewed energy and modernity.

The love in Little Women is tactile, charming and never soppy. Gerwig shows it in a hand entangling another, the four sisters cradling each other at their mother's feet, pillows thrown across the room or a playful punch to the shoulder. Lose yourself in the first dance between Jo and Laurie (Timothée Chalamet), a joyous piece of classical dancing and free-spirited, loose-limbed modern raving. And despite the incredible cast of women and their performances, Gerwig's secret wild card is Chalamet, who twirls through the film like a storm, his carefree arrogance and open heart both in tune and at odds with March sisters, and is, like the rest of us, pulled helplessly into their lives

A standout scene, of which I could honestly choose any, sees the entire March family barge into Mr Laurence's estate, each of them caught in their own little world, enrapturing the men all at once by their sudden presence alone. In this scene it is as if the women have woken the men up from there dull and serious lives. It all just glows with warmth.

It is Gerwig's generosity to all the little things that make the book timeless, and make a great film, that ensures this adaptation reaches and soars beyond all those that have come before it. No character feels forgotten, and each have their place in the film, their own little moment in the spotlight, right down to the wonderful, joyful process of printing and binding a new book. I have no doubt that Gerwig's Little Women will reach modern classic status within a couple of years and maybe it already has.

Scott writes the movie reviews for Sharon's Facebook page. So why did Scott rate this a 5. Has he lost his manhood. Maybe? It's a very different look at Little Women. So it definitely isn't a repeat. This was the best version of little women I have seen, and I have probably seen 4 different versions.  It was extremely well acted, especially by Saoirse Ronan as the title character Jo March. For instance I normally don't like Laura Dern, but she was perfect as the mom, and Chris Cooper was great as the Lauries uncle. The movie just did a much better job than the others in developing the multitude of characters.  Another thing i particularly appreciated was the way the director chose to not tell the story chronologically.  They start the movie near the end, and then throughout the movie go back and forth from the early days to later points in the story.  This really helped you to better understand the characters and their motivations.  I must say that in this version I had a much greater appreciation for the characters of Amy and Beth.  Amy is normally just a spoiled brat.  But Florence Pugh does an excellent job playing her both young and a bit older with different motivations.  In sum, everyone on my family loved it. Following her stunning solo-directing debut "Lady Bird" (2017), a contemporary film imbued with her voice, it is perhaps surprising that Greta Gerwig would choose to adapt for the screen and direct another iteration of Louisa May Alcott's "Little Women" ... but lucky us that she did, because her version enhances Alcott's voice, making it at once more clearly feminist, romantic and consequential. Saoirse Ronan is the perfect Jo, but it is "Midsommar" (2019) star Florence Pugh as Amy whose character arc indelibly defines this take. They're both so strong it hardly matters that Emma Watson as Meg and Eliza Scanlen as Beth are merely good. Featuring a heart-meltingly dashing Timothée Chalamet as Laurie, Meryl Streep as a perfectly curmudgeonly Aunt March and Tracy Letts as kind-hearted Mr. Dashwood, this "Little Women," with its nonlinear storyelling, is a feel-good triumph of the female spirit.

LITTLE WOMEN comes late in the calendar for 2019 releases but it may be the best movie of the year.  With an ensemble cast to die for--Saoirse Ronan, Meryl Streep, Laura Dern, Emma Watson, Florence Pugh, Eliza Scanlon, Timothee Chalamet, Chris Cooper, Tracy Letts,  and a director in Greta Gerwig who knows how to tease out a surprising bit of nuance in almost every scene yet keep the trajectory moving forward at good pace, this film moves steadily towards a glorious conclusion.  I was fully immersed in the story and felt like I experienced the world and troubles and joys of the March family along with them.  I measure great films by whether or not I was engaged, thrilled and moved by the experience and thus LITTLE WOMEN gets BIG PRAISE from me.  A must-see movie.

Little Women shows to me that I need to pay more attention to Greta Gerwig as a director. She used her direction to craft a faithful and emotional adaptation of the classic novel. Each and every performance in the film was great. Saoirse Ronan was fantastic as the lead character and Emma Watson and Timothee Chalamet do great jobs as a sister and a friend. Each character felt unique and it was interesting to watch each of them reach their lowest of lows and then reach their highest of highs. The story flows pretty smoothly although the runtime is a tad bit too long. The film is about 2 hours and 20 minutes and it really felt like it should have been just 2 hours. That's mainly due to the film's slow pacing. That being said though, there was something in each scene that interested me whether it was the lighting, cinematography, or performances. I also too slight issue with some stylistic choices in the beginning. There is a scene where Jo Marsh is running down the street and it changes to slow mo for 2 seconds and it felt weird. From the films from Greta Gerwig that I have seen, she loves using themes of love and relationships with our family a lot. She expertly hides these themes within her screenplay for the film. The film manages to pull off a lot of emotional weight. Certain scenes in the film are intended to be emotional and they worked great for me. Some directors probably wouldn't have been able to pull it off but Greta Gerwig did. The cinematography, although not the best of the year, was great. Almost every shot was interesting to look out and there was always something to pay attention to. The costume and set design are fantastic. The costumes look great and authentic to the time period while the set design is warm and inviting. The musical score by Alexandre Desplat is fantastic. It feels authentic to the time period and feels unique. Overall,Little Women is a great take on family relationships with great performances, an intelligent script, fantastic musical score, and good cinematography.

As someone who loves and cherishes the 1994 adaptation of the film, and adored the book, I thought this version was really well done. I was most impressed with Florence Pugh. Many lines from the book were faithfully rendered so that anyone who knew the story by heart would hear the beloved words, yet the style and pacing and sensibility were completely modern.  The daughter's character portrayal was true with no cringes required for unfaithful renditions.  In Alcott's time, there would have been little praise for a woman who supported  her family although there were others who also were principal breadwinners through writing or speaking (Lucy Stone, e.g.)  Emphasis on some few of the author's words and a bit of expansion led to us knowing and understanding the barriers in her way and the determination with which she overcame them.  And we got a classic story retold to new audiences, at least some of whom will read the story.

My first-ever LITTLE WOMEN experience could not have been viewed at a better time! This film effortlessly took me back 20 years in time to when I first started to really fall in love with cinema and relived that precious feeling over again, stirring such deep emotion in me that not many movies achieve. 

Greta Gerwig's splendid writing and directing work succeeded strongly at making me feel a part of this family, whose close-knit relationships is something I never had in my own childhood and upbringing. She has extracted some truthful and valuable themes and lines of dialogue from this classic story and told them in such an eloquent and powerful manner. 

A magnificent ensemble of some of the best and most favourite actors and faultless filmmaking in every aspect elevate the total joy and poignant moments there are to be had watching LITTLE WOMEN. This film is accessible to all ages and audiences, and is everything I just love about cinema!

Little Women (2019) Review:

Greta Gerwig writes and directs the beloved story of four of sisters coming of age in the aftermath of the Civil War.  The story is told through flashbacks and present tense mainly through the eyes of Jo March (Saoirse Ronan), Amy March (Florence Pugh), and Meg March (Emma Watson).  I really like the story of Little Women.  In 1994 we got a version with lead actress Winona Ryder and I liked that one last time I saw it.  Greta Gerwig proved to be a fantastic director with 2017s Lady Bird.  She was the only female director nominated for best director that year.  I really hope she gets nominated again this year and I think it would be amazing if she could win.  Gerwig has a way of directing to make everything feel real and personal.  I was invested in the story and the characters.  Every performance is practically flawless.  Even with Emma Watson occasionally slipping to her British accent, she still provided a great performance.  There's three performances that really stood out to me.  First off, Saoirse Ronan is perfect in every role that I've seen her in.  She is the perfect Jo March and brings life to the screen.  The sparks of creativity that lead her to write we're all genuine.  Those sparks were her becoming Jo.  I just loved her.  Second, and another actor that is perfect in every role, is Timothée Chalamet.  He plays the main love interest, Laurie.  He embodies this arrogant but fun man who is trying to get the stubborn Jo March to fall in love with him.  Chalamet's performance isn't getting the recognition it deserves.  He costarred with Ronan in Lady Bird and those two have a real chemistry.  Their energy is just perfect together.  I loved his Laurie and how he interacts with everyone.  Finally, my favorite actress of the year, Florence Pugh plays Amy March.  From what I know, in the book we're supposed to not like Amy and she's annoying.  However, Amy was my favorite character in the whole film.  Florence Pugh is a fantastic actress.  In Midsommar she gave a gripping performance and also another good performance as Saraya Knight in an underrated movie this year, Fighting With My Family.  I love her so much and she is well deserving of the Oscar for this performance.  Since the film is shown through flashbacks and present, we get to see this change of character from young her to adult.  Younger her would whine and joke around.  I loved that aspect of her character.  There's a scene where she's crying outside and then comes inside and is joking around.  I was dying of laughter.  But for every comedic part there's always something dramatic.  If Hollywood needs an actor to cry for a scene, she's the perfect choice.  In Midsommar she practically cried throughout the whole film and then parts at this.  Her crying feels real to me because it's not the typical cliche crying we usually see.  That may just be me but that's what I think.  Like I said many times, I love the performances.  The story was adapted very well and Greta Gerwig deserves the praise.  The only problem I had with the story was when it goes to the past it doesn't show that it's the past until we look at the characters and what story is happening.  There were a few attempts where the tone in the cinematography changed but there was one instance where it went back and forth sort of frequently and it was hard to keep up.  It's something you sort of have to get used to.  Speaking of cinematography, I liked it.  There's some really gorgeous shots, in particular some beach sequences.  Alexandre Desplat's score is beautiful as always.  I think he's one of the greatest composers and there's no doubt he'll get a nomination for his work on this.  Some of the songs are emotional and help with the tone.  It wasn't just the sad scenes and great performances that made me cry, but also his score.  I urge anybody to listen to his score, or any score in general, rather than some music on the radio.  People should really appreciate them more.  Listening to it before watching the film I felt some emotion during some of the songs.  I basically only listen to film scores and this is my message to get you to take some time, sit down, and just listen to the beautiful music.  If you don't know the story, I'd suggest bringing some tissues into the theater.  That goes for those who know the story as well.  I think basically everyone in the theater was crying.  This goes back to Gerwig's direction of making everything feel real.  I cried a few times.  The emotion is all there and there's no denying it.  Overall, Little Women hasn't had an adaption better than this.  I'd highly suggest seeing this.  It's made it to one of my favorites of the year.  There's no way to be disappointed.

But overall, a fine film. The acting, cinematography, costumes and set design are wonderful. Women may find the relationship-driven story easier to follow than I did, but my mother, aunt and a girl I overheard in the hallway afterwards all mentioned being somewhat confused at times. Don't let that stop you, though. This film is well worth seeing!

This movie was fantastic! It's a movie about family, friendship, courage and ambition. It's filled with food for thought by offering different perspectives. The amalgamation of Jo March (as we know her from the book) and Louisa May Alcott is introduced for the first time. This iteration's Jo emphasizes the progressive thinking of Louisa May Alcott, her determination and sense of self, pride and worth. Certainly her struggles as a women during the mid to late 1800's drives the plot, however, they are universally relatable, as all people, at one time or another, question their sense of self, pride and worth. We see struggles through the lens of each of the March sisters, who are mirrors that allow us to see versions ourselves as we are and/or who we hope to be. Some struggles are singular to each of their artistic gifts, while others apply to women, in general, during that time period. The acting was superb! The nonlinear structure was fresh! I left the theater feeling hopeful and ready to start the new year with a sense of self, pride and worth and the belief that I have grown into the big dreams I had as a young girl!

An enjoyable film and I'm happy to see new themes highlighted in this generations iteration. 
What I liked:
1) The cast is strong overall. I have a preference for Winona Ryder but that does not take away from the performance of our new Jo March. Meg is well performed by Emma Watson. She is unexciting but contrary to what some reviews say, I appreciate that as it reminds us that there is nothing wrong with not being exciting and that we all value different things and have varying goals for ourselves. Mr. Brookes is played with much more dimension than the previous versions, this is due to the performance but also the added length of time spent focusing on the little women as adults.
2) I loved that it showed that you can be a feminist and still be a homemaker, an aristocrat, quiet and gentle, or fiercely independent.
3) The edit to have Jo negotiate the same book deal Alcott did is an excellent addition and is made even better beside the randomness of the marriage she ends with. It demonstrates the marriage is not really meant to be part of the story but is simply added there to please publishers.
4) Many of the lessons of the book and directly quoted dialogue are well covered.

What I did not like:
1) The cast as an ensemble. While the performances were great as mentioned above, the actors do not fit together as the characters should. Laurie looks far too young and it really is just not realistic to have Amy played by one actress throughout. She starts the story at 11 years old and is 20 by the end.
2) Laurie was the disappointment of the cast. He was childish and boring to watch when he is meant to be just as exciting as Jo.
3) The bouncing around with the timeline (especially with no effort made to age the cast appropriately) is confusing (especially I would imagine for those that have not read the book) and takes away from the emotional impact as well as the appreciation for the struggles and growing up that is done.
4) The edits to make viewer more comfortable. The reality of the time is women married young and men tended to be older for example. Jo's love "interest" is meant to be an older German professor. We do not need to make the life of the past identical to our own to watch it. 

Overall, I love this story and enjoyed watching. I may rewatch in the future but the 1994 version remains my first choice.

I likely wouldn't have even watched this in the first place had it not been for Greta Gerwig and the stellar main cast- BUT WAS BLOWN AWAY. I haven't felt anything this heartwarming in a long, long time. I do not think of myself as a "mushy" person or anything, but this movie made me laugh, cry, and stirred my heart so much, I just wanted to be IN the movie. And it's not just the story (which has been adapted for film too many times to count already)- it is very clearly Gerwig's direction, detail, comedic hand, and amazing ability to balance the story in the most captivating way. Pugh, Ronan, and Chalamet are also absolutely captivating and PERFECTLY cast for their roles. Overall, this is absolutely on my top 10 movies of all time, and definitely in at least the top 5 for now!

By my count, this is approximately the 182nd version of Louisa May Alcott's Civil War sisterhood. There must be something universal about the trials of the March sisters and their struggles for independence, agency, love, and happy endings on their own turns. Greta Gerwig, fresh off her Oscar nominations for Lady Bird, has given Little Women a decidedly modern spin. The story flashes back and forth between past and present, sometimes in consecutive shots, and feels full of authentic youthful energy. It's also the first adaptation I've watched that has fixed the problem of Amy (Florence Pugh, affecting), widely regarded as the least liked sister. Through Gerwig's telling, she becomes a self-determined woman, just like Jo (Saoirse Ronan), who recognizes the social trappings holding her back but chooses to do her best within this unfair system rather than rage against it. It's like an empathetic reclamation for this often reviled character. The enjoyment of Little Women is how vibrant and different each of the March sisters is and how an audience can see degrees of one's self in each little woman. Jo is by all accounts our lead and her struggle to be a successful writer pushes her against conventions of the era. There is an invented and very amusing bookend where Jo bickers with a blowhard male publisher (Tracy Letts) about "women's melodrama." It's a meta commentary on Alcott's book herself, especially with the helping of marriages and happy endings by story's end. Ronan is a force of nature in the film and sweeps up everyone around her with charm. Meryl Streep is supremely amusing as an older rich aunt bemoaning the girls won't get anywhere without marrying a wealthy man. The limited options for a working-class family are given great consideration, but it's really a movie that seems to pulsate with the exciting feelings of being young, having the world stretch out before you, and chasing your dream, rain or shine. It's also gorgeously shot and feels so assured from Gerwig as a solo director. There are a few detractions for this new 2019 Little Women, the biggest being how confusing it can get with its melded chronologies. If this is your first exposure to Alcott's story, I fear you'll get lost more than a few times trying to keep everything in order. The love story with lovesick pretty boy Laurie (Timothee Chalamet) feels tacked on even though it's a feature of the novel. This newly structured, reinvigorated, charming remake of a literary classic feels definitely of the period and of today. It's the first Little Women adaptation that made me realize how timeless this story really can feel in the right hands. It may be the 182nd version but it might be the best one yet.

This is a film set in the 1800s about young women who are longing and waiting, and waiting and longing. I attended this film as a recompense for taking my wife to Star Wars IX. My wife is a fan of the original Little Women film but was just as bored as me watching this remake. She spent most of the movie fiddling with her phone and asking when it would be over. 

I tried to concentrate hoping that there would be some payoff, but the film's big climax was the main character staying up late and writing a book by candlelight. Spoiler: the book she writes is Little Women. It's a movie about a book where the author is writing about herself writing. It's recursive and paradoxical, but not a fun or interesting paradox like Kyle Reese becoming the father of John Connor. 

My largest complaint is that this movie jumps around between flashbacks and it is hard to distinguish where you are in time. You have to pay very close attention to keep track. The only clue of timing is that the actresses' hair changes. My second big issue is that it doesn't show any of the relationship forming between Jo and her suitor. The only early scene with him is when he critiques her writing and she is insulted and storms off. He doesn't appear again until the end of the film when he makes a random visit tohher family's house and her family explains to her that she is in love, which promptly leads to a marriage proposal. 

I think this movie could only be appreciated by someone who read the book. The movie is too muddled to understand or care about the characters without the back story. Anyway, I should probably wake my wife up now that the movie is over.

I love this version even more than the 1995 version! This version of Little Women is much more feminist in that even Amy in her debate over wether to marry Fred articulates a full awareness of the state of womens rights at the time and the transactional effect it had left on marriage.  Both she and Jo comment on the impact this has had on their own decision making.  As much as I adore Laurie, it was satisfying to hear Amy call him out for the hypocrisy of a man judging a woman for being  pragmatic about marriage rather than waiting for true love when he and every other man know very well how risky it is to do otherwise, as we see later when even Jo has second thoughts which I also thought was great to include because it was realistic as to what would genuinely be going through her mind- but I also love the speech she gives at that same moment when she is talking To her mother that the true reason she is even reconsidering marriage is once again nothing to do with love but just an attempt to break out of the little box her society has put her into.   She says it right then that civil war society refused to allow a world where a woman can have love and ambition, and it is creating that sense of loneliness.  Ideas that still hit close to home in 2020.

I've seen every version of Little Women, and this ranks third (after the BBC miniseries and 1994 version). Saiorse Ronan and Timothee Chalamet are exceptional, and Meryl Streep is predictably perfect for her brief role as nasty Aunt March. But Emma Watson's Meg is colorless and inconsequential, Florence Pugh as Amy is too contemporary in appearance and demeanor to be believable as a 19th century woman (which could also be said of Laura Dern as Marmy), and there's nothing memorable about Eliza Scanlen as poor Beth. She and all the sisters, in fact, suffer from the plot jumping around over 7 years but the same actresses playing them and there not being much distinction about what age/plotline is being shown. I've asked 2 people unfamiliar with the story if they knew what was going on, and they said no — there's a lot of assumption by Greta Gerwig that everyone knows the book. Chalamet rescues Laurie, but poor Friedrich is reduced to a clownish figure whose appeal to Jo makes no sense. But here's the overarching problem, for me: The heart of the story is the love among the sisters amid a father away at war, coping with challenging, humble circumstances. This March family seems to lack for nothing — warm lovely home, beautiful clothes, travel to the seashore, etc. That provides a less convincing backdrop for Alcott's story. I'd love to hear her "notes" for Gerwig about the film.

Another remake of Little Women--and this one is spectacular. Instead of telling the story in a linear fashion, Gerwig begins in the present and then flashes back and flashes forward and back again, etc., unpeeling layers of meaning and emotion in the process. The cast is superb--Saoirse Ronan is dazzling as is the camera work and musical score. Why would Gerwig choose to present the narrative complexly rather than in a straightforward manner? The latter approach has already been done ad nauseum, for one. Secondly, Gerwig has made Jo into Alcott's alter ego, and as Jo struggles to get published in New York, she reminisces about her adolescence and early adulthood in the March family. When one thinks, there are no time constraints--you can be anywhere, anytime you want and jump freely as your thoughts inspire you. As the audience for the film witnesses this random sequencing, we experience new anticipations, meanings, and insights not possible in a linear presentation. If the movie frustrated you, I urge you to watch it again with these ideas in mind at a bargain theater or certainly on cable--the experience will be rewarding.

Went to the theater wanting to love this newest version of Little Women..came out, not a fan. 
First the decision to tell Jo's story as Jo/Alcott's story did the source material a disservice by emphasizing the author's personal opinions, esp at the end ..ugh.

The decision to tell this story in a non-linear format was strange, yeah, okay, the makers wanted to do their own version of the movie, I get that..but it didn't work for me. Good Lord, I would imagine, if you were not entirely familiar with other versions or the book, it could be confusing, esp since the characters really don't change pysically in the decade they are portrayed.  Laurie/Teddy, looks like a 16 yr old Eurotrash boytoy model all the way through the decade..same with Amy who looked 20 yrs old as a 12 yr old. 
This version, for me anyway, was not able to bring any investment from me to the characters..esp the men portrayed, but also to the sisters and Marmie. Everything was gorgeously shot, nicely acted and terribly dull and lifeless.

Oh and please, don't get me started on Amy's feminist speech, or Marmees "I'm ashamed of my country"...so they could squeeze in a line for a person of color and call it a day. Making sure to be inclusive and self aware of women's social status of the era lest we as an audience somehow are unaware of this or think the filmmakers are unaware and get our collective panties in a wad.

Instead of making another Little Women movie, I think the producers and director of this movie should have made a film about Alcott's life, her struggles and how they influenced the shaping of Little Women..that would have been interesting and I think they would have done that justice..but not here, not with this movie.

Writer/director Greta Gerwig has reimagined the classic, skipping back and forth in a timeline that follows the 4 sisters from their teen years to adulthood. In addition to her spirited script, she's created a wonderful world of independent-thinking women and family support. The 4 actors playing the "women" are all winning, effectively capturing the dynamic between a quartet of teens, while later exploring their own struggles for happiness and worth. The performance standout (as the rich boy next door) is Timothée Chalamet, who's simply fetching, his most charming role to date. Even with the period setting, the film feels modern, fun and sweet.

This is Greta Gerwig's latest film about 4 young women coming of age and living in pre-Civil War Massachusetts. I have not read the original novel, nor have I seen any of the previous versions of this, so I watched the film with no preconceptions. When I watch a Gerwig film I feel like I am being guided into a special place, and this film is no exception. She is a brilliant director who gets the most from her actors in this film about these 4 women finding their voices in 19th century but feels relevant. Jo March (Saoirse Ronan), the oldest, is strong-willed and trying to establish herself as a writer with her own unique voice. Her publisher wants her to make sure that her writing ends with the woman getting married and her aunt (played by the wonderful Meryl Streep) tells her that marriage is her only option. Her sisters are Meg (Emma Watson), who wants to be an actress, May (Florence Pugh), who aspires to be a famous painter, and Beth (Eliza Scanlen). They are guided by their mother, played by Laura Dern, to be true to their own inner voices and to find their own paths, not those that have been pre-determined for them. The actresses playing the four sisters do a great job, especially Ronan who carries the film. Timothee Chamelet, who plays the rich neighbor Laurie, is excellent in his supporting role as the young man who finds joy with the women. The cinematography and score are also excellent, and Gerwig makes interesting and effective use of alternating between past and present to tell the women's stories. I loved the film - it is a thoughtful period piece, with just the right amount of humor, that gives center stage to the energy and determination of women. Kudos to Gerwig for crafting a film that leaves you feeling really satisfied when the film is over.

FUN FACT:
There have been 8 film adaptations of the Louisa May Alcott novel and 5 of them are rated a 7.2 on IMDB. Also, 3 of these film adaptations have been within the last 3 years. For reasons unknown these facts amaze me.

SYNOPSIS:
A story of Jo March (Saoirse Ronan) coming of age with her sisters while trying to support herself with writing stories for the newspaper and attempting to live outside of the social norm of what's expected of a woman during the 19th century.

REVIEW SUMMARY:
This was a lovely cast with lots of chemistry. I started off really enjoying the film and would've rated it higher if it had not veered off of the strongest part of the story. In my opinion, Jo March's story was most interesting along with her friendship/romance with Laurie (Timothee Chalamet). Although they do make her the main character of the story, I felt they took a little too much time with some of the other sisters. I wish they did less with Meg March (Emma Watson) and Amy March (Florence Pugh) had a situation where her half of the story could've been really interesting, but it almost felt like a huge important chunk of her story was left on the cutting room floor. With that being said, the movie was very sweet, but I think it's going to fall a little bit outside of my top 10 for this year. 7.4/10.

-------------------------------------BREAKDOWN------------------------------------------

DIRECTION:
Greta Gerwig is a solid director, but between this and "Lady Bird", she isn't necessarily a name I need to go out and see work from. I understand that these two films have been very critically acclaimed, but I have yet to be convinced through the direction. There's nothing that I see and think "wow, no other director could do that." In fact, between these last two I think there are quite a few that could successfully pull these films off. There have literally been 7 other directors of Little Women (even if this has the highest rating of them all). This is more of an editing flaw, but there were times near the beginning where I wasn't quite sure which time-period we were in. Like, we're flipping between present day (in the film) and 7 years prior and though I had a hunch which point in time were at due to the color difference, I still struggled a couple of times. Also, why was Timothee Chalamet's hair all "cover of GQ magazine?" I was waiting for him to pull out his iPhone 11.

WRITING:
Now Greta Gerwig strived here in the writing. Give credit to Louisa May Alcott for the original story, but Greta Gerwig did write the screenplay. It's always hard to adapt a book into a movie and it's impossible to compare when you're like me and haven't read the book. As I mentioned in my review summary, there were flaws. Specifically with the character of Amy March. There's a subplot of the story with her and someone else where I don't really know how the transition from 7 years prior to present day happened. It really didn't make sense to me and that's all I can say without spoiling it. That's why I feel like there was possibly more to her story that would patch that up, but it wasn't in the movie and that's unfortunate, because her story might've been the most interesting, if not for Jo's story.

ACTING:
Everything is amazing her except for one minor thing. Emma Watson does not have the American Accent down. Clearly they weren't going for a Mid-Atlantic accent as people had during that period, so her having trouble with the American accent through me off slightly. Again, very slightly, not enough to make me hate it or anything and I could never hate Emma Watson. She might be my dream girl. Her natural beauty is something of angels. *clears throat* Anyway, the acting in this film is so good otherwise. Timothee Chalamet is A-List and Florence Pugh kills it. Honestly, I wouldn't be mad if anyone in this film was nominated for an Oscar, but I don't think any of them should win an Oscar. I could most definitely see this film winning a Best Ensemble award.

I have seen only two cinematic versions of The Little Women: this version and the 1994 one with Winona Ryder as Jo.   IMO, this is the far superior version, although I liked that older version as well.   All the acting and performances in this new version were superb, but the standout was Florence Pugh as Amy.  Pugh's more willful Amy often stole the scenes from Saoirse Ronan's Jo.    This version also expanded on the relationship between Amy and Laurie, so their final love seemed more deserving and natural than the other version.  The ending was also more crowd-pleasing than the 1994 version: everyone lived happily ever after, so much so that I felt this version should have been a Disney movie.

The 90s little women was so good, I feared I couldn't give this one a fair shot. The synergy between the sisters in the original, Susan Sarandon as the archetypal mother, Winona Ryder winning the hearts of so many women with her performance as joe; but like any lover of that film; I wanted to see how this one stacked up. 

Saoirse (sp?) did a brilliant Jo, even if she can't approach Winona. Emma Watson was a respectable Meg. But the casting of Beth and Amy were flawed. To ask the audience to believe Florence Pugh (as Amy) is 8 or to care about Eliza Skanlen (as Beth) after her minimal screen time and impact were foul plays. No one will see the same woman who so adeptly plays a witch on big little lies as a convincing Marmy...Dern felt hollow. 

Now Timothy Chalamet...he really blew it! While this kid can act, in this film he gave us but one narcissistic and immature note. Perhaps the role to which he played a man child was intentional as this was a reinterpretation, but the result was someone I preferred not to see more of, and with whom I couldn't sympathize.

Saoirse and the beautiful costume and cinematography plus attention to historical detail made this film. While it won't be one I'll rewatch again and again, it was a highly enjoyable 145 minutes where Saoirse succeeded in getting at the heart of Jo March- a woman who was brave enough to be herself in a time this was a heroic act. That story is fresh all over again, in a time when women have renewed reasons to feel unsteady with our place in society.

What a great movie. Little Women is another retelling of the classic 1868 novel by Louisa May Alcott. This is directed by Greta Gerwig who did one my favorites Lady Bird (2017) and she absolutely knocked it out of the park with this one. Little Women is the story of four sisters and their coming of age story. Set during the late years of the Civil War we follow Jo March (Saoirse Ronan) an inspiring writer, Meg (Emma Watson) the eldest sister who wants a family, Amy (Florence Pugh) a talented artist, but always feels she's battling it out with Jo, and Beth (Eliza Scanlen) who is excellent at playing Piano, but very much a quiet and to herself kind of person. The four girls live with their mother Marmee (Laura Dern) while their father (Bob Odenkirk) is away during the way. The movie is shown in the present time with all four sisters away trying to find themselves Jo is out in New York trying to be a writer, Amy is off at Europe with their somewhat mean Aunt March (Meryl Streep) learning more about art, Meg has married, but lives close by to their original home and Beth has stayed home because her health is declining. When a letter reached Jo that Beth has gotten deathly ill she drops everything and returns home which in turns churns memories of their times as kids seven years past. Jo recalls meeting Theodore 'Laurie' Laurence (Timothee Chalamet) the grandson of their neighbor Mr. Laurence (Chris Cooper). Laurie has always been very close to the March family and is in a bit of a love triangle with Jo and Amy. Jo has to finally decide by the end whether or not a women like herself can be sufficient by herself, or does in fact need a man like Laurie. There's obviously way more to it, but I've already said too much about the plot here. I really loved this movie a lot. The performances are outstanding. The four sisters are very believable as their interactions are very sibling like. We get a lot of arguments, but we get a lot of love. I liked how you really felt for them as they were going through their own issues. Beth is probably the character we get the least out of, but it fits her character since she's the least spoken out of the four. Timothee Chalamet is absolutely fantastic as Laurie. He really embodies this character and you get a feel for what he's going through especially after a harsh turn down from Jo. I liked this film and through it has a great plot (based on the novel) as well as some outstanding performances. This is one not to miss. Definitely, check this one out while it's in theaters!

Little Women is written and directed by Greta Gerwig, and is the 7th film adaptation of the 1868 novel. Greta Gerwig truly is one of the best young writers and directors working today. She excels at translating compelling dialogue from paper onto the screen, which otherwise may not work for many other writer/directors. Lady Bird is one of my favorite films of 2017 and definitely one of the best that year. Honestly, I didn't expect anything of this film, and I believed that I would end 2019 not even having seen it. I haven't seen any of the previous adaptations, and frankly this story just didn't interest me. My biggest fear was that I would be bored with the film, but gladly that wasn't the case! I really enjoyed this film; I was engaged the entire time, mainly appreciating the phenomenal script, amazing performances, and the beautiful costumes and 19th-century set pieces. There is a framing device used of jumping between flashbacks and future events, with the flashbacks being brightly lit, and the future events being a lot colder, in more of a grey tint. Toward the film's end, the cuts between time periods tend to jump a bit sporadically and the colors blend, so it's likely some may get lost in what is happening on screen. This is the film's biggest flaw for me, and yet is still full of wonderful, warm, tragic, and heartbreaking stories.

Eliza Scanlen, Laura Dern and Timothée Chalamet are excellent in their roles. Florence Pugh is a STAR and I'm always excited to see what she has coming next. She has had a brilliant last couple of years, everything she has done, one amazing performance after the next! But this really is Saoirse Ronan's film. Her chemistry with the rest of the cast, her sisters, other family members and friends is great; such a treat to see these stories unfold as the cast works off each other's passion. Again, just as with Lady Bird, she gives an out of this world performance. This team of Greta Gerwig, Timothée Chalamet, and Saoirse Ronan will always make magic, I'm sure. So glad to say I enjoyed this film so much, ending my 2019 film journey on a positive note! I definitely recommend seeing and supporting it.

My eleven-year-old daughter and I went to see this movie, after anticipating it from seeing the trailer. Unfortunately, the trailer portrays the only good 2 minutes of the entire jumbled up movie. So many things were rotten that I'll just hit the highlights. 
1. Jo was the only believeable character - and I'm even a fan of Laura Dern. But no, this part was not for her.
2. The monologues when the characters were reading letters was cringy to put it in my daughter's words. Out of place, awkward and did not fit with the rest of the movie.
3. Why not just tell the story from start to finish, like the book, instead of doing 3-time-warp-flash-back-and -forward until the viewer's head is spinning. The only way you can tell time keeps swapping back and forth is the length of Jo's hair.
4. Laurie looks like a 14-year-old boy throughout the entire movie.
5. Amy looked like a 30-year-old woman throughout the entire movie, she's too rough around the edges, not believable as one of the little women. Nothing about this actress says Little Women, not her voice, her looks, her acting. Terrible casting.
Major disappointment. There's several hours and $25 of our life, wasted.

(12/29/19) Movie ‘Little Women' : Written and directed by Greta Gerwig (who also directed ‘Lady Bird'), this is absolutely the WORST movie I've seen in recent years. It unequivocally affirms my worst opinion of Rotten Tomatoes, which positively rates this movie at 95%.

This movie is all-round bad. Its poorly written script fundamentally changes the original story just to inject a faux feminist overtone. So is its casting. In trying to distinguish it from previous movie adaptations (and presupposing its audience already knows the story), this movie randomly flips the timeline and sequence of events back-and-forth. Not only does it kill plot cohesion, it fails to give most actors a chance to develop their roles. Purporting to address the issue of feminism of this era (Massachusetts during the Civil War in 1860's), it blasts marriage as merely an ‘economic proposition', which is true - except it does so casually in 3 lines of one dialog. 

In my view, the 1949 (Elizabeth Taylor) and 1994 (Susan Sarandon) adaptations of ‘Little Women' are fantastic classics. Why they bother to make such an inferior one in 2019 really beats me. Only guess is : director Greta Gerwig has no clothes !

Missed the mark entirely. The talent of the cast was completely wasted and ruined a classic tale. Emma Watson is wasted as Meg, and would have served better as Jo.  The list goes on, but it missed the mark

Little Women
Little Women is a timeless story told through the lenses and pen of the talented Greta Gerwig. Do we need a new version of Alcott's masterpiece? It's the question that everyone, included me, asked when the project was mentioned in 2018 and indeed we needed to see for the first time Alcott's characters be freed of the commercial stereotype of what a women's novel and their fictional ladies must do to be liked.
Beautifully shot in Massachusetts, the place where Alcott grew up, we see the March sisters story develop not in a linear narrative but through the eyes and experiences of each sister in different points in their life. This decision fleshes out Meg, Amy, Beth and Jo, we truly see what drives each character included their passion and fears, we no longer vilify Amy as a spoiled brat, we can understand her frustration of not being quite as talented as she hoped for in her paintings and Beth and Marmee are more human; they finally acknowledge the injustice of Beth's fate which makes it easy for Marmee to say ‘that she is angry everyday', this characters are no longer porcelain dolls but human beings.  
Jo March the fearless leader who was portrayed with great pathos by Saoirse Ronan is no longer the focal point of this story thanks to Gerwig's direction we finally see the story of the other characters develop in their point of view. Meg's story is of sacrifice and patience what most women's story was about at that time when they married for love, Beth's innocence and Amy's ambition and frustration of wanting more in a world in which women weren't allowed to be themselves. The male gaze is well represented through their companions, but no one shines brighter that Chalamet's Laurie a vulnerable and lost boy who is adopted and cared for by the March family and who later matches Amy's bravado and accepts Jo's friendship.
This story was brilliantly told through flashbacks and we can see the golden glow of childhood when hopes and dreams are built and the gray palette of adulthood. This film is a masterpiece of dialogue adapted by Gerwig and finally be told like Alcott would have wanted, it took 151 years but the story of the March sisters and their complex relationships and life was finally set free of romanticism.
It was a fresh approach to the story that made it very enjoyable. The actors were excellent!

Greta Gerwig directs the 3rd adaptation of the beloved book by Louisa May Alcott
first there was the 1940's version then the 1990's version, however, none of them have been able to capture the spirit of the novel
with this version it stays more true to the source material exploring a lot more themes and ideas for the female perspective
set during the aftermath of the Civil War 4 sisters Jo, Meg, Amy and Beth whom live together with their mother hoping to find their own dreams to live happy, fulfilled lives from the restraint of the patriarchal society
Gerwig does her own spin on this story with a splendid cast from Saiorse Ronan to Emma Watson to Florence Pugh to Laura Dern to Meryl Streep
the main focus is Jo wanting to be an aspiring author; she wants to have her manuscript published risking a large investment and failure but also reaching out to many women about how they should be allowed to have free thinking
even today it's tiring to explain to everybody that a woman should have her own voice, options, way of living, dreams, ambitions, even struggles 
a woman's whole purpose isn't to just fall in love and get married, potential happyness and fulfillment are still there
Meg wants to be a successful actress on stage while also finding the right person to spend her life with and raise a family, but Jo has a tough time understanding that just because she also has dreams doesn't make her own less than important
Amy wants to paint and sell her artwork but doesn't want marriage in the slightest if it isn't beneficial for her and her spouse, she sees marriage as only a transactional act, no freedom comes from matrimony or even having children
Beth is a musician at heart and is perfectly content with bringing joy to the fold 
Aunt March is the more stern member of the family being fabulously wealthy with no husband to weigh her down, still she wants the best for all 4 sisters to have the best lives they can; manageable and smart 
The main male love interest is Laurie looking for the completion of happiness but which sister will he choose if not Jo?
Jo's book is the summation of the life she has experienced changing her as well as her family through all the joys and hardships 
Most of the narrative switches between the past and the present making it a big jarring at times and it is a bit long but Gerwig cleverly assembles this group of ladies exploring that strong bond of sisterhood and feminist staying power 
This might be the best adaptation of the book yet

Thanks to its excellent cast, beautifully crafted screenplay and excellent directing, this re-adaptation of 'Little Women' is a force to be reckoned with.

My mom wasn’t much of a reader but her favorite book was Louisa May Alcott’s Little Women. I grew up a voracious reader and never read it. Go figure. Over the 150 years since it’s 1868/9 publication, Little Women has been made into multiple movies, stage plays, television series and even an opera. How can this uber familiar story possibly be told again? We all know the plot, the characters and the raison d'être. Little Women was the choice for our family’s going-to-a-movie-every-Christmas-Day tradition. Entertain me. Educate me. Encourage me. Please. And it did! The scenery gorgeous, characters delightful, story irresistible. I can understand why Little Women offered a now tame, but in the day a groundbreaking invitation for young ladies to envision and expand their life possibilities. At the same time, a woman’s traditional, domestic lifestyle, challenged by feisty, brilliant Jo was preserved by beautiful, bright Meg. The revolutionary notion introduced by Alcott is choice. The film follows the March family –conventional Meg (Emma Watson), writer Jo (Saoirse Ronan), pianist Beth (Eliza Scanlen), artist Amy (Florence Pugh) and doting mother Marmee (Laura Dern) as they come to maturity during and after the Civil War. Rounding out the central figures are lad Laurie (Timothee Chalamet) a wealthy, orphaned neighbor who becomes a de facto family member and prosperous, spinster Aunt March (Meryl Streep), the self-appointed guardian of social pedigree, looking for at least one niece who will marry well, salvage the family name and keep the “Family March” afloat. The flashback, nonlinear way the story is told caused me some confusion but I finally came up with my own cues to alert me to time shifts and guide my tracking. It’s no fun to be left behind, stuck in the past when the action jumps to the future. Hey, where’d everybody go! The film is full of romance, unrequited and realized, tragedy and comedy, poignant moments and outrageous indiscretions. Little Women was the perfect Christmas Day movie. For the record, the theater was sold out and sitting next to me was an elderly Jewish woman with whom I enjoyed a festive chat waiting for the movie to start. As the lights went down I wished her a Happy Holiday and she wished me a Merry Christmas. And it truly was.

I’ve seen two other versions of this wonderful movie, but this one is BY FAR the best. The cast is perfect, the performances terrific, and I think having a woman leading the charge on this movie makes all the difference. It has so much heart. Characters are fleshed out beautifully. You’ll laugh, you’ll cry, and ultimately you’ll leave feeling good.

Now, I've never actually read Little Women by Louissa May Alcott, but I have vague memories of seeing a play of it when I was little and I've just now skimmed the Wikipedia expert so I guess I'm an expert now.
There's a lot to love about this new adaptation about Meg (Emma Watson), Jo (Saoirse Ronan), Beth (Eliza Scanlen) and Amy (Florence Pugh) March. The movie cleverly intertwines both the past and the present, contrasting the cheerful youth of the four sisters with the more dreary present. The flashbacks are all coated with warmer tones giving a sense of coziness to the girls memories in sharp contrast to the cold blues of the present. Little Women is not the first movie to have flashbacks in a different color tone than the main story, but Greta Gerwig manages to make all the colors come from the natural environment, making both the flashbacks and present day feel very real despite looking very different. 
The movie, like the story, centers around the second oldest sister, Jo, as she grows up over the seven-some years that the movie covers. Jo is tomboyish and generally opposed to playing the feminine part that society wants her to play. The movie begins with her struggling as a writer in New York, writing harsh and violent stories in an effort to make her writing relevant in a world of men. Despite managing to sell many of her stories, she is told very early on by a fellow tutor at the home that she works at teaching children, Friedrich Bhaer (Louis Garrel), that her stories simply aren't good. The movie never admonishes her dislike of traditional femininity, but over the course of the movie she learns that it is possible to embrace her life as a woman and all that entails while still maintaining her sense of identity. Ronan excels both at her hard resilience against the marital institution and all other misogynistic institutions and the softer, more sensitive side of Jo that loves her sisters and eventually 
Little Women ends up being both a celebration for both women who fight against society and push for greatness and women who choose to live a domestic life with a husband and kids and women who choose to live both lives. The movie begins with Jo's publisher saying that if she is going to write a female protagonist that she has to be either married at the end or dead and it's treated as if it's another example of the suppression of women's stories. Then, at the very end of the movie, when Jo has brought her new novel, an autobiography or memoir finally allowing Jo to embrace her domestic side, to be published, the same publisher insists that if Jo needs to marry off her protagonist, an extension of Jo herself, saying that marrying the protagonist off isn't patriarchal, it's romantic. Once again there's a hint of misogyny, but Jo amusedly agrees to the marriage as the movie intercuts to her chasing her recently discovered love Bhaer to the train station. 
The rest of the sisters build off this film in their own ways. There's a flashback early on in the movie where each girl through some way or another announces their passion and what they want to do with their lives. Meg wants to be an actress, Beth wants to play music and Amy wants to be a painter. Out of the three, Florence Pugh is easily the strongest as Amy. Amy has similar ambition to Jo, but also loves elegant life and realizes that she will have to marry rich in order to provide for her family. Pugh manages to turn what would otherwise be an annoying, selfish character into a real person who's attention seeking as most younger siblings are while also ambitious and yearning for genius or something that could let her make her mark in a world of men while also being very aware that she'll have to marry some rich man simply to have money that she can take care of her sisters and family with. Pugh becomes almost a second lead to Ronan, rivaling her in depth and growth in character. Unfortunately, Emma Watson and Eliza Scanlen get less to do with Meg and Beth respectfully. Emma Watson plays Meg similarly throughout the entire movie and although there is some sort of sub-plot of her learning to settle for domesticity with her husband John Brooke (James Norton), it doesn't quite feel that she's grown from the experience or changed at all. Scanlen does a fine enough job portraying Beth but unfortunately, the movie doesn't do quite enough to endear us to her besides the occasional nice thing that she says followed by all the sisters saying that "Beth is the best of us". The fact that Beth never quite comes into her own as a character diminishes the emotional punch of her death somewhat and makes her appear as more of a narrative device to allow Jo to embrace domestic life more. Nevertheless, Scanlen portrays the shy warmth of Beth very well and, what the script lacks, she is able to make up.
The rest of the supporting cast fares about as well as the sisters, with a few shining while a few others disappoint. Timothée Chalamet excels as Laurie, playing both the lazy, rich boy along with the endearing neighbor and love interest. Chris Cooper does a fine job as his grandfather Mr. Lawrence and Meryl Streep turns in a very entertaining role as Aunt March. It's Laura Dern however, that proves to be the weakest, not that she isn't trying, but it is simply hard to believe her as the mother to the four girls. As for Bob Odenkirk and Tracy Letts, they play such insignificant roles that you wonder why they're in the movie at all even though Amy needs a love interest and the sisters need a father. The movie might have benefitted from cutting them all together, because as it is it's asking the audience to have some connection to characters that almost don't exist.
In the end Little Women will be very poignant for some and a enjoyable enough use of two hours for others. This isn't a movie that's going to blow a lot of people away, but what you're left with is a well crafted story of family and femininity that gets better and better the more you think about it.

P.S. Emma Watson really struggled with an American accent, I'm not normally the type of person to pick up on these things but it was painfully obvious at many points.

The good: All the actors give outstanding performances (Saoirse Ronan, Florence Pugh, Emma Watson, Timothée Chalamet, and Laura Dern in particular). Ronan, Chalamet, Watson, and Dern especially breath life into this otherwise colorless and dry film. The writing demonstrates an understanding of realistic conversation.

The bad: The score is forgettable, the cinematography is bland, and the characters are either one-dimensional, unlikeable, or both. The exceptions being Chalamet and Dern's characters. The plot is non-existent for the most part, and what is there is boring and predictable.

Overall, if you're looking for great performances and dialogue overshadowed by a paper-thin plot and forgettable, underdeveloped characters, this movie is for you.

I generally don't like "chick flicks" (e.g., "Bridges of Madison County", "Beaches", the 'message in the bottle' movie with Robert Redford, etc.) and feared that this would be one of those - but it wasn't.  I thoroughly enjoyed watching the young ladies recognize (and give voice to) the impediments that women faced in their time (and to a certain extent, currently) - and how they overcame them. 

The acting was first-rate by all. Although he had a relatively small (but important) role - I liked Chris Cooper and imagined the Bourne Identity guy gets older, mellows and meets the Marches. I've liked Emma Watson in many of the things she's done - and she doesn't disappoint in this movie.  Saoirse Ronan was spectacular.  I'd never seen (nor even heard of) either Florence Pugh or Eliza Scanlen - but they did fine jobs and I'll look for them in future movies.

As (necessarily) with all movies of great books - I found the plot/character development to be a bit thin. Why did Amy get to go to Europe instead of Jo? Did young Meg really want to become an actress - and if so, how did John Brooke woo her away from that ambition? What did Beth actually die of - and over what period of time?  I'm sure these and other questions were more fully developed in the book. I think it's the sign of a good movie when it makes me want to read the book(s) on which it is based - and this one did.  I think that the idea of telling the story in a series of flash-backs and flash-presents was a good one (my wife, who has read the books, tells me that the story is presented in the books in a strictly chronological manner).

All in all - it's an engaging movie that is part 'buddy' movie and part 'family' movie that shows how a group of ambitious, plucky young ladies find themselves and overcome both emotional and societal hurdles to reach a (mostly) happy ending.  I'd recommend it to everyone.

I waited months to see this movie! I never read the book so this version may be more accurate than the other films. Here is what I have a hard time wrapping my mind around: Amy is too old in this version. She looks the oldest and her voice is quite deep, therefore, she comes across much older. Because she comes across as a 20-something-year-old, versus a young girl, it's hard to root for her. When she threw Jo's work in the fire, she just appeared as a witch. The love that these sisters have for one another never comes through. Plus, the scene where Amy is in school, and gets hit, she looks so out of place because she looks too old. I never felt anything for her. She just comes across as a spoiled, entitled brat. Laurie and Friedrich were cast too young. Especially when they shared the scene with one of the sisters. The mother, Mary March, says that she spent nearly 40 years working on her temper. There is no way that Laura Dern looks 30ish. The camera did a close-up when she said this, and all of Laura's wrinkles and neck was in full display. The ending, when Jo and the editor turned to talk to the camera, was ... cringy. It was so out of place. So too was the scene when Freidrich came by Jo's house, and she turned around and faced her family, then they raced to the train station. The movie got so corny towards the end.

I was expecting a beautiful adaption of the novel. I got that and so much more: stunning cinematography, perfect casting from top to bottom, a screenplay that is both a fully faithful and fully original take on the source material, a nuanced exploration of hardship and what it means to forge your own path in life, and a fiercely beautiful feminist manifesto that perfectly complements the very human drama of each of the main characters. This is about as perfect of a film as I could have asked for and the themes are still so very relevant that it felt like it was speaking right to my soul.
And a final note: the originality of the screenplay, the way it shifts seamlessly backwards and forwards in time to create a thematic approach to the novel, is beautiful and so well done that this film definitely deserves the award for best adapted screenplay.

Unlike many, I wasn't that high off of Greta Gerwig's hit "Ladybird". It was fine, but in my opinion not the coming of age tale many pushed it up to be. I won't say that about her take on "Little Women", a telling of the classic that gives her plenty of space to deliver a very beautiful film.

Saoirse Ronan, Emma Watson, Florence Pugh, and Laura Dern, are just part of this critically successful cast that walks us through the path of the March sisters as they grow up and make life changing decisions through the good times and the bad.

The material is no trouble for this group of all stars, but Gerwig paints us a beautiful period piece that makes this world both happy and world when needed, as well as cold and devastating as our characters move along. There are some wonderful shots that moves us through fancy French parties and Christmases in the March household with little trouble.

When you combine the talent that is everywhere in this film, along with the direction, there just isn't any space for this movie to fail. And I haven't even mentioned Meryl Streep.

Of course, this story won't be for everyone and it's not "The Fast and Furious", you're going to have to work with this film's slower pace.

But if you have the patience, I think you'll find "Little Women" to be quite enjoyable and that really falls on Gerwig.

I only have raves for Little Women. The latest incarnation from Greta Gerwig drags the tale into the 21st century without losing the magical prose that makes the book a classic. Previous versions offered up one dimensional and saccharin sweet portraits of the sisters. Gerwig's version allows for the characters to behave like children growing into adulthood. Giving the girls a full range of emotions. Boisterous and joyful. Jealousy and rage. Vulnerable and ambitious. With a wink to the fact Jo's marriage was an economic requirement for the book publisher. Luara Dern's Marmie was a stand out.

That was messy. I'll stick with the book or the 1994 movie version, which was a 100% better adaptation. 
I almost walked put, and wish I would have because the last 10 minutes was maybe the worst part of the film.

This is the instagram generation version of the Little Women. The visuals are great, mostly, but the story is told out of order to try to group the emotional moments together (?) and draw parallels. This not work for a couple reasons - it destroys the character development... we know that Jo declined Teddy before it happens and that Jo likes to dance with a man. The make-up (or lack there of) makes it difficult to follow when was 'present' and when was 'past.' While there is a 7 year span covered all the actors appear to be the same age the whole time. And while the performances were fine is a bit understated it was hard to believe that Beth was on death's door.  On the other hand script and performance of Aunt March is an improvement on the 1994 version - which I much prefer on every other aspect except the lovely expansive visuals and Aunt March.

The timeline jumps around making it extremely hard to follow especially if you are new to the book/movie. Some of the characters are grossly miscast. It does not hold a candle to the far superior 1994 version with Winona Ryder.
Alcott is rolling in her grave! This movie is loosely based on the book. Prepare to have a political agenda that is already accepted pushed down your throat. The one star is for Timmy. Loved him!

I just saw this film which was set contemporaneously with Gone with the Wind but in the North in Ma and NYC rather than deep in the south. It was a feel-good (mostly) heart-felt story with (mostly) attractive actresses and heart-felt true-to-life emotionality/sentiment. It was definitely a tale of sentiment and sensibility a la Jane Austen. I would say it was most like her Pride and Prejudice in terms of mood and content and characters. There was tremendous sympathy and understanding to the point that even fairly insensitive guys should be able to connect with the lead characters. Joe was a lot like Elizabeth Bennet. I liked the way intellectual and artistic (painting and musical) pursuits were treated with respect.  Note also that the general foci of historical fiction was inverted in this case so that what is usually found in the foreground, the war, receded into the background and what was usually in the background, the domestic life, moved to the foreground. Incidentally the tragedy involving scarlet fever was similar to what my dad experienced as a boy though he survived and lived to the age of 82.

Having read the book, I found the actresses spot on in their portrayal of the March sisters.  The use of flashbacks effectively brought out story themes.  
Two drawbacks were the cramming of events into certain scenes in particular Beth visiting the family, receiving the piano and Mr. Lawrence concerned about her feverish condition.  The other was the removal of biblical reference that Alcott used throughout the book and in particular following the giving of the Christmas dinner.  Faith undergirded the March family. To fully understand and appreciate the intensity of Jo's journey into adult hood her reference to loving your neighbor as yourself was a significant expression Alcott introduced in chapter one.

In spite of its efforts to showcase women finding their direction in Victorian New England, most of this film felt frivolous. Yes it played up feminist themes (to marry or to work?). But none of the women managed to remain free of the desire to fulfill their lifes destiny and marry, in spite of how the institution extinguished the possibility of any professional life. I guess we should collectively applaud the sisters enlightened career goals. I actually got bored and wanted to leave early, and that just never happens to me. A big disappointment!
