I had high hopes and high standards for this adaptation of a classic. I did find it an enjoyable time at the theater however, I still believe the 90s version reigns supreme. I did appreciate the development of Amy and Beth and the depth it added. Timothee Chalamet and Saoirse Ronan were pure gold and the entire movie had some amazing moments of scripted brilliance. On the negative side, this film jumped around between flashbacks and it is often hard to know where you are in the storyline even for a true fan let alone my father who was a trooper in seeing this film over something with more fire power. Greta is a brilliant writer but the cinematic direction lacked detail and moments of quiet where the actions of the characters could speak for themselves. I was very displeased with the last 15-20 mins. Felt it was written with an inside joke/ or on a cultural note of today without being true to the novel. I would watch again, but it wont replace Winonas version in my heart.

A fresh and worthy treatment of a beloved classic, Greta Gerwig’s celebration of Little Women (and of Louisa May Alcott herself) bursts with joi de vivre, tugs at the heart strings, and earnestly endears while proving that a story (and especially a error piece) does not need to be bastardized to be more “edgy”, cannibalized, or dumbed down to feel relevant and relatable. A fantastic cast under inspired direction, Greta’s passion, love, and appreciation for the original work shines through every scene warmly.
A little slow in the middle, but a great movie.

Jo and Bhear loving each other didn’t make any sense. They barely knew each other. I didn’t feel any chemistry with Teddy and Amy either. So far, the 1994 version remains my favorite of this movie.

This is a show I'll sit down and watch with my (unborn) daughters in 10 years. Brava, brava!!

I liked the different perspective in this new version. Its more focused on the latter part of the book. It incorporates Jos writing career and gives a little more attention to the love stories. I went into this movie skeptical and I left loving this movie!

Quiet, intentional, unannounced shifts in time frame from scene to scene are gently challenging and disruptive of the natural somnolence of passive moviegoing. Not everyone may readily take to it. I didn't, but by-midfilm I found it invigorating and distancing in a way that forced me to more intentionally, and less automatically, process the lives of these women. Enchanting performances, humbly gorgeous cinematography, and pitch-perfect art direction. Meryl Streep will be the performance to beat for Supporting Actress -- she anchors an already solid production with the perfectly-rendered Aunt March. A worthy, charming, quietly courageous retelling.
One of the great novels and movie all time. Current versions acting was superb.

This movie was absolutely brilliant. Greta Gerwig's adaption and direction are inspired and incredible. The performances were nothing short of stellar. Especially that of Saiorse Ronan and Florence Pugh. Florence made Amy more accessible and likeable that in other adaptions of this story. Saiorse's portrayal of Jo was completely visceral and compelling. This story is classic for a reason and needed to be told in this time. The lessons to be learned still hold true and are as prominent as ever thanks to Greta's screenplay. I can't say enough good things about this movie.

"Little Women" | C- |  Transforming a timeless classic into a disjointed, boring, chemistry-free misfire should be a crime. To understand just how bad the direction is, watch the continuity errors in the first 3 minutes & midway when "Jo" is eating a piece of bread (spoiler alert: it disappears from her hand).  In addition to amateurish direction, boring script / story changes, casting four actresses as sisters who look nothing like each other, odd time shifts, etc. --- Timothee Chalament & Meryl Streep's worst performances in years should disqualify Gerwig from an Oscar nomination; despite the "we demand a female director nominee" B.S.

Shot beautifully, and very well acted. Chemistry between the actors and characters made the story believable. Beautiful story told beautifully. Not predictable in the best way for those who have not read the book. You definitely do not have to have read the book to enjoy this movie (I did not, and easily understood everything). Watching this movie is like a breath of fresh air,  it is immersive from the start, feels new, and the time seems too pass too quickly, making you crave more. My only critique would be that it cannot last forever.
Worst movie I’ve ever been dragged to
Loved the movie. Based on my favorite book of all times, they hit all the important parts of the book.

The individual performances of Little Women were sublime, but in the midst of Saoirsa Ronan et al's grandstand performances, something warm went missing. The homey love of the March family is the backbone of Little Women in every incarnation, and in Gerwig's adaptation, it is presumed. We do not come to love the March women's unyielding loyalty to each other and each other's dreams. We come to quake at their individual resilience. The latter should not have required the loss of the former. But I'm afraid that is what happened.

Until today I had never experienced the story of "Little Women" in any form. I have not read the classic book and I haven't seen any film adaptations that came before. When it comes to this new movie, I thought it was very good. Greta Gerwig did a first-rate job behind the camera yet again and her passion for telling this story shows. Typically period piece stories don't engage me easily, but I liked this one simply because the characters are portrayed so well and are genuinely interesting. I thought all of the performances in this movie were fantastic. The movie didn't always grip me in its first half, but by the time it ended, it carried a lot of emotional weight and won me over. Overall, the movie is skillfully directed, superbly acted and a real joy to watch.

I didn't find it as great as it was made out to be by reviewers and critics. I couldn't stop comparing it to the Winona Ryder movie (with Christian Bale as Laurie, Kirsten Dunst as Amy, Claire Danes as Beth, and Susan Sarandon as Marmee), and found it quite poor in comparison. I really like Timothy Chalamet, but found him a total miscast as Laurie. Meryl Streep was wasted as the aunt, as was Emma Watson as Meg. From what I heard, the ending was supposed to be different from the original — Greta Gerwig supposedly gave Jo the ending she would have liked. I don't see how — she still gets married to the immigrant professor she meets in New York. And the ending of this movie was so mushy — it's all one, big, happy family at the the house Jo has converted to a school.

Saoirse Ronan is an absolute triumph in this lovely film. I have never read the book, so I have nothing to compare it to, but I really enjoyed the film. Every one of the ladies, and gentlemen, are fantastic in their respective role. The internal struggle that Jo feels is evident within every scene. Timothy Chalamet does a fantastic job in his playboy role that has an internal fight to grow up to be with Jo or to continue living his life carefree. The chemistry between him, Florence Pugh, Ronan, and Chris Cooper is so great. The actors play off each other making the audience truly believe in their roles. All in all a great movie that everyone should see.

This heartfelt movie is still an inspiring coming of age in America in the aftermath of the Civil War. The March sisters are so loving, but so different from one another. The whole family stands by each other through difficult and changing times.

How can the 9th remake of a beloved story FINALLY get things right after the 8 predecessors fell short. The key? Greta Gerwig! Okay and Florence and Saoirse. And honestly Meryl is at her best since August Osage County.
I laughed, I cried, it’s perfect.

Greta instills the lushness & warmth that we crave from the story, but also fuses in her inventive, emotional, nostalgic, GENIUS perspective to freshen the story up & have it rip up our hearts. Every performance (especially Saoirse's, Florence's, and Timothée's) is fully realized and powerfully fierce. I can't say enough about this instant-favorite film. Greta is a GIFT to the world at a time when we most need it & I can't wait to see what her career brings us five or ten films down the line if she's already creating masterpieces like this with her SECOND film. Saoirse & Timmy forever. Please go see this, I promise you'll be changed. THE ENDING THOUGH.... a cubist, multi-layered, open-ended meta-narrative that only a pure original genius mind like Greta could pull off.

Most of the characters are not developed and therefore not loveable.  Laurie never becomes a man. Amy remains spoiled and unlikable. Beth dies with no one shedding a tear in the audience. I have mixed feelings. The settings were beautiful, and the acting was very good. Emma Watson wasn't bad. Ronan, Pugh, and Scanlen were excellent. While I thought this movie was beautifully done and had several qualities I wish I had seen in the 1994 version, i cannot give it 5 stars. What I loved: The relationship between the sisters felt so organic and loving that I was instantly convinced of their wonderful bond and just like the book, it won me over. And the longer version of Amy and Laurie’s romance was sweet and helped you understand and applause his change of heart. All the actors did amazing and as always I bow to the incomparable Meryl Streep! Now for what I didn’t like: The one main thing I didn’t like was the sequence of the time line. The constant flash backs made you feel a little disconnected from key points in the story. While certain moments were still tearjerkers, I felt uninvested in certain characters enough to where I walked away dry eyed. Overall this was a gorgeous movie that leaves you feeling warm and and fuzzy!

I thought Little Women was emotionally cold and at times emotionless. There were many parts of the movie where they needed more character development and less scenery. Cinematically, it is beautiful, but I did not care what happened to the characters, and scenes which should have been very important were not explained, so you just missed the point if you had never read the book. This is not something that other adaptations have missed. And there are some big problems with Amy. In what world would they have the same adult actress play the 12 year old girl. It just does not make sense. And there are very pivotal scenes with Amy and Beth, where you just do not care, and I was shocked at how those plots were not developed. Maybe, it was just taken as a given that everyone knew the story, and they were driving home a modern narrative, but it did not work.

Don't believe the big-media reviews. I've read them and am convinced none actually saw the movie (or saw it sober). Case-in-point reviewer from WSJ refers to Mr. Laurence as Laurie's father (he's his grandfather.) The movie is very hard to follow unless you know the book/previous movies. Their relationships and interactions are far too contemporary/modern. It's missing the chemistry in the relationships - that of the sisters (key!), Marmee and the girls and romances. Completely shocking with all these A-list actors. Seeing roots Demarcation in Marmee's hair in the first scene was a distraction out of the gates. Casting was odd overall. Very little character development. Jo was the best character. Emma Watson's Meg had some nice moments, too. She had inconsistently in her accent. Which is a bugger. Too much telling - not enough showing. It was a little preachy at a few spots - which was an unnecessary addition to drive home feminist slant of the story that tells that on it's own merits. There were parts that were very visually rich. The soundtrack got better about 1/2 way through.

Excellent ensemble acting is the main reason to see this new telling of the classic story. Some have lauded this version's time-traveling, non-linear screenplay, but on first viewing I found it confusing at times, taking me out of the otherwise immersive atmosphere. I'm sure those who know the classic novel's story by heart will more likely immediately love the playful tweaking by screenwriter/director Gerwig, though, and I enjoyed and appreciated her adaptation technique much more when I saw the film again a week later. Saoirse Ronan, Florence Pugh, Laura Dern and Timothee Chalamet are standouts, but really everyone featured here has their shining moments. One noticeable thing that bugged my best friend and I:  we saw and heard absolutely nothing that kept this from being rated "G," and it would've added to the quiet joy of an escape from modern snark this film is to have been one of the very few "G"-rated grown-up films made in recent decades. This movie is a true work of cinematic art. Having read the book to prepare for watching the film, it is such a great adaption of the literary classic. In my opinion, this film shows why Greta Gerwig is truly one of the greatest directors of this generation. By playing with the chronology several times throughout, she adds a whole new dimension to the story by making you like characters more than you initially thought you would. A few things are changed from the book but they work incredibly well. All the cast was just stellar, especially Saoirse Ronan. They really brought new life to the characters, by portraying them in a somewhat modern way. If you are going to see a film this holiday season, this movie should definitely be near the top of your list.

This film is hard to follow with all the jumping it does in the timeline. Some parts you aren't sure if the girls are young or adults. There were also moments of straight up feminist speeches that I do not recall being a part of the book. I understand what they were getting at, but I didn't need to be clobbered over the head with it. The film added some nice scenes not had in other versions, but it sacrificed development of Beth and the relationship between Jo and Professor Bahr(?) is almost completely unexplained. Suddenly at the end, we learn she loves him with hardly any understanding of their friendship. Meg and John's marriage also feels like it comes out of the blue.  Also, when they sent letters, they broke the fourth wall which was a bit random feeling. I'm still processing the movie since watching it this afternoon... but my main reaction is it's interesting in parts, but falls flat in too many ways to justify recommending that others see it in theaters.

So my critique of Little Women 2019.

It was good.  Not as good as the 1994 version, which in my opinion is close to perfect.  And personally I really like 2018 modern version.

Likes:  Laura Dern as Marmee .  Emma Watson as Meg.  

Timothee Chalamet is perfect as Laurie.  Best of any version.  He is Larie from the book.

Meryl Streep as Aunt March of course.

I liked how it showed Amy always being in love with Laurie and how he falls in love with her, instead of just suddenly they are married.

I thought it gave better depth to the characters.

What I didn't like:
The timeline jumps around.  It would be hard to follow if you haven't read the book multiple times.

Professor Brehr is too young.

Amy isn't pretty or flighty enough.

Beths character is not as fleshed out as the others so her importance to the family is lost.  And there is no death scene for Jo and Beth. You just see jo and marmee crying and then standing at the burial.

Wierd juxoposition of jo and an editor and makes it seem more like her imagining/writing a fictional story, then the characters living the story.

One of the best movies of 2019 (I should hit 50) by far. Saoirise Ronan and Laura Dern were OUTSTANDING, the remainder of the cast were absolutely solid with two exceptions. For some difficult to characterize reasons, Emma Watson did not warm up to the character she played (a frequent complaint), while the other sister actresses did so easily. The only person I thought was miscast was Chris Cooper, mostly because his voice and manner of speaking were jarring and did not seem to blend in easily in the late 1800's setting, although his role was supporting not a frequent distraction. Saoirise should easily get nominated for best actress (probably with Margot Robbie for Once ... in Hollywood), and Laura for supporting actress. I will probably see it again in the next week. Kudos to Greta Gerwig as well.

As someone who thoroughly enjoyed reading a good half of the Louisa May Alcott's book before viewing the film today, I have to say that I am thoroughly impressed by this film. The characters I just recently came to know and love in the first book are beautifully portrayed by the four actresses in the title roles. Charming and heartwarming, the film shines the brightest when the performers effectively and heartfeltly showcase the central relationships of the book (sisterly, romantic, and platonic). A solid supporting cast, beautiful visuals, and a sincere tone throughout round out some of the many positives of this film. 

I do have one negative aspect of the film to mention. My mother, who has never read the book, was understandably confused with some events of the film. Structurally, the film frequently bounces between the events of the first book, and seven years later (which is the focal period of time of the film). If you find yourself easily confused with stories that frequently bounce between events in time like this, I would advise that you at least read the first third of the eponymous book. This helped me immensely during the film (it's also a fantastic read anyway). If you neither have the will or the time to read it, I believe you will still get much from the film.

All in all, I would recommend lovers of the book, period-piece viewers, and anyone with a palate for a heartfelt story about a loving family to see this film. It is deserving of the praise it is getting.

The film is an absolute masterpiece. While standing as a strong and honorable homage to Louisa May Alcott's work, the film is both entertaining as it is poignant. The cast renders both powerful and nuanced performances in this period piece. Saiorse Ronan, Emma Watson, Florence Pugh, Timothee Chalamet, and Laura Dern are, without doubt, the most noteworthy standouts here. Another beauty worthy beholding is Alexandre Desplat's beautiful score that paints a beautiful soundscape for the characters' journey. It manages to incorporate an exquisite blend between the classical and the modern. Gerwig's work here will go on to be both celebrated and cemented into the fabric of classic Hollywood cinema. Splendid work. / 5 Stars
